I also wanted to try the Middle Eastern\/Mediterranean food, as I am Chaldean, but was sadly disappointed. The hummus was too "rough" and the tabbouleh was more brown than green. I tried a curry chicken dish which was pretty good, but ran out quickly and was never put out again in the time I was there. I had the same experience with the mac and cheese...which was delicious. It's the best thing I had there. They have a lot of desserts to choose from. I tried the mini mint cupcake and a mini gummy bear strawberry cupcake, not only are they cute, they were good too. My husband tried the cinnamon bread pudding and loved it, he said its the best thing he had there. 

The flow pattern was odd, which made it confusing for everyone walking around. There was no order, just people aimlessly walking up to stations and in your way the entire time. Granted, I understand it's Vegas and it's busy, but other buffets I've been to had a decent flow of the restaurant allowing people to take want they wanted, walk past what they didn't, and keep the line moving. People had no direction and were all over the place.  

There is a long line at all times, but the wait isn't worth what you're getting. Our "waitress" Danielle brought us water and coke then disappeared for about 20 minutes. We watched her serve and attend tables that came after us, but even after being flagged several times, she wouldn't come to us. My husband asked another server named Samantha to start taking care of us and our experience got a little bit better after that. Overall, I wouldn't recommend it.

I was super excited to see breakfast buffet being offered for $15 in the sleeve of the registration folder.  

Too bad the Sunday brunch is $23.95pp.  And really not so good:
-Greasy Chinese food, MSG laden, I did like the Napa Cabbage stir fry.
-Crab legs, ehh.  
-Shrimp cocktail, big, but don't be fooled.  
-Smoked Bacon, cold. 
-Thumbs up for having creamy balsamic dressing.
-Mmm...seaweed salad, a little icy, but still pretty good.
-TWO omelette stations.
-Weak fruit selection, very lacking in berries.  
-Desserts, it was cute how they all had 'Happy Father's Day' choco signs. 

Iced tea and hot green tea, both a thumbs down.  Skip it all together.
Love all the different variety of gourmet flavors.  With a bonus stare grazing view of a topical pool landscape.

Even with the notification of it being renovated does not really say much in terms of organization. I am not sure who designed the lay out in how the food should be organized but it makes no sense. Fellow Yelper Yvonne R. was right about how certain foods are found in random areas. You would think the signs that denote the type of foods there are would help. If you were asked, "Where did you get that?" some items will leave you kinda giving abstract directions in an unknown city. 

I did notice they have steam crab legs or fresh ones. I am wary to eat the seafood. I had the nigiri and the fish wasn't very fresh. I have to make note I did enjoy the brisket but it's weird because it looks like sauced ribs at the carving table. Do not be confused like me, then again I don't really eat red meat that often. There was not really a wait. I came here on a Friday around lunch time right after arriving into Las Vegas. The place is clean though and the restroom of course is outside the buffet.

The buffet here is very good from the food quality to the selection everything is great! I been here twice now,  I always start off with a salad and then make my way to the delicious crab legs and king crab legs they have both. 
They're macaroni is really good too, and I love how they have such a huge fruit and vegetable section. A huge upgrade from the buffet at Cosmo called wicked spoon .
Food is excellent at dinner time. Expensive but the food fills you up here. Takes way too long to seat us with a VIP card cmon!

This is my favorite buffet on the strip. The wait to get in is always long but to me it's worth it. I love the seafood station and the meat and cheese station. There is honestly so much to choose from that it's hard to decide. The layout and decor is also very nice. I keep coming back because there are so many quality options and it's really worth the money.

This is the Vegas buffet I have been to the most. Usually I'll go for brunch, but this time since I was staying at the Aria I decided that I would go for dinner. I went around 7pm on a Wednesday, and paid $37. I was in the fast lane due to a pearl card so only waited a couple minutes to enter. I seriously love this buffet. In the mornings they have pork belly that melts in your mouth along with a ton of delicious options. For dinner I enjoyed some great pizza, decent sushi, some prime rib, really good creamed spinach, some great salmon, and the winner of this buffet was the beef that they had at the Italian station. (not sure exact type). One of the only downsides that I can say about this buffet is that they have crab legs which although cooked well, they are not sliced and they don't give you crackers so you spend a long time trying to get the meat out of them. I was pretty full after eating the delicious selection so I only had a couple desserts: a piece of sugar free coconut cream cake and some flan. There is a nice big gelato wheel with several flavors on it which I did not do this time, but in the past I have enjoyed the peanut butter gelato, but it was not on the wheel this time so I guess they rotate the flavors.

let me get straight to the point: don't come here!

i paid $38.00 for a mediocre meal...and that was just the lunch price!

it's a typical buffet with a variety of food but the food wasn't amazing at all. the only items i really enjoyed was the prime rib and dessert bar....

refund please :(

I came here for dinner and i loved it! 
They had Awesome variety of salads which was amazingly good! I ended up getting 2 plates of salads! Haha
The seafood section was also quite good. Although it didn't have too many varieties but king crab, crawfish, mussels and shrimps were good enough! 
I also loved that they had so many kinds of dumplings! So yummm. 
The best part of this buffet is the dessert section! 
I have particularly sweet tooth and it was a trip to heaven for me. 
Their sugar free coconut cake was just melting in my mouth and the milk pudding(?) was just too good! Ahhh i want some more now! Haha 
They had whole variety of gelato available but i couldn't eat no more! 
Had the most wonderful meal on my last day in vegas! Woo hoo!!

My first time here was WAY better. I guess things can change for the worse over time. 

Seriously, what buffet doesn't have ham? I thought that was a requirement at Vegas buffets. When I came here the first time, they had this delicious honey baked ham and a coconut macaroon for dessert! It was one of the best macaroons I've ever had. Now, the only thing I like is their prime rib and that's not even that great. For $40 per person, I expected more. I mean, I'm not asking for fireworks, but at least put some more effort into it like you did before. VERY disappointed.

My boyfriend and I practically live in Vegas lol so this is our go to buffet every time. They have the most delicious selection of varieties of food. The seafood most importantly is always so fresh!!!

Crab legs, crab legs, crab legs.

Our family visited this buffet on Saturday Evening. Expected long line to be seated, there were few people out there and we were promptly seated. 

Craving crab as i seated beside the buffet tables. And there were lot more asian fusion. Chinese wonton soup, Japanese sushi. Salad, cheese, salamis, and desserts. 

The staffs were very friendly and the drinks were free. The end of the meal, we had coffee. It was gorgeous.

It's not the cheapest place to eat, but you do get what you pay for. For a meal at a AAA Five Diamond hotel, the offerings seem appropriate. I really appreciate that they try hard on the simple things. What could be an ordinary salad bar is anything but. On the night I visited, some of the pre-made salad options included "Duck Confit, Huckleberry & Spinach" along with "Roasted Asparagus, Crispy Onions & Field Greens." I've eaten here a few times, and I've never been disappointed by the food quality, the service or the modern atmosphere.

While the Mirage Buffet had gone downhill from my last visit there, I actually felt like the Aria had upped their quality and game a bit from my last visit.  While I don't think the food is fantastic there are a few things about it that keep me coming back.  The first thing I really appreciate is the fresh fruit on the Salad Bar.  I also love their Crab Legs.  They use King Crab instead of tiny Snow Crab like many other Buffets these days.  I also like the fact that their Crab Legs are served warm with drawn Butter instead of Cold with Cocktail Sauce!  If I am going to a Buffet the main thing I like to eat are Crab Legs and Shrimp.  The Prime Rib was fine but not great.  The other thing I love about the Aria Buffet is the desserts!  I guess Jean Philippe make their desserts and they are fantastic!!!  I love French Macarons!!!  Probably one of my favorite desserts.  They also always have Gelato and other great desserts as well.

Used a BOGO Lunch and at almost $40 was quite expensive but certainly the best meal we had while in Vegas.  It is not a huge buffet, but the food was all amazing.  Everything we tried was delightful!  Wish we could go back for more.

The buffet at Aria is wonderful!! The crab legs were fresh and hot and kept coming!  Wide variety of choices and the desserts were great!  Gelato is delicious. The only downside is the price $42 per person on Saturday night. But well worth it - I will definitely be back!

I just can't get over how awful this buffet is.  The best entree is the dry lukewarm crab legs and the almost expired tasting oysters... Thank god for the amazing host the magician and the balloon artist!  They distracted us from the almost edible fare and mediocre steak.  I tried a bite of almost everything that looked edible and yes I'm full but I am far from satisfied.   If we had paid full price I'd have been pissed!

All the meat was poor quality and overcooked. The dim sum was OK, great cured meats and cheeses. The shellfish was awful and the crab legs with ghee was my favorite part. The dessert selection is great but many poorly executed dishes. I only went because of proximity,  would not go back, and think it was very overpriced for the quality.
Good , solid place to enjoy while taking a break from the gambling. Ok food, nice atmosphere, medium high in price.

I was really excited to go back to the buffet since we were staying at ARia but when we got to the buffet line - the line for sky suites was longer than regular line and service was horrendous. 

We sat down and ordered drinks (no non dairy option for milk) and all our orders were wrong and the buffet isn't that big to start out and they don't have as many options if you are vegan or gluten free. None of the dishes are properly listed so you don't know what has dairy, gluten or anything at all. 

Chef that was working the Omelette station was rude and was screaming and got a simple eggwhite omelette wrong. 

When we sat back down after grabbing our below standard food, waitress was no where to be found and we couldn't get any drinks again.

What a waste of tummy space and our time. Wish we went to Cosmo or any other place for breakfast.

Great experience eating here although after eating 5,000 calories in one meal you get the feeling that you want to die.  

Seafood is excellent.  The crab legs and cooked jumbo shrimp make it worth paying the premium prices here.  Dessert and gelato are also tasty so save some room if that is even possible.

The overall feel of this buffet is upscale and they are very nice about not rushing you to finish.  Other buffets try to get you out of there as soon as possible to make room for new people but I definitely did not get that feeling here.

Completely average. Unless it's free (comps, MyVegas) skip this for something more worthwhile. If you piled all the casino buffets in the US into one list this would probably make the top third.

They did have a decent selection of meats at the carving station and lots of seafood choices.
It's a buffet....yawn (did I mention I'm not a big buffet fan).  Compared to other vegas buffets this one is very small.

This buffet was an incredible ripoff. The prices are the norm for a Las Vegas buffet but the food was reminiscent of something you'd find in Hometown. I found that the problem was they tried to cover too much ground. There was mexican, asian, seafood, pizza, etc but only a small tiny section of each. 

Mexican: I think I saw 4 things in their section. Enchiladas and Mexican rice were what I remembered. 

Asian: Decently sized but incredibly random. They had a platter of kimchi with chilled tofu\/cucumber salad on one side and purposely cold chicken noodles on the other.

A few steps down from the asian section were cut up chunks of cheese and deli meat placed on a carving board. 

Pizza: I never bother with buffet pizza but my boyfriend said it was really bad. 

Seafood: Cocktail Shrimp and Crab Legs period. 

Dessert: I picked up a cookie labeled chocolate chip only to find that it had nuts in it. Disappointed look for me but imagine if someone with a nut allergy had picked that one up. But even besides that, the cookies were pretty gross. I'd have to say i've tasted better from the bakeries at Ralph's or Safeway. Those actually semi-taste home-made but these tasted like they came from cardboard or out of a factory.

I was pleasantly surprised by this buffet. I have been living a keto lifestyle for a while now, and this place had everything I could want. The for was fresh, the line was short (I came at 2) and things tasted good

I would not eat here. I didnt have breakfast and ate here for lunch. I got sick pretty bad. How could i assume its other food if i didn't have breakfast.  
I def didn't have dinner afterwards cause i was feeling so nauseous.

Would i go here again? No.... pay approx $25 to get sick is not my idea of a good place to eat. 

Judge for yourself

I ate at many buffets in Vegas. The Aria buffet is overpriced and not impressive.  The staff were friendly and quick with drink refills.  The food was the same standard generic "buffet food" you can get any any 3 star hotel in Vegas for half the price.  The seating and atmosphere were great but they totally dropped the ball with the food. Check out the Wicked Spoon inside Cosmopolitan, that's an amazing buffet.

I thought it was good just a tad over priced. I mean I'm not a seafood person so I see why they charge so much on a Thursday night. They have a variety of food including tons of seafood and two carving stations with an array of meats and grilled veggies (my favorite). They also have some pre portioned sized plates which is great for those that want a sample sized amount. 

I would give it 4 stars if it wasn't so over priced.
I did a comparison to the ARIA, Bellagio and Mirage buffets.  I will be quick.  Pick the ARIA it is the best choice of these by far and you wont wait forever in line.

This was an outstanding buffet. None of the foods appeared warmed over or soaked in butter\/oil.

The king crab legs were cut in half, so you didn't have to break them yourself. They were outstanding. The boiled shrimp were fairly large, but still had shells. They had a three types of grilled\/baked fish.

The pizza was the best that I've had at a buffet. It was a cross between thin crust and a regular crust. 

The desserts were very, very good with unique designs. You almost have to see them, but they are all wonderful bite size desserts. These unique desserts included the Aria take on carrot cake, strawberry shortcake, and even the Oreo Cakester!!!

This buffet would have gotten 5 stars, but the salad bar was virtually not existant and the fruit selection was lacking.

However, overall, it was very good and much better than many of the other LV options!

***For the lunch buffet only***

With good reason, I'm not usually much of a fan of Vegas buffets.  However, it was lunchtime, the gf and I were hungry, we had a $100 resort credit to use, and the ARIA is an upscale casino-resort.  So we figured the Buffet at ARIA would be a safe bet.  Unlike most other casinos, the Buffet at ARIA is not located just off or even near the casino floor.  Instead, it's on the second floor\/Promenade level with several of the casino's fine dining restaurants.  The dining room is smaller than other buffets, yet open, well-lit by natural light coming in from floor to ceiling windows, airy, but with a weird, almost IKEA design aesthetic.  I could be very wrong about that last comment, but it was what came to mind when I entered the restaurant.  

The Buffet at ARIA offered culinary representation from many of the more popular international cuisines. The buffet's major draw seemed to be the Snow Crab legs as evidenced by the crowd of diners that were picking over the crab leg offerings like vultures over a rotting carcass.  Sadly, the crab legs were spindly, with little meat, and mealy for what little meat was present.  The selection of sushi rolls also failed to inspire much faith in the kitchen as the rice lacked moisture and the fillings were largely flavorless, relying on wasabi and soy sauce to provide the entire flavor profile.  Despite these and several other misses, all was not lost on the buffet.  The Indian chicken curry was actually one of the best tasting chicken curries that I've ever had.  It seemed to possess with all of the hoped for Indian spice and didn't taste "dumbed down" for Western palates.  The Chili Verde was a successful offering as the chunks of pork were nicely tender and bathing in a flavorful roasted green chili and tomatillo stew.  The lunch buffet with tax for two was $53.  Unfortunately, the food wasn't quite up to the price tag.  Fortunately, even though the food was largely lackluster, service was spot on.  Our water glasses were filled with frequency and dirty plates never lingered on our table for more than a minute or two.  

In the end, I only give the Buffet at ARIA 2 stars for food and value received, but added 1 star for the solid service.  Next time, I'll just stick to the Bellagio buffet or skip buffets altogether.
OMG best buffet ever! Food is super fresh! Great selection of food! Not your normal Vegas buffet!

Kind of a disappointment after reading the reviews on yelp. $32 for brunch on Saturday afternoon (I ordered it without the champagne). The food didn't look appetizing. I did go back for seconds for the roast beef and parfait. Save your moolah and try another buffet.

My boyfriend took me here because I absolutely love crab, and the only way you get to eat as much as I can is to go to a buffet. He chose the Aria. I was so excited to go, it was really beautiful and the lady who rung us out was the sweetest can't recall her name though... I get in food looks great although not as much seafood as I remembered... I make a plate my waiter was this warm hearted beautiful Ethiopian woman I can remember her name but she was very kind. In the middle of my dinner I end up getting a call its a family emergency I haven't even taken a bite yet. It's not cheap either... So me and my BF get up to leave I ask to speak to a manager they tell me he's on his way. I am greeted by such a warm face the manager Glenn I let him know my situation and he takes care of me without question with a personal note sign sealed delivered by himself for me to be able to come and enjoy the buffet another day. If I ever come to another buffet I will go to the aria the staff is unbelievably warm personable and kind,! Your dinner will be more than memorable,!

So disappointed by the average reviews on here!  I went to the Caesars Buffet in 2013 and I felt like the Aria beat Caesars hands down ten times over!  All of the food was SO good!!  They had so many great stations -- Asian, Indian, Seafood, Mediterranean, Meat Carving, Desserts, etc.  The meat station was amazing -- I was so impressed that the prime rib had a perfect medium rare on it, the leg of lamb was nice and tender with a great mint flavor, the dim sums were steamed perfectly, the snow crab and king crab was delicious, and even the sushi was amazing!  And the desserts -- omg the desserts were so amazing.  They even have gelato that they were hand scooping that was AMAZING.  And they have $12.99 all you can drink (beers, wines, champagnes, etc.)!  Cannot wait to come back here again for SURE!

If I could leave two different sets of stars I would. In terms of a buffet there are great options, excellent food quality and even better service from the very attentive staff. However, because this is Las Vegas I felt it should be a little better. Perhaps offering options that aren't available at every other buffet on the strip. It cost $80 for two of us to dine at night. We arrived at 8:45 and I know they closed at 10, but one of the employees said food would be out until 10:30. What she meant was the food already cooked would be out, but as the night went on dished offered on my first time around were gone. By the time I hit the dessert station at 9:40 there were only 4 varieties of Gelato left and very few options for the 1-2 bite desserts. People were walking in at 9:30 and I felt bad for them. I don't think there will be a next time for us here at the Aria Buffet, but if there was I would definitely come earlier. Our number 1 buffet of choice on the strip is the Wynn and 2 Belagio, for your taste reference.
I usually don't do buffets but it was right across the street from my hotel (Vdara) and I was hungry. Lots of heavy, oily, salty foods. I would not go back.

Went for lunch. About $25 per person. They had everything. However, only thing i liked was the roasted pork, Portuguese sausage, and their gelato. The Asian section was so gross...everything was stuck together in their little steamers. Their chicken dumplings look like they've been there for so long they turned black. Their Shao Mai have been steamed too long or re-steamed too many times so the skin is falling apart.  Not worth $25. Overall, everything was probably reheated from their leftovers from the night before. Not going back.

The line was super long and not worth the wait.  The interior was promising, but the food was almost decent.  About the only thing I liked was that the food stations were more spread out compared to other buffet set ups.  The food was uninspired and inconsistent with the hotel itself.

Other important info: spread out food stations, uninspired offerings, long waits, TVs available while waiting in line.

I just drove home from Vegas and wanted to give my review of Aria's buffet. We used a 2 for 1 comp here, so this made the whole experience a bit easier all around. Knowing we did not spend $35 each helped us not feel cheated. We did purchase the $12.99 all you can drink sangria, wine, and beer. I stayed with the weak Sangria as I did not want to get drunk, I wanted to enjoy the food. 

I should have opted for drunk as the food was not good . There were stews (Chinese), stews (Indian) and more stews (fish, shellfish); boring, ugly and lazy for a buffet. Why have a tandoor if you are not going to cook nan to order? The nan was cold, and crisp and no one was there, at any time, to cook some up fresh. (And it appeared and tasted like the tandoori chicken was NOT cooked in the tandoor...perhaps baked?!) Sushi was stale and sloppy looking. Clams gritty. Cold prawn pasty and muddy tasting. Crab...well it was so small it was not worth the effort. Most certainly the cheapest they could find. Prime rib: flavorless (but at least there was both cream and grated horseradish). Sure there were lots of roasted meats offered on the carving stations so for some, this is a big plus, I am sure. 

Other than the flirty gentleman serving ice cream everyone there seemed angry and short. No one smiled, no one was pleasant. Our waitress scored a big tip because she at least kept the sangria coming, but even she seemed ready to go home (we got there at 8:15pm for a buffet that closes at 10pm). We tried to leave with a glass of sangria, and the woman at the front almost jumped down our throats and told us we needed to drink it there. ( I have half a mind to say "Fine, but you know what, we were told at 9:50 it was the last we could get as the bar was closing yet the "rules" of the unlimited says two hours. So I will sit here, and BTW, I have another 25 minutes I could be drinking." Mind you. we were being rushed out of the place because they were closing. yet this abrupt woman was telling us to sit and drink it. I felt sorry for those customers who were rushing to get food and did not seem happy about the closing of the buffet before being able to enjoy it. If you want everyone out at 10...then don't close at 10!!!) 

Back to the sangria. We pounded it and then promptly went back to our hotel which was NOT the Aria. If I cannot take a glass of sangria I paid for,(and was being rush, in my seat, to finish before 10pm) to the casino floor to gamble, then I leave.  Bad move Aria, you lost my evening gambling money. 

Can I say anything good about this buffet? Nope!

Aria's buffet used to be my #1 buffet on the Strip and I've been to all the major ones minus Bachannal. However, they have been gradually going downhill for the past two years to the point that I wouldn't ever pay to eat here. I would only eat here when I could use myVegas rewards. If I had to pay for a buffet, I'd much rather go to Bellagio's buffet which has now become my #1 choice.

What a disappointment. 

When I booked our room at the Aria, I let the saleslady talk me into upgrading the room with a free breakfast buffet for the length of our stay. After all, it's the Aria -- a brand new hotel with top-notch ratings for service and quality. Plus, The Buffet at Aria is #5 on the Top 10 Vegas Buffet ratings at LasVegasDirect.com. So I came here with high hopes. 

It started bad right away. They have 2 cashier's stations for this place, and one of them is often clogged with "VIPs" with line-passes, so the line gets long and goes slow. Once you pay, you're held up until they get several tables to seat, and the maitre'd dispatches you with a hostess to drop you at your various tables like a UPS driver on a tight schedule. 

The buffet itself is constructed with a wall limiting access to it to a handful of entry\/exit points, and also serves to constrict traffic so that you are constantly in the way of or impeded by someone else. The overall sensation is of a herd of cattle being shunted down a chute to the feeding pens or holding floor. 

The bakery section is partitioned by glass that goes all the way to the ceiling, so when you try to talk to the buffet worker about what sort of bread or bagel you'd like toasted, it's like talking to a prisoner in "Midnight Express." You can barely hear each other though the glass, and leads to fun miscommunications (e.g.: "May I have an onion bagel please?" "You want an Everything bagel?" "Uh, no, ONION please!" "Ok, white toast, coming up!" "Okay, fine, give it to me.") 

For those lucky enough to get seated near the windows, as another Yelper wrote, you will get sunlight and verdant views of the pool. The rest of you will get exiled to the low-roofed oppressive dungeon, with test-tube lights dangling from the ceiling like Superman's Fortress of Solitude. 

The food was uninspired but serviceable. The waitress, when she showed up, was friendly and efficient. 

The overall vibe, however, was one of "we're really busy, so hurry up and get out of our buffet." We were more than happy to comply. Skipping the "free" breakfast today -- here's hoping Wicked Spoon next door is better.

Came to this buffet on a recent trip for brunch and it was very good. Excellent quality and I was so excited to see bagels and lox! I'm sad I didn't get to eat the crab legs, but I'm not one who can eat more than a little seafood before 10am. 
The wait staff was great, I was sick and had no voice and she brought me lemon and honey and hot water and kept it filled. 
Dessert selection left something to be desired, but otherwise I was very happy.

I'm not a huge fan of buffets in general, but this buffet is definitely nothing to write home about. I should have realized that there was a reason why this buffet is significantly cheaper than all of the other buffets on the strip. 

The only okay thing about this place was the crab legs, but you really have to dig for the good stuff. Other than the crab legs, there was nothing too appealing about the food. 

Service was good though. Our waitress was always ready to refill our drinks when they started to get low, which is something that usually doesn't happen at buffets.

Anyways, if I were you, I'd walk the extra half a mile over to the Wicked Spoon buffet.

The Buffet at the ARIA is not too shabby. I admit, compared to the numerous buffets in Las Vegas, the Buffet doesn't stand out, however, there are a definitely things that one will love about this buffet.

Now this review was during Saturday Brunch on Valentine's Day\/President's Day weekend. The regular brunch price is $29.99 per person but they decided to increase the price to $35.99 due to the holiday weekend. This was sneaky on their part to raise prices just for the weekend, but I realized $5 wasn't a big deal in Vegas (especially when you have a $50 room credit). It's also convenient for those staying at the ARIA. The line was nonexistent at 9:30a but grew after we left. Still, the line was not ridiculously long.

The Buffet is modern as you would expect walking into the ARIA. There are windows all around so it's quite bright. The décor & furniture also help make the entire restaurant bright. The waiter service was just okay. My orange juice order was forgotten but plates were removed at a reasonable amount of time. I do love that they give you a large pitcher of coffee instead of having to flag the waiter down for a refill.

Overall, they have a good selection of foods. You can find Chinese, Indian, Korean, American, Mexican, Italian, French, and even Filipino food here. Their Asian foods were probably my favorite as they had Filipino longanisa (sausage) and their kimchi fried rice was delicious! They also have a legit tandoori oven to bake the naan. I really appreciate the gluten free options but I did find those dishes to be a bit bland. Most will appreciate that their snow crab legs are already cut in half. Although this saves the mess and time, I definitely feel more satisfied cracking open a crab leg myself. I also think that this dries out the crab meat. Speaking of dry, I found that a lot of their dishes were a bit dry possibly due to overcooking. Their desserts are quite good. I especially loved their revolving gelato machine. Other desserts one should try are their pecan pie and flan.

The Buffet at the ARIA met my expectation and was decent enough with the room credit. I do wish that some of their dishes were more flavorful and less dry. I don't see myself going out of my way to eat at this particular buffet though.
The buffet here is not the best on the Strip.  Food is bland and not much selections.  Very boring.  Go to Paris, TI and Mirage for their awesome buffets.

The hubby & I stayed @ Aria in late September.  We hit up the buffet for breakfast, price wasn't too bad (you're in Vegas, everything is pricey anyway).  I don't know what they put in their French Toast but we were hooked after one bite, it was THAT good.  They had a great selection of food but all I remember was the french toast. Customer service was prompt and friendly.

This place is amazing!!! They have warm crab which is my absolute favorite they also have more a variety to choose from compared to Wicked Spoon. The pricing for the Buffet was good, the only thing was that because it's so busy the service was quite slow. It took us a couple of half an hours to get refills on out unlimited drinks, so at the end we decided to get up and get our own drinks from the bar. Overall it's a good place to stuff your face at!

The best thing about this buffet, in my opinion, is the dessert bar: tons of selections and most pastries\/cakes come straight from Jean Philippe Patisserie! I came hungry, after reading reviews and the restaurant guide from Aria, I knew I had to save room for dessert. You won't be disappointed eating here if you've got a sweet tooth!

The entrees\/selections were OK - price was $38.99 per person on a Saturday night, which comes with unlimited wine & a lobster for two, plus endless supply of food from the buffet.

Some notable items on the buffet were the sushi bar, tandoori chicken, freshly baked naan, grilled salmon, and king crab legs. We made our own dipping sauce using butter, pepper, salt, and lemons.

It was delicious and a great experience here.

I am not a buffet fan since I do not eat a lot. I happened to book our stay at the Aria during a promotion for 2 free** buffets per day. I went for brunch one day and breakfast another. It was pretty good. You get what you pay for and IMO this buffet has some quality food. Fresh ice cream. great Indian food, yummy omelets, fresh fruit and more. I would recommend this buffet for meat eaters since there was a variety of choices to choose from. For a vegetarian? Only if you have a resort credit and vegans, forget about it.

The service was great. One of the best I've experienced at a buffet.  The waiters were nice and quick with drink orders and table clean up.

After trying so many buffets in Vegas, I wanted to give the Aria buffet a try ! We went there at 3 PM they were serving dinner. 
It wasn't crowded because its was so early for dinner. The place look clean and organized , there is different stations and choices ( Italian, Mexican, Asian, Mediterranean ...) 
I tried different choices but unfortunately didn't like anything !! Food and presentation look so good but there is no taste at all. I am sorry to say that but its like frozen food reheated !! 
The only thing that my friends liked was: lobster ravioli and paella. 
After the food wanted to give the desserts a try ! I am known for my sweet addiction I didn't even eat half a cake because it has no taste ! My friend tried the ice cream and found it so sweet and didn't like it! 
I am writing this review so that the management team of the buffet can read it and improve the food quality. 
For the same price you can have way better food at others buffet.
Waitress excellent,  food area clea, lots of choices, fresh made. Breakfast choices were well thought out. However way to costly for enjoyment $$$$$$

This is the best tasting buffet in Vegas so far. Crab to order, fresh and great flavor. A nice assortment of choices and everything was delish.  
The staff is courteous and efficient. Love it, can't wait to go back

My husband and I ate here. what a disappointment. False advertising people!! The food was cold and not good! The salmon tasted funny the Mac and cheese was a step above a cafeteria and the sushi was dry and chewy. Way overpriced what a disappointing experience. If you want an amazing buffet go to the bellagio.

We ate at the Aria buffet since we were staying in the hotel (the other buffet we were going to try had a ridiculously long line).  There was no line at Aria.  

The price over thanksgiving weekend was inflated (I do not recommend dining at a buffet over holiday weekends as the prices of most buffets are over-inflated and definitely not worth the price increase)

The food is comparably "fresher" than other buffets but the selection is very limited. 


The buffet boasts the only tandoor oven at a Vegas buffet. I found the naan to have a biscuit like quality which is not to my liking. The tandoori chicken however was very juicy and succulent. Taste somewhat lacking though. 

The other standout was the crab legs (fortunately served hot - I hate cold crab legs).  
Seafood - slightly above par in all respects
The pasta and salad selection was surprisingly decent.  
Carvery - standard selection - preparation slightly below par
Dessert selection - below par in all aspects. 
Asian food - below par in all aspects. 

You should go to this buffet if you hate waiting in lines and if they are charging their standard price.

Since this is new to me, I decide to try it for dinner.  I got here around 6 PM on Saturday night and there was a short line.  The price is similar to some others at $40 per person.  The dining area is huge but the food stations are not as big as I expected for a buffet place.

The Food - there are some hits and misses here.  

Hit - Prime Rib, King Crab legs, salmon shooter, manhattan soup, and civeche.

Miss- the whole Asian station.  I pretty much tried everything and not like a single one.

So, I have tried various buffets and this rank right above MGM.  By far, Bellagio is the best for me follows by Wynn.

I'm not a fan of buffets in general.  I just can't eat my money's worth.   I found the buffet to be pretty good value for the money you spend.  Seems like the strategy is to focus on quality than large selections (plus for me).   I spent my time eating crab legs, oysters, shrimp (ie. the expensive stuff).  Some of my friends got the meat (they said the prime rib was salty but other meats were good) and I tried the cake desserts and I thought they were horrible.    All in all, for the $40 range for dinner, I think it's top 3.

The food was excellent but the chubby male cashier at the front was rude as hell. He had a bad attitude all because we asked if our group could be split up. He slapped my receipt down and talked as if he was angry. Sucks that I'm a Mlife member and he'd act like that. Otherwise, everyone else there is awesome.

I don't understand how the average rating is 3 stars!!! No way!! This is my 2nd time in Vegas and their buffet is, by far, my favorite in the city!! Great variety and different types of cuisines! Highly recommended!

This buffet is great!! Used the myVegas offer for buy one get one for lunch and also bottomless beverage pass! You save a lot! Their crab legs are amazing! Their rum punch was great too! Definitely get the beverage pass if you're a big drinker! It's about 13 bucks, I could only finish 1 and a half of a drink! 

The only thing I was confused was our waitress, she didnt show up to our table til 15 minutes later, and the busser was the one cleaning our plates the whole time and actually giving us great service. Then our waitress went MIA and 30 minutes later told her manager "Sorry I was gone for 20 minutes" (we were sitting near the door where you see the waiters and bussers come out bringing out drinks), yeah she was bad, but our busser was so kind and polite. I wish I knew her name!

Well worth it if you play myVegas!!

Me and my girlfriend decided to try out the buffet on a thursday evening. We got free complimentary dinner buffet through my vegas.  The original cost would have been 34.00\/person. When we got there, there was no line and inside the restaurant, it was half empty.  When I went to get some food, it felt like the food was just sitting there for hours, the snow crab legs were decent, but not great and it was not huge.  I thought this buffet would have been great since it is inside of a new hotel. The only thing that was good was the gelato.  I sure would not pay that much for the buffet here.

Don't waste your time in this place.  I was lucky the check was picked up by my employer.  The food is nothing special that can't be found elsewhere in Vegas at 1\/3 the cost.  The kielbasa was good but the beef was way over cooked and  just didn't seem to be fresh.  The Italian selection seemed to be microwaved from the box.  The Tandori section just looked plain gruesome.  Go find the closest McDonalds before you waste your money in this place

We read all the reviews online and had our doubts regarding the Buffet at Aria.  We were more than pleasantly surprised.  Very interesting and delicious items, including delicious jumbo shrimp in lobster sauce, all you can drink wine and many unique specialities.  However, the complimentary lobster was tasteless and rubbery.  The desserts were less than luscious.  But, overall a very solid buffet.  Definitely would return!

Good selection of food. Service was okay. The server hardly came by to pick up our dirty plates. The food was average. I tried most of the dishes they offered and didn't like any of them. Bacchanal is a much better choice.

What a big let down.
I've read online how aria has one of the best buffets in vegas.  Sadly after attending I learned that is not the case. 

The wait to eat on new years eve was not terrible. Maybe 30-45 min.
We went around brunch time and the service was better than many people gave them credit for.

The food selection seemed very limited compared to the wynn and bellagio.  But that wasn't even what I was most disappointed with,  the food quality lacked majorly in flavor.  I think the only meat worth eating there was their kilbasa sausage. Pork was over cooked and skin was hard to even cut with their huge bulky dull knife, tri tip was very over done, and their chorizo sausage had no spice.

They had an Italian section which I expected to have all sorts of pastas, instead there was maybe 4 kinds of pizza and spaghetti.  

I do not believe I will be coming back.

I have to agree with Deepika below, this is probably one of the worst buffet at $33 dinner price.  This is our first try at Aria so we don't know what to expect.  We had to wait in line for 75 minutes and the restaurant was only 3\/4 full with some sections closed off at 3:30 pm.  I noticed that our waitress had to cover 2 big sections and she's not even fit physically (250 lbs +).  I'm nothing against overweight waitresses but she moved really slow and didn't even notice that our glasses were empty for half an hour or so.  Moving on to the food, the only thing worth eating is their brisket and rack of lamb.  Their prime rib is too dry and the king crab is nothing special.  I don't care about the Indian and Mexican food because they're so cheap to eat elsewhere.  This is probably the worst $33 we've spent on any buffet.  If you're thinking about trying this buffet, please don't waste your money.  Just go to Wynn buffet for LUNCH and you'll be glad you listen to me.  Finally, we went to Wynn for lunch the next day and their lunch was way bigger than Aria dinner buffet at only $25.   Wynn had more cheeses than just 3 cheap selection of cheeses at Aria.  Wynn had parmegiano reggiano cheeses (expensive), more gourmet salad selections, more italian station, better sushi and way better dessert and gelato.  Even our kids didn't like Aria gelatos.  Their selection is poor and taste awkward.  If you go to Wynn, don't forget to try their bread pudding with anglaise sauce next to it...it's the best I've ever had.  Their gelato taste like real gelato and not some cheap ice cream.  I'm glad we came back to Wynn and after so many years trying Wynn, it never disappoint us.  I will never come back to Aria, for less money I'd rather eat at Paris Buffet who has better prime rib.

Honestly, if it weren't for the free dinner buffet comps, I would never eat here.  In fact, if I paid, I'd probably ask for my money back only because their food is just so old, dry and nasty.  I mean, you would think that ARIA of all places would have a nice buffet, but they don't.

- Indian curries - all watery and spices, naan - old and stale
- seafood - old and nasty crab legs
- latin - super salty
- salad bar - pathetic 
- italian - dried up spaghetti noodles, super greasy pizza
- desserts - not appetizing. old cookies.

only memorable item was their gelato, dinner roll, and the pepperoni on the pizza. 

Again, it was free and I wanted to try it once. I'm not sure what's worse... The Buffet at ARIA or the Mirage Buffet.... they both suck. 

I'd highly recommend Bayside Buffet (at Mandalay) over this garbage.  If money is not a problem, go to Bacchanal Buffet (at Caesar's) because it's worth every dollar!

Underwhelming for a lovely hotel like Aria. We did a Sunday brunch\/lunch on a Valentines holiday weekend. It's $40\/person, which makes it one of the pricier of the lot for Vegas buffets. They have standard fare of multi cuisines. Nothing was interesting or tasty enough to go back for a second. They had lobster and crab, so I can't comment on how that tasted since I don't eat that! Their desserts were plain, not necessarily special or tasty or unique. Would not come back! Too many better choices in Vegas!

I've eaten at this buffet a few times and have thoroughly enjoyed myself every time!! I especially loved the Asian food, carving station and dessert bar.... OOHHH!! And the unlimited Thai iced tea!! Yum!! The staff is always friendly and quick to serve drinks and switch out plates. Would totally recommend!

I'm pretty confident that the Aria buffet has solidified my idea that big name Vegas buffets totally aren't worth it.

A friend of a friend suggested that, "Duuude. the Aria brunch buffet is sick brah, for real." So we wrangled up all 11 of the troops and dragged our butts across the street, in the rain and cold, up and down those annoying Vegas hanging walkways...only to pay $30 for a barebones sad-ass buffet.

Ok, heads up here. These people charge an automatic 18% gratuity on parties larger than 9. Don't get hosed like we did and split your group in half. All they're going to do is push together two tables of 5! Why are we tipping them anyhow when we're doing all the footwork of bringing the food to the table? Be careful, they'll also try to con you into buying the champagne brunch...they don't tell you that the alcohol is an extra $7 charge.

Food was kind of on par with Mc. Donald's. Textures were off, proteins were crazy dry. Hash browns suck...and were chewy. And don't you dare touch that sushi! Day old sushi does not a buffet make! The only thing i thoroughly enjoyed was the lovely fluffy waffles and maple syrup. 

Okay, let's be serious here, Aria: you can't slap the label "GELATO" on tubs of generic ice cream. Don't you dare put nuts in apple pie, either! BLASPHEMY!

I feel cheated. I feel like this should get zero stars...but it should get a Bonus star for having a gorgeous hotel to walk through to compensate for a less-than-stellar experience.

Second Only to the Wynn and I Ate at ALL of the Main Buffets During My Stay

Ok I slept mainly at the Aria hotel but this does not affect my review of their Buffet. I five starred the hotel also as it deserves it!  The Buffet was dynamite, food was hot and selection endless, as well as quality of Aria Buffet food very high. Behind the steam tables MANY smiling faces! And quality protien foods meaning not 1001 ways to serve useless carbs as Bellagio seemed to do.  the chef was funny and enocuraged me to take some scones in my purse!  He said "everyone else does!"  ENJOY!  I am a high stakes player so next time I will bring a bigger purse!!!

Compared to all the other buffets, except the Wynn and Mirage-this was the brightest, easiest to attend and "happy" buffet in Vegas. Food was also HOT when it is supposed to be hot (Bellagio was cold and useless with the added insult of very pricey!) The selection at the Aria was also wonderful and recipes from every type of country featured you could think of.

I see some reviews rail the "staff." This is somewhat true but I did not focus on the staff--mainly the food, quality, variety and thoughtfulness put into their buffet. It is five star. I do agree their staff could all smile more...but their jobs probably very hard. I do agree Mirage Buffet was also dynamite AND EVERY person I walked into THANKED us for our business and let us know we were truly appreciated! And they were sincerely smiling. That stunned me.

If Aria could just get their staff to "fake it" or maybe pay them a LITTLE more to SMILE--it would be six star. Also keep in mind what just happened down the street. Many people were impacted by that. More so the locals that serve us and this may be heavy on their mind.

no one really expect prime dining when going to a buffet. and this one is certainly not. Still wonder why we made is there? Probably the fixed price $37 per person (not cheap but affordable in vegas) as we got burned by an mediocre restaurant the night before @ $120+ per person. 
It is basically a combination of savorless cafeteria food, calorie galore dish that satisfy no other intent than stuffing yourself as much as you can to make your $ worth it.
But no it's not good. Service is below acceptable. And atmosphere is a mix of a jail cafeteria (of what In think a jail cafeteria is), a economy waiting lounge in a train station,  or a feeding troff for people with scooters

Mlife comp.  Awesome buffet, fresh, hot, delicious all in one.  Line to enter the buffet moved fast with Mlife membership card, the restaurant staff was very nice from the cashier to the table bussers, and the chefs.

The Aria Buffet is excellent for those that want the taste of a fine restaurant but also want the ease and assortment that you will find in a buffet. Their stations are manned with an exceptional number of employees and are always in stock with their items. This is your chance to pair foods from their tastes. For example I had the Spanish rice with cilantro with my salmon from the seafood section. They also had 3 different types of crab legs! I don't usually eat pie but when I saw their apple pie next to their assortment of ice cream flavors, I just had to have dessert. 

The only thing is it was a little in the pricey end as it came out to $80 for two but you're at the Aria what did you expect?

The snow crabs were very small and the stone crabs were frozen. This was an average buffet at best. Long line with mediocre service. The only thing that was really good was the corn and I'm NOT a picky eater.
We opted for the $35 buffet plus unlimited mimosas\/bloody mary's. This place is ran poorly but the deal is unbeatable.  $35 buffet plus bottomless mimosas and bloody mary's.

Surprisingly decent buffet. With so many choices on the Strip I was hesitant to dine here based on the reviews\/rating, but ended up here due to a promotion I received. We waited about 30 minutes on a weekday for the lunch service. The stations are all clearly labeled and there's lots of walking room. Our server was very attentive and nice. Make sure you try the prime rib.

I wasn't sure a five-star buffet was even possible, but Aria's Buffet changed my mind on that. I'm normally way too cheap to pay $38 for a dinner buffet, but my friend offered to pay 1\/2 my bill, and buy us a bottle of wine on his work tab. How could I refuse?

You know what? I *would* have paid $38, and I would have been happy about it. The ambiance in the room is excellent - light and bright, but not aggressively so. My friend and I spent a good 2 hours there and could have easily spent more.

Service was top-notch and a bottle of bubbly cost us about $35 - not a bad deal in Vegas. And the food? Oh, the food. Everything I tasted was delicious, and the desserts were divine, and perfectly portion-sized. I'll be back. Oh yes, Buffet at Aria - I'll be back.
Very pricey, but very good.  I suggest having a welcoming stomach, your hangover may prevent you from enjoying it to the extent that it costs.

Maybe it is not the best buffet in Las Vegas, but it is my favorite buffet in there. After I tried all the famous buffets in Las Vegas, Aria is fittest buffet to me. It have reasonable price, sufficient seafood and attractive desert. The most important benefit is that you don't need to wait too long time to the line compare with the other buffets. Highly recommend.

The buffet is better than the standard fare. There are a wide variety of foods from around the globe. My favorites? The easy to eat crab legs, clam chowder, naan bread, panacotta, and OMG the cake pops. The cake pops are filled with chocolate whipped cream. Overall, I was satisfied but wished there would be a bigger selection of foods. I use my "one round" rule when judging buffets. If I can fit all the foods I want to eat in my first round for food, there is not enough of a selection.

I tried a variety of dishes from the different stations, none of which were well-prepared. The Pork Bun was dried and leathery; the meats were over-salted; the "Asian" dishes were bland; the lamb stew had more bones than meat. The desserts were the only highlight. Certainly not worth the $50 price tag (which doesn't include a cocktail).

HORRIBLE HOSTESS'  and MANAGEMENT!!!!!

I visited the Aria buffet this monday (march 21st) and I was so excited because I love the hotel and had the best service all 3 days that I stayed there! I had never been to a buffet in Las Vegas but made sure to make a point to visit one this time around. I really wish I would've gone to the buffet at the Wynn beause the reviews for it are stellar!

My girlfriends and I arrived at the buffet around 130pm for lunch the price was great about $23 and the cashier was friendly. There were maybe four people ahead of us so there was no wait and there were tons of open tables. After paying they had us wait there at the register for the Hotess to come and take us to our table. After about 10-15minutes of waiting there were about 10-15 people lined up behind us all paid and waiting on the Hostess. By this time we are asking the cashier 'what's the hold up?" and "why is it taking so long to be seated?" The sweet lady (shikieko) who took our proof of payment was getting flustered because we weren't the only customers questioning the wait. Another man in line offered to go and find the Host for her because she expressed that she couldn't leave her post. After a few minutes more of complaining from all the customers waiting Shikieko ran off to find the Host who were no where in site. They came strolling out in a pair (one was named Kirly, she was especially RUDE) without any sense of urgency and still chatting to one another as they approached us. At this point a friend of mine was was pissed and requested to speak to the manager. The manager took a minute to come out as well so when she came we were all already at the buffet rushing to get food because we were on our way to the airport. Once we got to our table the manager (Brittany) was standing there. She started by saying "Did you all want to speak with a manager?" We replied "yes we did we are not satisfied with the service we recieved at the front counter! The Host are not friendly and have no sense of customer service or urgency we have been waiting for nearly 15 minutes to be seated and there are several tables available" Before I could finish she replied "oh well they came as soon as they could they were busy clearing tables, but ill talk to them". Before I blurted out BITCH what fuck is your problem you owe us a damn apology!!!!! My gf stepped in and said "Tthey were no where in site and a 15 minute wait is just unacceptable when there are several free tables. It's not busy in here and they could have thanked us for waiting, apologized or something!" Brittany replied "oh ok well ya I will talk to them." We also brought in a cake with us. We had no intentions of cutting the cake there our plan was to grab a cocktail at a lounge in the Aria and cut the cake there. Brittany made sure as she walked away from the table to say "oh by the way you all can't cut that cake in here!" We were extremely pissed at this point.

So we conitued to eat, but the food was nothing spectactular. They had a a few dishes from several different cuisines (Italian, Mexican, Japanese, American, seafood, roast beef, and a pasta bar) Im a vegetarian so I wasn't impressed. I had a a few avacado rolls, vegetable rolls, mixed green salad, corn on the cob, french toast and tofu salad. Believe it or not the best thing was the damn french toast everything else I tried was so mediocre. So after we ate we decided to cut our cake and offer our sweet server Shikieko some she decilened; but wecontinued to nibble and left the rest there in hopes the manger would see!!!!

DON'T GO HERE THE MANAGER IS BEYOND RUDE SO WHAT CAN EXPECT FROM HER RAGEDY ASS EMPLOYEES!!!!!!

Really sad my stay at the Aria ended this way!

Ate here for breakfast. Great service, selection, & very good quality of food. Even at breakfast, you can choose from items such as Pad Thai, steamed dumplings, Brazilian, taco bar, pizza, curry, soups, crab claws, mussels, carving stations of turkey, prime rib, sweets, gelato wheel, individual baskets of chicken & waffles, huge salad\/fruit bar, sushi, plus every breakfast item you can think of. 

Buffets usually lack on quality, but this was some of the best curry & dumplings I've had. Shrimp pad Thai was SPICY. Love the Aria.

I'm really picky about food, but when it comes to Vegas buffets, I make my monies worth it by eating KING CRAB LEGS all the time. So when my sister kept raving about this place and how good it was, I decided to give this buffet a try. Thankfully, there was NO line. The cool part was that for every two people, we get to share a maine lobster. The lobster was GOOD! However, the KING CRAB LEGS, were NOT. It was sooooo salty!! I even dipped it in butter to take away the saltiness, but I gave up after ONE plate. C'mon...I usually plates and plates of this! 

Not only was the king crab legs salty, their weren't many choices for other types of food. I love all types of mash potatoes, and you can't really go wrong with that. However, their mash potatoes were still uncooked and also LOOKED uncooked. UGH. The only good thing about this place were their desserts. 

For close to $40 including tip, I would NOT return here.

I've eaten at Wynn's buffet and the Bellagio, both were my favorites, however my husband and I thought of trying something different and here we are at Aria. For the same price as the Bellagio buffet, this place is very subpar. Yes, there's a fair variety of seafood, which is probably the only good thing about this place. However, the food here lacks quality. The soup tasted bland, fish tasted funky and the cuisine selections are very limited. The prime rib and lamb chop here is so overdone (old), it looks so brown on the inside. The turkey cut was also dry. Foods are portioned on small bowls like it is being rationed. I definitely would rather spend the $45 at Bellagio or Wynn for much better taste, QUALITY, service and selection. 

Definitely a thumbs down for Aria's buffet. Won't be coming back and will not be recommending this buffet.

Not impressed.  I guess after we ate at the Bacchanal Buffett (Caesars's Palace) the bar had been set fairly high and we expected so much more from Aria.   The food was mediocre at best. The atmosphere boring and uninteresting.  The experience as whole was not worth $50. Sushi was pretty much the only appetizing dish here. Won't visit again.

Immediately after leaving, I went back up to the room because I had the urge to throw up, which I did. And NO I don't have an eating disorder.

Friend who walked in on me as I was voiding my stomach contents into the guest room toilet: "Ew."

Not a doctor, so I can't say if it was because I had a spoiled sushi roll, or if some piece of prime rib I ate had gone bad...or if in true Vegas fashion, I just really did overeat and my stomach just could not hang.

To be fair, it wasn't garbage whatsoever.  Descent upscale buffet with better than average ingredients.  The selection didn't seem as varied or plenty as Bellagio's or The Mirage's buffet though.

The dining area is well decorated...nice and contemporary --- in line with the rest of the Resort's styling.  One really weird thing I have to mention! While eating at a banquette seat, you WILL feel a rattling vibration as you dine which I'm guessing comes from the CityCenter tram.  Terrible design flaw.  We could actually see the surface of the wine in our glasses shiver like the way in the first Jurassic Park film when the terrified kids helplessly watched the water in the plastic cup moving when the T-Rex was stomping towards them.

Other notes: Aria comp'd half our bill (thanks Players Club) and we went when they were serving unlimited red wine and lobster tail (only available Friday & Saturday for Dinner).  Best thing there aside from the lobster tail is the lobster stuffed ravioli. Mmmm.

Had holiday brunch here. Wait was an hour. Food totally not worth the wait for the price. The $38.99 holiday brunch is worse than the holiday brunch at MGM at $29.99 or even the regular lunch at MGM.

--- Regular Hours & Pricing

Breakfast: $21.99*
Monday - Friday
7:00 AM - 11:00 AM 

Lunch: $25.99*
Monday - Friday
11:00 AM - 3:00 PM

Brunch: $31.99*
Saturday & Sunday
7:00 AM - 3:00 PM 

Dinner: $36.99*
Monday - Thursday
3:00 PM - 10:00 PM

Gourmet Dinner: $41.99*
Friday - Sunday
3:00 PM - 10:00 PM

--- 

Holiday Brunch $38.99 (kids 5+ $21.99)
7:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m.

Holiday Dinner $47.99 (kids 5+ $25.99)
3:00 p.m. - 10:00 p.m.

However, holiday is defined as 12\/13-1\/?, so you are pretty much stuck in the higher prices.

3 or younger eat free.
- Regular and holiday pricing: 
https:\/\/www.aria.com\/en\/restaurants\/the-buffet.html

We went here bc it was so highly rated on TripAdvisor.  Should've listened to you, YELP. 

So many buffets to choose from, and at a comparable price ($40) to Como's (Wicked Spoon) and Encore's -- this one pales in comparison. 

- The line to get in seems to always be really long, except at random hours that aren't usually when people eat
- We went after reading all about the crab, but this is where we were most disappointed (and entire Yelp Star off) for the crab (snow, king):  they served it cut in half (length wise) which means you're getting little shards of meat, not those heavenly huge chunks you can get when you crack it yourself. They also serve it cold (read: it's completely frozen) and steamed (limp, soggy, gross)
- Huge selection, so if your goal is to stuff your face you're all set and you'll be in heaven -- but if your goal is to taste really well-done versions of international foods-- then this is not your place 
- Sushi\/sashimi are terrible

This buffet is insane. We went for the crab legs, and oddly enough, I was less impressed with the crab legs over everything else.  There was a very wide variety, our server,  Flor was very attentive, and we all left full and satisfied.   There is an Asian station, Indian station, Italian, seafood, salad, meat station, and desserts amongst others.  The price was comparable to others in the area.  Brunch was the best value, and we added on the bottomless drinks option  (it was buy one get one).
Good value for money ($25.99+tax). Decent vegetarian (and Indian) choices. The food was delicious.

We were looking for somewhere to eat quite late in the evening during a week night. We ended up at the Aria and decided to the try to buffet. The service was very good, the price was unremarkable and the food was EXCELLENT. The array was outstanding, we loved how many ethnic varieties there were, and the desserts were MMMMMM! We enjoyed the personal attention we got from the service staff especially as my mom was feeling very sick and weak. They allowed my parents to sit with us and have free drinks even though they didn't pay for the buffet, and turned a blind eye when we forced my mom to eat a little shrimp and dessert. Overall, it was a very pleasant dining experience and the best buffet we've had in Vegas to date.

WOW! Let me just say I am impressed! I don't really eat at buffets much, but I feel compelled to give this one a lot of credit. Everything from the staff to the food was amazing from beginning to end. The staff was friendly and was always providing top notch service. We never had a dirty dish on our table and always had our beverages filled to the top. I also appreciated  how Chef Kreg asked how we were enjoying our meal. The little things like that help enhance your experience and make you feel valued.

The food was absolutely phenomenal! I almost wish I didn't get full so fast so I could try more. My favorite part was the endless amount of fresh seafood. They never ran low on anything and every item I picked seemed like it was in the ocean the day before. I also would like to rave about the lamb chops. I am picky with lamb, so it says a lot if they got my approval with that one. It was cooked to perfection along with their other meat choices. I had the prime rib as well and wish I had saved room for the cowboy steak. I didn't have it, but my friend said it was her favorite.

My favorite dessert was the pistachio gelato. I have this odd obsession with pistachios so I when I saw it in the gelato form, I had to indulge. It was the perfect way to end my perfect dinner.

The best way I could describe this experience is it truly is fine dining cuisine in a buffet setting. Kudos to Chef Kreg, our server Kelly, and the rest of the staff. Keep up the good work, guys! I'll be back soon!

Short:

Slow... slow... slow.... S...L...O...W.... Oh, and did I mention slow?  

Full:

We decided to try this buffet since so many people hyped it up to be something it really wasn't. But we stayed at Aria so we though might as well right? We came on a Saturday night and got the two maine lobsters (which weren't great and big at all, more like prawns) and unlimited wine. We paid around $37 per person and I don't feel like it was anything special. The waitress was nice, but very slow even though the place wasn't even packed. It was amazing how slow they were and it was pretty stupid since another waitress passing by could not serve us, she had to hunt down our waitress to refer our request to her. Even for just a simple refill. Talk about inefficient and slow! 

The food wasn't really unique or tasty, nothing really stood out. I would go to the Belagio buffet for better stuff and seafood. There were however a good selection of meats (prime rib, ny steak, lamb, etc). The thing that turned me off was the food manager who was throwing an absolute piss fit. Yea, sure the table was messy, but he was yelling at the chef right in front of the customers in line. Talk about total humiliation and making yourself look like a jerk. When you're pissed it shows and people tend to avoid pissed off people or think differently about them. 

End: 

Overall, I wasn't impress and I didn't get sick. I just felt like I didn't really get my money's worth. No more next time.

The buffet overall is very nice and the staff is incredibly friendly. There dessert station has fresh gelato and great cookies. I do wish that there was just a few more options and fresh fruit available but overall the quality of the food is great.

Five stars! From all the buffets I have eaten so far, this buffet by far is the best one! Lots selections of different type of food such as Chinese, Mexican, Indian, American foods. If you are someone that looks for strong flavored foods this buffet is must go!

not a lot of variety and range for the breakfast transitioning to lunch.
nothing wow'ed me or made me go for seconds..most of the food i only 
ate midway of it all.

i rather go to wicked spoon or to even excalibur's buffet.

vdara comped me 2buffet tickets for it so thats the only plus

Aria lunch Buffett was awesome, if u like seafood it's a must! Paid $28 each, kids 3 and under eat free. I at least ate 2 crabs, muscles, clams, grilled fish and fish tacos mmm. They also have bomb Asian good, flan, gelato selection and so much more.  Service was great & lots Of choices for kids too. I would def go back again!

I came here over Super Bowl 50 weekend eager to try it out because I just had the Bellagio Buffett the day prior. 

The dinner experience at The Buffett at Aria left me wanting more. It costs more $ to eat here than it does at the Bellagio, but the Aria offers a smaller collection of food and dessert. I enjoyed the King Crab legs and the Prime Rib here but the sushi, chinese and dessert sections were lackluster. I saw a whole aisle of Chinese dim sum steamers but was disappointed to find that they were all filled with buns and some yucky potstickers, no other dim sum. The sushi rice was also really dry too. There were not a lot of patrons eating at 3pm on Sunday, but the servers were very slow in taking away used plates and refilling drinks. 

 I like that the buffet space is very spacious and the interior looks beautiful. Unfortunately, I rather go back to the Buffet at Bellagio or Bacchanal Buffet because they offer much more in terms of selection at a comparable cost. 

REMEMBER to present your MLIFE card to get Tier Credits for your buffet purchase!

They have a really great buffet, especially given the price you pay. Lunch was delicious--would definitely go back and recommend to others. Desserts included gelato, which was really good! There's also good variety, not like some of the other Vegas buffets.

straight to the point.. omg this place sucked. 

* $33 per person Sunday brunch. i had hotel credit thank gawd.
* for real now how can u mess up on salmon sashimi?
* sushi selection was small.. tuna, eel, and other vegetable rolls
* the strawberry gelato was melting before they served it to me
* getting soda takes forever.. the lady took my Sprite and i didn't see it until a long time later
* crab legs are alright.. cut in halves.. nice that i don't have to work for it
* parfait was sour? why..

that's about all i had.. i was tired of wasting food and the disappointment.. so i stuck with crab legs until the end.

ps. the big boy handling the cut meat had gloves on.. the same gloves he used to grab a whole bunch of tip from the omlette bar thing.. he shoved the tip under the counter and resumed meat cutting. never changing his gloves. health code violation?

Best buffet ever. We had a horrible waitress that wouldn't acknowledge us so we asked a waitress in area beside us who was busting rear if we could sit in her section. From there on everything was awesome. 

We had a bogo from myVEGAS so half off we are already winning yay!!  Crab legs awesome huge claws. Pre cracked. Hot butter. Tons of seafood selections. Fresh pastas. Skipped salad because well, HELLO SEAFOOD AND BEEF duh. Oh did I mention dessert? Ya Um YUM. Skip bread. I can eat bread anytime. Go for the yum. Go for the " not everyday". For 30$ they had a pitcher of cosmos. She said it was about 4 servings. I was only one drinking but the regular drinks were close to 15$ so I went for it. I drank half and was a little. Or a lot. Toasted. I finally just stuck my straw in the pitcher and went to town. Great night!!!

At around $40 Dollars for Brunch, I was expecting a really great situation when it came to food quality. The Aria Buffet did not let me down. They had many different stations that included LATIN, and ASIAN and and AMERICAN.. haha.. and some Mediterranean style dishes and salads too. There was a fantastic salad station which had a Waldorf Sald when I visited .. I like Waldorf Salad.. and a really nice dessert bar that included a rotating Gelato bar. 

In addition, since it was Brunch,. they had chicken and waffles, biscuits and gravy, pancakes to order..hashed potatoes and eggs.  I'm a sucker for Breakfast. I Brake for good brunch. I could have my chicken and waffles with eggs, Chinese-Style steamed buns and Mimosa! 

Pretty excellent and I would go again if given the chance. In a sea of buffets and all you can eateries ..thie ARIA Buffet stands out for me! Happy Eating!

I guess 3 and a half stars is about right. I enjoyed the food but it was pricey. I came to Vegas and we were starving and went to the buffet since we were staying at the Aria. Dinner on a Saturday night was $35 per person. Ouch!

They did have lobster which I'm told isn't served at most buffets and since lobster goes for about 10 bucks per tail, I could see why people were loading up on lobster getting 3-4 a plate. 

For a buffet, they do have a decent selection of meats (prime rib, steak, roasted pig, chicken, etcetera. No ham). They had pork chops as well but I can't remember how it was made. 

They do have a good selection of seafood, pastas, and desserts and the Aria buffet seems to strive for quality over quantity but I think most of buffets have similar items. The items at Aria are slightly better but I never go to buffets for desserts and a creme brulee is a creme brulee no matter where you go. The desserts look pretty and come in their own plates and they do have a decent selection.

The oddest thing about the restaurant is that it actually shakes. We all thought it was because we all had a long flight and had been starving all day. But it seems either their sound system isn't setup right or they forgot to install some insulation when they built the place. It actually felt like eating during a mild earthquake (around 3.0 on the Richter scale for us Californians :) ).

Service was slow. Our server was nice but we could tell she was really busy despite the fact we arrived really early for dinner (4pm) and the place was not packed. It took awhile before she could back to our table for refills and clear our plates. My opinion on that is that they need to hire more servers because they can't handle the load at the moment. 

To summarize: I liked the food alot but it's pricier than most buffets and you could get better deals elsewhere.

The Buffet at Aria is one of my new favorites. It has a lot of the same food that the Bacchanal buffet has at Caesars but it's not as pricey. Caesar's has the fresh juice and the crepes made to order but if you don't care about those items I think the food is similar.  If you are a local there is a locals discount during the week which is about $30.00 a person . The good news about going during the week is they still serve crab legs during dinner and it isn't as crowded as the weekend. 

I liked the fact that during dinner you not only get the crab legs but they can make you Pan Roast (seafood cooked in a red broth served with rice) to order. They only sprinkle a little rice in it but you can add more white rice it is near the Pho. Yes there is also Pho (Vietnamese soup) for those who love soup like I do especially in this chilly weather. The Pan Roast had a nice kick to it and it was super tasty but I think it could do without this pink and white seafood block they put in it though.  They also have a Cajun type of stew with corn ,sausage , shrimp that is pretty good too. Dinner and brunch both have creative salads to choose from. My favorites contained plenty of mushrooms, beets and grapefruit.  If you are there during brunch do me a favor and get a couple of little plates of the baby clams in the garlic sauce it is to die for!! Trust me!

Was staying at vdara when we decided to take a short walk to the buffet at aria. Woke up on a Thursday (August 3rd) around noon and got to the buffet line around 1pm for brunch. About 10 people already waiting in line, which isn't terrible because Vegas buffers usually have a long wait to check in to get seated. About a 10 min wait in line to check in and pay. Got seated next to the jacuzzi facing the pool. The buffet had so many options! I started in the Asian cuisine (which is the first station on the left next to the desserts) my eyes were bigger than my stomach! Pad Thai, rice in a cooker for self serving, pho with all the toppings you can add. Omelet station, pizza station, Charcuterie, multiple cheeses, middle eastern food with homemade naan bread, tahziki, mexican food with pozole! Prime rib, Mac and cheese, sliders, bagels and pastries, sushi, crab legs, salad bar, waffles with whip cream and fruit compote toppings. (Waffles were amazing, kept coming back for more), fresh squeezed watermelon juice, and more!! The desserts were amazing. The muffins were the same ones they sell at the fancy bakery in the casino. Tons of gelato options! Our server was great! Attentive and friendly. Removed used plates quickly to give us more room to get more food. Overall a great experience, can't wait to come back!

Why the 2 star wack? Well, 1st of all, the dim sum I raved about in my previous review has gone tumbling downhill.  At first bite of har gow (I got 5)...I grimaced and thought what? So I surreptitiously spit it out.  I said "it has no shrimp in it!"  So onto the next one...that must be a mistake of course. Har gow #2....what....?!!  I spit it out....less surreptitiously. This time I poked at it and tried to assess what was going on. It tasted like shrimp and seafood...but not completely like shrimp and it seemed mealy. Well these two must have been overcooked I surmised. Onto #3.....gag. What? This time I dissected this thing and the only thing I could think is that they have mashed up shrimp with fish cake or fish ball? #4 was the same...I couldn't even go to #5. By the way, the har gow was not disappearing off the buffett like last time. Aria, you definitely saved money by preparing it this way...please don't call it har gow!

The seafood saves this buffet though. We chowed down on snow crab legs which were surprisingly tasty for as small as they were...not too salty and seemingly fresh. We also feasted on well prepared shrimp, clams and mussels. They even have crawfish or "mudbugs" like they say down in Louisiana. We splurged on the all you can drink package for 13 bucks....quite a deal but it does take a little while to get your beverages.   While I still think they have one of the better seafood selections, not sure I would return knowing that they cheapened the har gow.

I honestly don't understand how anyone can grouse about the buffet at Aria, unless they don't really like buffets in general. If you want a fine dining experience - go to Scarpetta or Guy Savoy. If you want an amazing buffet - it's at Aria. 

I first went to the Aria buffet in October 2012 and by the time of my next visit in October 2013, it had been revamped. I liked it originally, but the re-do makes the experience even better. My friend and I visited for lunch, and the price was very reasonable - maybe $22? Complimentary beverages are served in classy stemless wine glasses and our cheerful server was all about making sure we stayed hydrated. 

Of all the things I ate, the only bite I wasn't crazy about was a lone potsticker. That means I found the following things delicious: chicken salad, ham, macaroni & cheese, mashed potatoes, sushi (albeit the rice was a tad dry), antipasti, mushroom bruschetta, French onion soup, corned beef hash, gazpacho, crab legs, mussels, pecan tart, chocolate cake, coconut macaroons...and probably more things I can't remember.

Very good. 
Waitress are friendly. 
Good Food. 
Desserts are good. 
Good Price. 
Best Buffet in las Vegas.
We didnt wait at all. We went there 3 Times brakfast Lunch & Dinner.  
We tried lots of the Buffets the last Weeks.

3 stars for food. Negative 10 for service.  Started off great. Server immediately took our drink order, cleared one plate and then totally ignored us for the next 2 hours. He kept walking by our table and avoiding eye contact with us. He serviced other tables that arrived but completely avoided us. We were nice and polite to him the entire time so we are baffled. This wasn't just bad service, it was NO service.  This lunch was supposed to be the highlight of our trip but it was the biggest disappointment.

Wow, this was the best buffet my husband & I have ever been to. Bottomless cocktails for just 12.99, and the best selection and freshness I've ever seen at a buffet.
