The nice thing about the Aria that I did enjoy was that after the nice meal the walk around the mall next door was perfect to walk it off sorta speak.

The desserts in here as well were a-ok but nothing spectacular compared to the above 3. I got comped 2 buffets for staying at the signature so it wasn't really terrible considering I didn't pay. It's the same price nearly as the other buffets as well so consider this before actually making it out here.

If I'm near here I guess I'd hit this up since it's not terrible and meets the standard of buffets in Vegas!

We have been to all of the buffets on the strip over time.  I will tell you that for the price and quality, this is one of the best!  Clean, fantastic quality of seafood and so many other items to choose from if you are not a seafood person.  GREAT buffet!

The hubby and I went here last weekend. It was our first time back since it re-opened. All I can say is OMG! This place is so good! We went for breakfast on a Saturday morning. We got there pretty early so we were seated right away and the server was very polite.  (Btw, the server told us that Saturday afternoons are the busiest.) The are lots of food options and if you have special dietary needs, ex. Gluten-free, there are some options for you. If you get an omelet made for you at the omelet station, it will be big so you might want to share so they you have room for the other delicious food.

 We are definitely coming here again!

This buffet was really poor quality.  If we didn't have a credit there, I would not have eaten here.  Nothing seemed fresh and it was all flavorless.  The desserts looked pretty, but all tasted like cardboard.  There MUST be better buffets in Vegas, don't bother with this one.

What to say?  Mid-priced buffet in a nice environment.  ~$34 per person for a Thursday night buffet.  Tables and buffet area were clean and neat.  Pleasant, refined-feeling atmosphere - which was a real plus.  Layout of buffet is pretty well organized, with a semi-circular layout around another center station.  Waitress was attentive to remove empty plates and even kept our water and ice tea full (There is no drink self-service).  I liked the food.  There was a good variety, and it didn't seem to be a bunch of low-rent\/cheap items.  The items were fresh, and the carver station meats were moist.  Good selection of dessert items, which a Vegas buffet is always expected to have.  Really what more can you say about a buffet?  Not a bad choice, appropriate for the price level, and you'll get what you paid for.

We are currently staying at Aria and have had pleasant stay until we decided to give the buffet a try tonight. We felt like having a casual dinner at the hotel tonight and were very very disappointed. The food was unacceptable for this class of hotel. The shrimp lacked flavor, the pasta was dried out looking, the Mexican food wasn't even close to mexican, the baked potatos were hard and not all the way cooked. The only thing that was good were the mashed potatoes of the day. My husband got vanilla ice cream which tasted sour and the chocolate chip cookies were hard. Save your time and money and don't bother checking out this buffet. For the price head over to the wicked spoon buffet at the cosmopolitan, it blows Aria's buffet away. We will never eat this buffet again. Such a shame in this hotel.

Terrible buffet for the price! Scraps for crab, their so called king crab isn't even worth putting on your plate. The salmon was dryer than dry and all their beef that they served was cold and well done. This buffet should be $15.99 for the quality of food... we won't be back!

My family and I visited The Buffet at Aria on Labor Day for lunch. Due to it being a holiday weekend, they upped the prices to ~$40 per person. For the price, the food selections were sparse and plain. 

The "Indian" section consisted of some naan and 3-4 different types of curries. The dishes lacked even a hint of the spicy fragrances that Indian dishes are known for. The "Chinese" section had some steaming baskets filled with "dimsum," but the wrappers and dough were all mushy and unappealing. 

The meat carving area offered a large variety of meats, including turkey, beef, and barbeque brisket. The brisket was dry and tasteless, even though we were there at just past 11AM. I shudder to think of what it tasted like at noon. Although we were there for lunch, they had a lot of breakfast options left, including cereal (Why?? I'm not paying $40 for cereal), bagels, waffles, french toast, and a custom omelet counter. 

The desserts were lackluster and unimaginative. They had typical desserts you'd find in any normal buffet outside of Las Vegas, like chocolate cupcakes and plain cheesecake. 

Service was mediocre, too. Our server took away my mom's bowl of soup that was still over halfway full without asking if she was done with it, and it took 3 requests until she brought us 2 (for the 4 of us) crab crackers. She was pretty much absent through much of the meal and we always had empty plates piled up on our table. 

The only redeeming qualities at the buffet would be its beautiful natural lighting, the not-overly-salted crab legs, and the lack of lines. With all of the spectacular buffets and restaurants competing on The Strip, The Buffet at Aria really needs to step up its game.

The buffet itself isn't horrible but the service is pretty bad. 

Came here on a Sunday night and they were way understaffed. People were confused as to where to sit and the hostesses didn't know which tables were open. Out drinks weren't refilled as the poor waitresses was running around trying to take too many tables on. 

Food: It is allright. You obviously can't compare it to the Bellagio or the Wynn but it's decent. The garlic naan was SO GOOD! It has to be good since it was actually made in those cool stone clay pans and made fresh right on the spot. The shrimp is very large and fresh. The crab labs weren't bad. 

Dessert: Ok well you know it has to be good since it was designed by Pastry Champion Jean-Philippe Maury. I literally tried everything! Not too sweet and not too decadent. 

I really only came here cuz I had food credit from Aria. I guess it's not bad for the price. I believe it was around $27.00 for dinner per person

Very nice establishment offering great tasting food and hands down one of the favorite buffet spots on the strip--better than most!!  MaryAnn, Luz, and the Manager on duty are very professional and provided a pleasant experience--outstanding customer service during my last visit (March 2017) by all three--thanks guys :-).

A huge variety of foods on their brunch buffet.  They have everything from scrambled eggs, bacon and a HUGE pancake to crab legs and prime rib!  There was a New England Clam bake, salad and food from many nations (the hummus was excellent).  The server who brought drinks was on top of it the whole time and even at $35 a person, it was well worth it.

It was Saturday morning and I was browsing the little booklet you get behind the headrest on the taxi and noticed this ad for a buffet at Aria.  
It showed a picture of Alaskan King Crab and shows breakfast for $15, lunch for $20 and dinner for $28.  

So we take a taxi to the hotel and by the time we get there, it was late morning.  Low and behold they charged us $25 each for BRUNCH.  We didn't think much about it until after I sat down and started eating.  I then remembered that they advertised Alaskan King Crab and that was one of the main reasons why I wanted to eat here.  When I approached the buffet line, they had SNOW CRAB LEGS-which is a anorexic, cheap version and very different.  I looked at the receipt and noticed that we not only were overcharged, but they falsely advertised their shit.  Not only did they charge us MORE for brunch than breakfast, even lunch, but they didn't have what they advertised at all.

I approached the manager and her response was that the Alaskan King Crab is for dinner only.  Look at the ad I uploaded and you tell me if it says that.  HELL NO.  I asked her to show me where the fuck it says that the crab is "during dinner only".  She said, "Oh, I'll talk to marketing about that".  Are you freaking kidding me?  I'm not falling for that BS line.  Not only that, but why is her brunch prices higher than lunch?  She couldn't answer.  She then said, "Well, let me check with the chefs in the back and see if we have any Alaskan King Crab.  Uh...that's great, but I'm actually DONE eating and it's more about the issue more than anything now.  She brought me a plate of the crab legs, but I wasn't into it anymore.  I didn't like how she tried to pull the sheets over my eyes and mislead me, along with all the other people that didn't bother speaking up.  As a compromise, she refunded me 1 meal ($25).  I was satisfied, but wonder how many other people caught this.  

The food was good, not spectacular.  One of my favorites was the thick-cut smoked bacon.  The pre-made breakfast burrito was yummy as well.  Oh...the absolute BEST thing they had was (drum roll) the COFFEE!  OMG...it was the absolute best coffee I've ever had in Vegas.  Starbucks\/Peets can't touch this stuff.  The only other time I had coffee like this was in Portland Oregon in a coffee house there.  Aria has good breakfast if you pay $15 (as advertised), but certainly not $25 they tried to scam me on.

What has happened to the Aria Buffet?

My partner and I have dined here on several dozen occasions over the past 2+ years, and we've seen it slowly go downhill. We are MLife Platinum members and frequent the Aria Casino regularly. Recently, it's been just hit-or-miss.

What a disappointment on Easter Sunday dinner at 7:30pm, when they do an extra surcharge at $47.99 per person, plus tax. I was expecting they could do a little better on a "holiday".
Foremost in our minds was the decision to remove the made-to-order pasta station, which my partner enjoyed on almost every occasion previously. Now, in its place, there's just a lonely Pho station, which does not look appetizing and from which no one orders. It's confusing what exactly it even is.

The deli meats used to include high end selections- delicious salami and prosciutto. Now, it looks like thin slices of turkey, ham, and roast beef. They have even cut down on the cheese selection, no longer serving mozzarella, dried apricots, various nuts, or the flatbreads and breadsticks which used to accompany the spread on a daily basis.

The carving station used to have roasted vegetables- carrots, onion, purple cauliflower, butternut squash, and zucchini. This time-ONLY yellow zucchini. 

In addition, some of our favorite classic selections have been ruined--Mac and Cheese is now Lobster Mac and cheese, Plain vegetable fried rice is now Shrimp fried rice. Not for vegetarians...

The Aria Buffet used to be amazing- a great and vast selection of food. I used to rave about it and recommend it left and right.
We loved the Raspberry and Apricot Rugelach from the dessert station, which is unfortunately never served anymore.

Also, during our most recent visit, my partner went to the dessert station for a chocolate chip cookie. He returned for another one and saw an employee taking about 10 remaining cookies and packing them up. If there's only ten left, why not allow customers to finish them? Very perplexing.

My partner actually left hungry because he couldn't find anything appetizing. At $200 for a party of four, we truly felt we did not get our money's worth, and do not plan on returning any time in the near future.

We lived in Aria and had our breakfast here. $18.99 for weekday breakfast excluding tax. Not many seafood, only quite a lot sausage and ham. Benedict egg was not bad. Desert was always of good quality. Not comparable to Caesar.

Since I live in Nevada and have had 5days\/week access to pretty decent buffets for a long time, buffets generally don't excite me anymore.

This trip however was with a first timer friend and we went for a mid week lunch. 

There were expectingly no line at all at the cashier, very friendly, helpful ladies. There were a buy one get one bottomless drink offer going on so we took advantage of that plus I had a 2 for 1 voucher for the buffet as well. So price wise it was unbeatable for us at least.

What I loved the most about the Buffet? It felt spacious and the pool view and extra light was a bonus. The food variety was acceptable. Enough options that anyone can find at least few favorites to go back to. Mine was the mushroom cheese pizza and dolma. The Mediterranean section in general was my favorite. 

Just had an issues with our server, it felt like he was deliberately avoiding to notice us! Had to flag him down every time we needed something. Before we leave asked for a beer refill and he rather aggressively ordered me to show him my receipt. He took it and came back with my beer (that was my 3rd glass, not that it matters) . And told me again with a very aggressive tone that this is your last drink you can't get anymore! We were done anyways and were almost about to leave but I asked why is that? And he told  me "there is a 2 hour limit no more drinks!" 
It's not a big deal I'm sure he was having a bad day or something, and I calmly told him first of all if I want more drinks I will get more drinks and second, we were there for exactly 1 hour 10 minutes! So this was a little bit odd. 

Bottomline this was a solid 3.5 star experience. To be honest , I would rather go to wicked spoon next door at Cosmo or buffet at Wynn if I have to pay the full price.
But if you happen to score a deal, by all means give it a try and I'm sure my experience with our server was just a one time hiccup.

Great selection and lots of foods from around the world. Loved the seafood station with salmon, crab legs, shrimp and grits, seared tuna and steam claims to order. 

The price is a little high but worth it if you want to experience a true over the top Vegas buffet.

Friendly service\/ staff and I love the feel of the place. Unlike some old looking buffets, this felt like a nice restaurant only thing is you're pretty much getting your own food. I really enjoyed the beef short ribs( went back for it probably 3x) and of course ate as much Crab Legs that I could handle but leaving room for some gelato ( I got the Oreo one) super good! Would definitely come back. Oh! And if you play Vegas slots you can get a free buffets, me and my family each got our dinner buffets for free! But still would come back even if it wasn't free

This is probably one of the worst buffets I've been to on the strip. A lot of the foods seemed like it was sitting there for hours, un-flavorful, cold...I could go on to how bad this place is but I don't have the words to describe them. Do yourself a favor and go to Bellagio or even Planet Hollywood across the street.

Amazing food selections for the price. Top notch. Great tasting. Great presentation. Loved the deserts. So much to choose from. Unlimited Mimosa's (great champagne  used? I was drunk before 1030AM wow! lol

Parents with kids be forewarned:  children over 3 years of age will be charged as an adult.  I thought this was pretty outrageous.  

As for the food, it's a mix.  Most of the salads are excellent including the crab legs.  The meats--prime rib, chicken, etc.--not so good.  

Desserts--not great.  Bad apple pie and flan.  The bread pudding (my favorite) looked so bad I didn't even try it.  

If you can, look elsewhere for a buffet.

The service provided by our server, Meraf, was second to none.  I spent three times the cost of this evenings meal at lemongrass last night and Meraf ran circles around the server at lemongrass. Many thanks to Meraf for making my last night in Vegas a memorable dining experience.

This buffet was pretty decent...  That is if you liked the food they had to offer.  Not too much in the fish department, which was a downer for me...  But the spaghetti with the asparagus in the truffle oil was pretty good...  I mixed that with the corn and I was content...  The cold shrimp and crab legs was decent, as it is a usual standard in all buffets...   The sushi on the other hand wasn't doing much for me.  The Salmon and the Tuna Nigiri was not for me...  The fish was actually dried out...  NOT GOOD...  Especially for this sushi girl...  But never got the chance to eat the meat stuff...  It's because the dessert was calling my name...  

There were these little shot glasses that got my curiosity going...  One was a berry cheesecake and the other was a coffee shooter...  So, I took a chance on the coffee shooter, and of course HAD TO HAVE my creme bruele...  But it only took one spoonful of the coffee shooter to have my mind set...  And I've got only ONE WORD for it...  AWESOME!!!  It was sooo yummy and it's just a light coffee taste...  So delicious, I HAD TO HAVE 2!!!  Anyway, this buffet is just "A-OK"...  Lucky for us, we had a $50 dollar food & beverage credit for staying here at the Aria, so it really only cost me, about 11 dollars for the buffet...  Works for us...  Maybe give it some time, it's still a new hotel and hopefully they'll jazz it up a bit...  We'll just have to wait and see...

My husband and I are staying in Las Vegas for the week at NY NY and we were so excited to come here, as we usually frequent this buffet every time we visit and are never disappointed. However, today caused me to never come back here again. We arrived around 4:30p today and we're promptly seated by our friendly host. Our waiter was friendly and very quick with our drink order. I come here strictly for the cold crab legs and the carrot cake. The carrot cake here is to die for and it comes with a small serving of a pineapple purée that is just divine. I walk by the dessert bar to get a view of the lovely carrot cakes and what do you know? It's been replaced by a disgusting Black Forest cake. I say it's disgusting because I tried it and it has some type of cherry jam in it that is reminiscent of cough syrup. YUCK! Ok, I'll move on to the crab legs and I'll feel better. Welp, no cold crab legs, just shrimp and muscles. I'm just striking out left and right at this place. I walk around the seafood bar and find steamed crab legs. I guess this will do, they look good. I sit down with my husband and begin cracking open and eating the crab legs and OMG! it's like someone just dumped salt all over them. They're completely inedible! We wasted money on this buffet and there is nothing I want to eat. It's so disappointing. I try the beef steamship and it's cold and hard. I give the beef brisket on mashed potatoes a try and it tastes the way cat food smells! C'mon, Aria! What happened? You used to be so good! You won't be getting my money anymore, or any recommendations.

This place has a variety of crab legs and a variety of ethnic foods, including curry, dumplings, and pho. There is a moderate selection of meat at the carving station.

The desserts are okay if you like them American-style.

What stood out the most were the dumplings. There was plenty of stuffing inside! You don't get that often, since they usually try to minimize the stuffing to keep costs down.

The sticky rice was also good.

Bottom line is, if you're okay with just snow crab legs but want the best meat, go to Le Village Buffet in Paris. If you want to have a variety of crab legs, curry, and Asian food, it is better to go here.

Keep in mind that lines can form, and it can take a while until the servers take your drink orders.
Decent buffet but definitely not worth the $37+ per person on the weekend.
We decided we should try an all you can eat buffet and wow, what a spread. Everything was delicious. Especially the desserts.

You would think being one of the newest resorts in Las Vegas, and smack in the middle of all the action, that The Buffet at Aria would be top notch.  Any but!

I went with a group of 4 on a Wednesday at 12 noon.  There was a 30 minute wait.  No big deal for a quality buffet.  Once we got our table, the service was prompt and good.  This is why I gave it at least 2 stars.  If the service was poor, I would have given none (1).  So why the poor rating? THE FOOD!  They pride themselves on all you can eat crab legs.  And they had both hot and cold to select from.  I tried both.  Both were very dry and little on the meat.  The legs are cut length wise down the middle, so you get one really thin side of meat to eat, which takes a lot of work to get a small dry and flaky reward.  They have several stations to sample different parts of styles; Asian, Mediterranean, American, Mexican and a couple others.  The Asian sucked.  Noodles were bland and the Korean ribs fat and greasy.  The Prime rib (which was actually Ribeye roast, not Prime) was dark throughout.  There is a cold cut section which was tasty, but all the cheeses next to it were cubed.  So if you wanted to make a little sandwich, you were out of luck.  I tried a pepperoni pizza bagel and waited until a fresh one came out of the oven.  When I got back to my table to eat, it was soggy in the middle, disgusting.  I tried a few other things and overall wasn't impressed.  The dessert section had a lot of variety and I sampled several items.  All were pretty good, except for a lollipop cake.  It was gross.

All four of us had high hopes for this buffet.  The Aria hotel is super nice and has an upscale look inside and out.  So to pay $35 and for this meal was a huge let down.  I'm not trying to be overly critical, just accurate.  Trying the one at Caesar's next... I hear it is amazing.  Hopefully I will remember to post a review

* Welcome Experience
- Blatantly Bad

Even for a buffet, this crew was just obnoxious.  

* Establishment
- Ordinary

It's a buffet.  It feels like a buffet.  It looks like a buffet. Nothing worth mentioning here.  

* Service
- Ordinary

Our server was prompt, friendly and attentive.   

* Food Quantity \/ Quality \/ Presentation
- Somewhat Encouraging (it's a buffet!)

I don't know should I write a review of buffet food or tell you how the food was at this buffet?  Ok I'll do both...

Buffet food: Ambitious!  They are innovative and are trying to do cool things!  Exotic(ish) entrees appear throughout the sectioned-off buffet and new ideas seem to be welcome here as they have small bites and cool combinations available.  For example...

A charcuterie section was a good try.  Tillamook cheddar and cheap lunchmeat slices made it a miss.  

Small bites glasses full of various salads was a cool idea.  I tried Thai beef and it was just ok.  (A piece of cheap roast-beef lunchmeat in a glass with some dressing and greens.)

Stunning (looking) desserts will please the eye but disappoint the taste buds (IMHO.) 

The food if it were not a buffet:  No good!  For the novelty of a buffet, variety and quantity, this place is your spot.  For good food you need to find another dining experience elsewhere.  

* What I'll remember

- The Mecca of glistening desserts - I SO WISH my mouth's experience matched my eyes'!

What I can't wait to forget

The dried out brisket.  The sawdust rice.  The decaying Shu Mai.  The velveeta Mac and cheese.

Steamed, hot snow crab with drawn butter is a winner! Having a choice of consuming hot or cold crab is a great idea. Must taste gelato flavors - mandarin yuzu, gluten free pistachio, pumpkin, peanut butter w\/ chocolate pretzel are delicious! There are so many gelato flavors that I saw in the automated carousel but did not have a chance to try. Mini whoopie pies are delectable! Gluten free panacotta is yummy!

After reading some of the other reviews here, I almost didn't go to this buffet which would have been a mistake.  Some of the points mentioned by the other reviewers while true, don't equate to a 1 or 2 star rating.  Yes, the shrimp was located a long way from the crab legs, the Asian items at this buffet are not the greatest, etc.  buth this place serves quality food.

I found the atmosphere to be dependent on where you are sitting.  The middle area is most pleasant with the dimmed lighting.  Sitting on some of the edges may make the place seem more cafeteria like.

The Food:  I ate the weeked gourmet buffet (which costs a bit more).  They had rack of lamb, leg of lamb, sucking pig, and many more great tasting  rare items.  Even the taste and quality of the none entree items (rice, potatoes etc.) was high.  The deserts here are exceptional.  They are exquisitely prepared on small desert trays.  I tried 5-6 different items, and they were all excellent.  They also had some gelato although the selection was not as great as at the Rio seafood buffet.  

I'm only giving this four stars because I have not tried  the Bellagio.  I'd say the overall quality, value, and taste is  a bit higher than the Mandalay Bay buffet (which is also very good).

I returned to the weekend dinner buffet in January 2011.  The prices seem a bit higher, but they now give you half a lobster ($5 extra for a whole lobster) and house wines with your dinner.  The various entrees and side dishes (great garlic naan) are still excellent as was the service.  The desert selections were not as large as when they first opened.
First time here and it was awesome, enjoyed all the food. It was great. And our server Beatriz was great, she was super friendly and had a smile every time.

I am not a buffet person. My parents live in Vegas and they love buffets. I must admit, for a person who eats healthy (me), this worked for me and I ate here twice during my stay, once for lunch and for breakfast.
The selection is not as massive as most but the food is refreshed often, the presentation is good and it worked for me.
Is it knock your socks off? Absolutely not. But for $20 for breakfast and $24 for lunch it is a good value.
What did I like?
They will toss your salad and it is good choices. This won me over.
The smoked salmon (lox) was pretty good quality.
The fresh fruit was decent.
The roasted beets for lunch were delicious.
I left happy and not stuffed. Perfect.
And I didn't hate it, like I usually do at Mandalay Bay.
Well done, Aria.

Vegas Bay-beeee!  

Buffets and Smoke filled casinos and the newest is Aria.  So of course we had to at least try it right?  

$19.99 for lunch. Ok it's new and bright and all pretty looking, but at 1pm the place was only about 1\/2 filled. Strange for the newest buffet on the strip.  

Onto the food. Salty. Bland. Salty. Bland. Salty. I couldn't even finish the piece of prime rib cause it was way too salty...plus the whole thing was cooked to what looked like medium-well and by the time they cut the piece off, the little bit of pink disappeared and it was a nice well done. blah.  I had to laugh at the chinese bbq pork...they had a carver cutting little pieces for people. Really? 

The only thing I enjoyed was the hot & sour soup. Cause it had flavor and wasn't salty.  Saving grace for bad buffets is usually dessert. Not here. Again. No flavor in anything. Oh and most of the desserts are served on these pretty plates that are really bulky so you can carry maybe three of them at the most if you stack them right. It's a buffet for crying out loud, I want to be able to load up a plate will 20 desserts to sample :o)

Ok maybe I'm being harsh. I mean I did stay out until 5:30am drinking so maybe my taste buds were dead or something.  Of our group of 7, three thought the food was good. But they were eating things like chow mein and pizza and chicken.  

The only thing I enjoyed about this place was the music playing. What's not to love about eating bad food while headbanging to Lady GaGa and Beyonce.

The customer service here let this buffet down considerably. Our waiter seemed to be making a concerted effort to ignore out attempts to gain his attention and took over twenty minutes to bring drinks even after we spoke to the manager.

Food was okay do not under any circumstances order the ramen soup at the Asian station it tastes like it was made from the same ramen college students eat. It was watered down to boot. So foul. My slice of prime rib was blue which is not my preference. The ribs were good though as were the deserts I tried except the flan which tasted like egg and the creme brûlée which was sloppy. 

There is a large selection and they do have hot beverages available on request. Getting your waiter to bring them is a problem

This buffet was over priced.  The crab legs were tiny and there was nothing that I wanted to go back for more of.  I tried something from every station and wasn't that impressed with any of it. The sushi and desserts were probably the best thing they had to offer.

The food is great here for the price. It's about $26\/person for lunch but you get unlimited smoked salmon, crab legs, peppered shrimp, gelato and other goodies. The entrée selections may pale compared to other buffets, but the dessert selection is hard to beat. The assortment of cakes, cookies and ice cream makes the price almost worthwhile. It's about $5 for a small cup of gelato outside, but you can get unlimited amounts in the buffet. Three scoops is already about $15! The sushi selections are meh.. not too great. Basically Asian food is not gonna be that great. The pizza was tasted alright though! 

The service is pretty nice. I had a few problems with my server this weekend though. I asked for OJ, and she forgot. I asked her again and she gave me grapefruit juice. It was bitter, but that's sort of expected since its fresh. I asked her for a coffee and she forgot again. Personally, I think she was attending too many tables that she forgets what people ask her for. So -1 star for that.

Personally I would give this a 3star rating for the price\/quality ratio but it's Vegas. It's hard to find great cheap food that you would normally find in LA. I've tried many buffets in the city, but this one seems to stand out from the rest.

Take this review from a seasoned veteran of Vegas buffets.  The $19.99 weekday lunch buffet at the Aria was my favorite buffet in Vegas, ever.  Yes, somehow the wifey and I ended up in Vegas, again, after my bro.i.l.'s (ie my wife's brother, not the husband of my sister) wedding in SoCal.  We stayed at the Aria and ate at the lunch buffet on a whim and because we didn't feel like walking around in 100+ degree weather outside (38C for all you metric people).   

King Crab legs, prime rib, pasta and omelette stations, sushi (rolls and a few pieces of nigiri), desserts by Jean Phillipe, and more- FOR LUNCH.  But the station that put this buffet experience over the top was the Chinese station.  Yes, believe it or not, the Chinese food station at Aria's buffet was excellent.  So fresh, not salty, no taste\/aftertaste of madison square garden, and not too oily.  The best Chinese I've had at a buffet- bar none.

I don't plan on going back to Lost Wages for a while.  But the next time I'm there, I'll be eating here again.

Not what I was really expecting from a Vegas buffet. Food was just ehhh, meats were sitting out for a while, you could see the harden layer above everything that was sitting out. I thought Vegas buffet's were supposed to be jaw dropping good.

Visited for Sunday brunch.  Paid $53 for 2 people. Not bad for 5 start hotel buffet.

Pleasantly surprised.  They had crag legs, typical american breakfast items, chinese (they have Congee!), mexican, italian, meats, sushi (not the real sushi with raw fish, just vege roll types), deserts, fruits, and etc.

Decor wasn't as nice as Wicked Spoon but food was better I think.  And more items too.

I saw the sign that you get whole lobster for 2 and unlimited wine for dinner buffet.  Not a bad deal.

I'd recommend this place.

Really dont know why this place only have 3 stars.. i hate comparing but seriously if i will, this place will still be one of the best.. specially the crab legs.. and the price is reasonable.. so guys what are waiting for? Go go go..
Not worth it at all, cold food, hardly anything is authentic, waste of money to be honest!

You come here for the crab legs. Pre-cut, all-you-can-eat and delicious. Keep in mind people are typically clamoring for them so you may need to be patient. My first two rounds all I got we're smaller legs because that was all that was left...slim pickings. The third time, however, I waited patiently for the fresh batch of crab legs and was handsomely rewarded. Totally worth it!

Everything else was either just ok or a pass. I tried thier baked salmon (good), clams (gross), new zealand green-lipped mussels (ok), shrimp (good) and eel (eh). For dessert I had cheesecake which was ok and caramel macchiato which wasn't what I expected. I didn't like it. 

Moral of the story...it's all about the crab legs. Lesson learned.

I have tried numerous buffets in Las Vegas, and the Aria ranks up with the Paris as tied for my favorites.  I go for the quality of the food and friendliness of staff  when rating them. I don't eat a lot but like the variety you get at a buffet. Marref stands out for her exceptional service!

Just visited at 10:00am, had omelette bar, different sausages, corned beef hash, biscuits n gravy, waffles, pancakes, etc. Ehh. Okay. Small which was fine because the quality was good and they offered lots of gluten free foods. I enjoy lunch foods more so I appreciated the crab legs, seafood paella, steak picado, meats, olives, and cheeses. 
They have pizza, salsa, and Asian food too.


Not sure it was worth 32.95 per person but that's the comparable rate for brunch buffets. For an extra $6, you can add bottomless mimosas or bloody mary's to your brunch. 


The waitress was nice but our soiled plates would stay on the table for quite  a while. 

If you're at City Center stop by during the week or lower prices. . 

*no line when we got there

We walked the buffet and they did not have anything that we liked. There were too many breakfast choices at 1pm. The only reason why I give them 4 stars is because of the service. We told the manager that the buffet did not interest us and they refunded us with out any issues!

I'm not quite sure why the reviews for this restaurant aren't that great. The experience that we had was pretty good! The service was a little slow, however our waitress was really friendly. When we got there, there was no line so we didn't have to wait. We also had an express ticket but didn't need to use it. 

As for the food, we thought they did a very well job with having foods from all over the world, & very fresh sea food.

All in all, our experience was great and will be glad to visit again.

Loved it! Went here for Saturday lunch and Sunday night dinner.  The selection isn't huge like other LV buffets, but the quality is very good. Nice ambience, good service. What really blew me away was the quality of the desserts.  I'm usually not impressed with the desserts at buffets because they typically have no flavor.  These were the best desserts I've had at a buffet.  I also read that the desserts were supplied by Jean Philippe, same guy who has the patisserie in the Aria lobby area.  So that's probably why they were so good.

Great selection of seafood. Lobster was nice too, including selection of lobster ravioli and lobster sandwiches on Sunday night.  We will return.

Yummy buffet with all types of food to fit everyone in your group's tastes. We got there pretty late at night but everything still tasted fresh. Our server was awesome and was right on top of clearing plates and refilling drinks. The desserts are beautiful!!

You know when you go to Vegas, and there's always some place that someone recommended in the back of your mind - "OH I went to Vegas, and the so-and-so buffet was so good!  You have to try it!"   The Buffet was that place for us this time around - we have no idea who recommended it, but it was recommended.

There's the usual variety - cold seafood appetizers, salad, ethnic entrees, hot carving station, and dessert.  Much like the so-modern-that-it's-boring decor, everything was just ho-hum.  The only things that wow'ed me were the crème brûlée and flan.  Maybe it's just me, but I've gotten used to Vegas buffets always having one or two or ten amazing items - whether it's great prime rib, fresh fish, or oysters - gimme something to make my friends jealous with "OMG you have to try this at The Buffet!"   Sadly, there was none of that here - just an empty feeling inside and an empty wallet outside.

Aria's interior and exterior decor is beautiful and stylish.  The hotel is huge!! However, I was not as impressed by the buffet as compared to the other buffets.

I came here on Dec. 26th for Lunch ($30 per person).  The Buffet is on the second floor.  It was quiet difficult to find .. only because I wasn't aware that it was on the second floor.  

The line for The Buffet was long; however, luckily my family of 17 had VIP access to the buffet.  To get seated for 17 individuals appeared very difficult, especially for one hostess.  We even told them that splitting the group would be fine with us.

The Food was good.  I especially loved the burrito!.  There was variety, especially in the Chinese food and Meat!.  The Shrimp and the Shu Mai is so FRESH! I really liked the food, but they lacked Pasta and did not have a large selection of sushi.  However, the dessert selection was amazing!! There was a large selection of pastries, ice cream, and cakes!  The Coconut Ice cream is A MUST to eat!

The service was good, except one hostess that was really rude.  So -1 star for her.  While we were getting seated, they placed our group to the side.  Throughout the whole time she was complaining to all the other hostess right in front of us saying, "They are not suppose to be here", "We should never do a group of 17", "What are they doing...", etc. as she rolled her eyes at us.  There were so many tables, that we honestly could not understand what the problem was.  However, one member in our group had a talk with her, in which she instantly started to treat us well.  High corporate power for the hotel can instantly change a person's service.   

Overall, the food was good.. but for a new hotel .. I expected better.

I love the muesli!  Good sushi, roast station, and dessert bar, too.  They also have pretty good quality selection with this price.  I like their buffet much better than Bellagio's .  I thought Bellagio had more food to choose, but only a few stations are good, and it costs more.  If I'm going to a buffet, I'll pick the one at Aria.
Came here with family and just want to try their buffet but it's not that good. Very disappointed. The service was pretty good but I don't think the food is fresh enough especially the seafood!

Not worth the money. This buffet does not have the variety nor quality of food you would expect for the price. I looked up the price on their website and it said nothing about holiday pricing the day after Thanksgiving. We arrived to find it was $37.99, even for my son who barely ate anything. Positive notes: kept clean and had attentive staff.

The Buffet at The Aria was amazing. I have Celiac Disease and have to eat gluten free. The chef came out of the kitchen and walked me around to tell me what I could and couldn't eat. He made me a gluten free pancake, amazing gluten free ravioli and gluten free pizza.  The crab legs were fresh and wonderful . The staff were all very helpful, kind and prompt. And to top it off, there were several gluten free dessert options, including cookies, brownies and muffins. Plus, I didn't get sick, so the chef knows his stuff.  We will definitely be back the next time we are in Vegas.

Had an early dinner here one Saturday night. $86 for two people. Did not get off to a good start. Seems that we were in the wrong line to pay (prior to being seated) and were barked at by a staff member to stay behind the sign. Once seated, had to wait for about 15 mins before a drink order was taken. Waitress really nice and working at full pace, but clearly not enough staff on. Food was fine and a number of different types - Italian, Carvery, Chinese, Indian, Mexican etc. some staff serving meals -- pasta and Carvery sections were very grumpy indeed. Overall, a very mediocre experience.

Our first buffet when we arrived in Vegas this trip. We hadn't been to this one before and were excited to try it out. There was a line since we are not M Life members or VIPs, but the line moved at a reasonable pace.

If you do buffets, you know what it's like that first Vegas buffet - your appetite is limitless and you want to eat it all. And ate it all we did. Every. Single. Station. (Except crab legs and pho soup because we don't like those things).

There is something for everyone here. There are even delicious roasted on the grill veggies at the carving station. Chips and dip. Little mini salads. Many foods from around the world.

Like most buffets, it is not super amazing. Like the Naan bread was heavy. The dim-sum taste was mediocre at best. I wished they had a steamed pork bun and they didn't have it. The tandoori chicken was adequate. 

The desert section was great. I should have saved more room for this. I wanted to try them all. I almost did but not the pink meringue which supposedly was do die for. The gelato was great and I tried 5 flavors. I wish I had some of the apple pie. Bread pudding isn't my thing so no for that. 

Anyway, if this were the 2nd or 3rd buffet I ate at in Vegas, I would have given 3 stars, but since it was the first one and I was so hungry and I ate everything and my stomach had room still and felt happy and well served here - I am giving it 4 stars. 

I know the reason why I am fat now is partly because it all started here.

Not really impressed with this buffet. We ate here twice and neither time warranted more than 3 stars. 
Arriving after 11am, we had to ask for waffles and cereal, as they stop serving them at 11. The staff did go to great lengths to get us what we asked for, thus deserving the 3 star review. The waitress, however, was slow and inefficient. She brought me coffee and forgot to leave a cup after it took forever to even arrive after getting our drink order. She didn't refill our glasses at all. The buffet itself is sort of a let down. The food is decent and it's limited. It served its purpose in a pinch, but we won't be returning.

Beautiful ambiance, spacious & great food presentation. The quality of the food is thus far the best buffet I have been to. Great dessert selections. I love the made to order salad. I like how you can chose to include unlimited alcohol.

How times have changed. I was given $100 food credit so my parents and I went here for dinner tonight.

My expectations of this place from last time were average so I was hoping that it was gonna be better. Far from it.

I was hoping to have a decent dinner experience since my last buffet trip at Bacchanal last year was really disappointing.

Where do I begin? Almost all the food I tried tonight really missed their mark. Cold crab legs were salty. Hot ones were ok when my parents brought some but when I went they were barely warm then became cold real quick. Sushi was terrible. Korean short ribs were burnt and had lots of fat on it. Pork ribs had decent flavor but was tough to eat. Pizza was awful and I usually don't have any problems with buffet pizza but the pepperoni slice was off. The only thing I tried from the Asian section was the sesame seed balls with red bean inside and those were tough to eat.

The only decent things I had here tonight were the shrimp and grits and mac & cheese.

But what gets me is the lack of variety in some of the sections. Mediterranean, Italian and Indian sections were poor with selections.

The saving point was the dessert. The rotating ice cream flavors tonight were a huge letdown. Not all the containers were used and some were repeats like vanilla. Dessert section was poor as well.

Service was not that great since our server took a while to get our drinks. And they still use the same tiny glasses.

Overall this trip was a letdown. Doubt I'll eat here again even if it's comped.

Worst dining experience in Las Vegas. Long line & wait to get in. Rude hostess. 15 minutes before our table was greeted & asked for our drink order - had to hunt down a server. For $16.99 the are limitless mimosa & rum punch, question if there if even alcohol in the drinks. As a person in the service industry it takes a lot for me to complain & not leave a tip.

On the positive, the food was decent & wide variety.
Food was just alright. Nothing special. Service was ok. King crab legs were frozen. Carving station chef needed attitude adjustment. Overall probably wouldn't be back for how much they charge.

I usually don't like going to buffet's anymore cuz I overindulge and end up feeling horrible about myself but this one actually felt pretty good afterwards. The buffet offered selections from hand tossed salads, various types of breads and cheeses, fresh seafood, and different types of meat cooked in every way possible. It's really hard to describe the whole dining experience in detail because of the overwhelming choices at this buffet but one thing I can say is that Aria did not spare on the quality of ingredients.

Highlights of the Meal:
Diner- Mac and Cheese with Truffles and the Grilled Cheese with Tomato Bisque
Seafood- Alaskan King Crab Legs
Poultry: BBQ Braised Pork 
Dessert: Lemon Bar and the Gelato!

Quite pricey compared to usual buffets at $45 per person for dinner but the two complementary meals for hotel guests make the bill a bit more reasonable. 

Also, if you're planning to come here for dinner I suggest you wait until around 6pm so that the leftovers from the lunch menu are already replaced by freshly cooked ones. My family and I went around 4:30pm so the sushi and seafood looked like they were out for a while. Besides that, the food was delicious and the service excellent, so I give the restaurant 4 stars for giving us a great family dining experience.

Amazing. It truly is what everyone says it is. I don't eat seafood at all, so that's saying a lot. I love the little decadent portrayals of the food, served in cute little containers. The food is very fresh and the service is impeccable! I will most definitely return, worth every $25.99 for weekday lunch!!

My first and only Vegas buffet, so I have nothing to compare it to... but it exceeded my expectations. Truly something - a lot of somethings - for everyone.  Unlimited snow and king crab legs, delicious shrimp shooters, great carving station, decent desserts.  Didn't have the "buffet" ambiance I expected - I could have easily been in a swanky, trendy restaurant.

There was a time in Las Vegas when people would get dressed up to go out to a luxurious dinner served by people in tuxedos in innovative  facilities with impressive modern design and atmospheric lighting.

While you may pay a luxurious price for this buffet your experience will not be one of luxury. The servers are dressed like farm hands. The maitre d or perhaps I should say the herder is dressed in a busboy outfit.

As for the design of the facility, think one step up from a lunchroom in a school cafeteria. This  is essentially a harshly lit box that charges a lot of money for poor service.
Food was ok. The server Joe was the best. He made sure our plates were taken and our beverage was filled. I give Joe a 5 star. Management needs to recognize his great service

Food was good. The service was ok. I made a request to move to better seating area about 1\/4th the way in and my request was granted.  However after I moved, I was ignored until I was halfway through desert (right before I left).  In general, I kind of like it this way.  I always hate having servers constantly asking you questions over and over when your mouth is full of food and you are trying to eat in peace. However they broke my #1 rule of rules.  One rule to rule them all! Keep my cup full.  Since we are not permitted to fill our own cups like we are at some buffets, this left me rather thirsty for most of the meal, which sucks.

To be fair though, the server did recognize the issue after 30 minutes or so and apologized profusely for forgetting me. It was probably my fault anyways, messing up her groove by requesting a move to another table.

BTW, buffet decor, great! I love the modern, artsy feel to the place.  Plenty of good food and presentation was good. Didn't see any stations go near empty.

I gave it a 4\/5. It was an honest mistake in my opinion and other than that blunder, I was satisfied.

PS: this isn't a 5 diamond establishment. Some reviewers want to pretend and rate it like it is. :-\/.

This buffet has your typical fare but the crab legs are overly salted and not very fresh. 

The Asian station is pretty decent with a lot of options which is far bette than just a Panda Express style spread,  including higher quality dim sum and pretty good ramen.

The carving station -- stay away from the steamship but do get the charred steak which is quite tasty

Just got back from Vegas in which we stayed the last night at Aria, so thought we would hit their breakfast buffet, thinking it would be on par with Belligo and Wynn. Boy, were we wrong. OK, know it's only their second day in operation, but how can you screw up bacon and eggs? My wife and I were shown our table, and immediately went to get our food. The food area was quite long, but not a great selection. Usually I walk and look at the food and figure out the few things that look best so I can fit them onto my plate, but here, it was a struggle to find enough things appealing enough to eat. Their eggs benedict looked very weird; the eggs were freakishly white. Hard to find just regular breakfast fare. There were two omelet stations with many people waiting at each ( you know a buffet is bad when people opt for the 'ol standby omelet) I got in line behind Mr. Picky who had to have a special egg white only omelet with veeeery light Cheddar cheese and was also behind some punk kid who was eating off his plate in line. Idiot. The chef manning the station seemed overwhelmed by the special order so I moved on. A huge slice of ham (not bad), some Chinese egg concoction and a slice of pizza later I went back to eat. Started eating and no server yet. Half way through and still no server. Finally when I was almost done, a server asked if I wanted anything to drink. I barely chocked out, "orange juice". Finally, when I was on my second to last bite, my drink came, all six ounces of it. I asked for two more. 
For 15 bucks, this should have been much better. I have gotten just a good breakfast at Terribles for half the price. Also, since this place should be one of the elite, what I found totally tacky was at each of the foods, instead of having a nice plaque with what the food is, it was written on the sneeze windows with grease pencil. Totally lame. Not sure if we would go back to eat here even if comped. Perhaps their lunch and dinners are better.

Been here many times I would give a 3 star but today is the worst experience ever, food taste bad, seafood not fresh, sushi without fish only veggies, no prime rib, and not many choice. I literally have nothing to eat. Very very disappointed.

I want to give this place a 3.5, but the extremely high price of this buffet made me round it down to a 3. There was like 5 people in line when I got there at 7pm which was very weird. I went on a saturday and the dinner cost like $46 after tax and tip. 

The layout and design of the restaurant give it a high class vibe. The general food and quality was very similar to Bellagio with more of a focus on Indian food. They have fresh made naan which was quite delicious.

Theres the standard crab legs and shrimp, but for some reason the weekend I went it had unpeeled shrimp and the crab legs were smaller then I remembered seeing before. They also gave half a lobster to each guest after you sat down, but you were not allowed to have refills on the lobster. Lobster was very delicious.

I mainly enjoyed the carved meats. They had a lot of options such as brisket, prime rib, pork ribs, beef ribs, skirt steak, mahi mahi, etc. I of which we very good. The chinese food and sushi was okay, but not real memorable. I didnt try the pastas, they had a pasta station, but didnt use it.

The desert area is sorta hit or miss. I didnt like it, but I know others who have liked it. Its more of a crap shoot on whether or not the stuff they had was the stuff you liked. I love cheesecake and creme brulee, but they didnt really have anything like that. The cheesecake they had was not something I would consider to be a cheesecake.

I would go back again, but I think I would rather go to Bellagio buffet.

Always friendly staff and clean environment,however; the food slightly questionable. Sadly, I didn't try the fish market but, I tried everything else. Fresh ingredients over at the salad bar. Some of the food was lacking but, there were some tasty food within the mix. Pace yourself there's definitely a large variety of food.

Just came back from a week in Vegas and I'm a little buffeted out but here goes. I remembered going to this buffet when they first opened a handful of years ago - I thought it was fantastic and worth the $50 we paid on an Easter Sunday. However, they have apparently renovated and this buffet is like half the size, with less choices and not as fancy. My wife and I had a 2-for-1 coupon so it was worth it - but I wouldn't pay full price. As far as items: Italian section was poor, it was spaghetti and meatballs and chicken marsala and antipasta. Carving board was quite good with four different types of meat - mostly beef. sushi was eh. Mussels were great, escpecially new zealand mussels. Most everything was average. Deserts were OK. Waitress service was very good, always filled our drink. I would probably give 3 1\/2 stars but cant. At 2-for-1 I like this place but not at full price.
I was there for mothers day buffets, Yummy, and double plus on crab legs already crack in half for you.

I don't have any idea why this place has 3 stars... The food was really quite awesome, and, by Vegas standards, totally average price. Until this trip, I was under the impression that Spice Market Buffet was as good as it got as far as buffets on the Strip, but I am so glad I did my research and wound up here instead. Every dish I tried was solid, and the dessert selection and presentation was incredible. Best Creme Brûlée I've ever had. The space is nice too, really light, airy, and clean-feeling (as opposed to the somewhat dank, farm-like environment one typically experiences in a buffet). Anyway, highly recommend! :)

The Buffet at Aria lacks variety. It has the typical "international" fair: Chinese, Mexican, American grill, seafood, Italian, Sushi, etc... one nice addition is the Indian cuisine. This may sound like a lot of dishes but really there's only two or three dishes per style. They do prepare the dishes well but there's just not enough choices. Their desserts however offers more choices than the cooked foods combined.

The selection here is solid. Not too much variety compared to the other ones. However, this place has one thing that I love to eat..... King Crab legs. I swore that was all I ate here. The tri tip was pretty good as well. However, asides from those two selection, everything else is pretty mediocre. If you want King Crab legs come here, if not then I recommend somewhere else.

Good food, and an excellent dessert selection, but not worth paying over $40\/person for the gourmet dinner on the weekends. I was expecting quite a bit more selection or higher quality for that price.

I don't know why this place got a 3 stars, but I'm giving it a 5!

I'm not a buffet person, but this buffet surely surprised me. For 30 bucks it was unlimited of yumminess!

The meat (which I judge really hard on, considering my background) was tender, VERY TENDER. It was easy to cut, and easy to choose. I had NO complaining.

They make the kind of pasta you want. The drinks (soda, raspberry tea, etc) are for FREE (well, with your meal, but free refills!. I know it sounds silly but there ARE places where they don't give you that option)  They had king crab, asian food, salad, etc etc. I thought they made the asian food non-salty though, which was a plus for me. 

They just have so much to offer! We sat there for 3 hrs and ate so much. I was truly satisfied. Oh, and if you must know, the bathrooms are clean!!!

The staff was extra extra nice. You can do the valet parking at arias and just provide tips. 

OH! and a BIG bonus for me was that they actually SCOOP the icecream FOR ME!! :] This ain't some lame icecream either...it tasted homemade. Oh, and their flan was delish. I went back to my hotel, SATISFIED. Now I wish I could go back :[

It was my first time coming and eating at the Aria Buffet . We paid $45 a person for my lady and I. Food was gourmet and there is a huge variety so much food to choose from so many flavors definitely worth it if you like gourmet food and buffet style. Also you get a waiter\/waitress

Does this place deserve a one star? Yes on many levels. Let's start with the price. $32 for dinner on a Monday night. OUCH! I immediately look around to see if it's the decor or view that I am paying for but disappointed to find neither. Keep in mind for this price I expect the quality to be on par with Belagio, Wynn, Rio, and the M. So you think my money MUST go to the food. No such luck as the courses are typical of all the buffets here in Las Vegas, but served colder and under-seasoned.

The bottom line is don't waste your money and your calories here.

We tried this because we were going to the Viva Elvis show and thought it would be convenient, which it was.  However, I neglected to check the reviews here first...for the price wish we would've gone to Wicked Spoon.  Food was ok, decor was ok, size was smaller than I would've expected and selection was lacking.  Also, what I read online said 'rack of lamb'...no.  And price online was less than when we got there, this was for a Tues nite.

We do buffets quite a bit and there's many, even at 1\/3 the price, which are far better.

Service, however, was very good.

My daughter and I dined here for lunch\/dinner on 4\/15, the cost was $26 a person. We arrived around 2:30pm, so not only were we able to enjoy the lunch options, we also were able to enjoy the dinner options since the dinner buffet started at 3:00pm. I honestly don't understand all the bad reviews of this place, we loved it! There were so many different options to choose from, and all the food was fresh. The array of proteins was amazing. Best place we ate during our 4 day stay in Vegas. And by the way, use Uber or Lyft everywhere you go, its way better than paying for a taxi or to park, the traffic on the strip is horrible.

Better experience than Cravings in TI, but anything would be better than Cravings. Buffet is deep in the Aria and took a little while for us to find. However, they were very prompt in having us pay and seating us. Price was on the steep side it was $65 altogether for lunch and bottomless drinks. Gratuity of 20% is included for large groups. 

We had a group of nine and we all did the bottomless mimosas, wine & beer in addition to the buffet. Wait staff will only bring you refills for one type of drink at a time. You can double fist the same type of drink but they will make you finish your glass to switch over to another type of drink.  The mimosas were extremely fizzy and carbonated thus hard to drink fast and really filling. Don't have too many mimosas if you're trying to get your $35 out of eating at the buffet! My friends did not enjoy the Bloody Mary. Most of us stuck to beer and drank about 4-6 drinks to get a value out of the bottomless. I tried one of the champagne vodka cocktails and that was pretty good too. Overall this is a great spot for large groups to all find what they like to eat and also get some day drinking in.

Buffet is worth 4.95 very dissapointing coming from Aria. Only French toast, tofu salald and gelato were good.

The wait and price totally not worth it, save your Vegas Money and go somewhere else!!

The Buffet at Aria includes half a lobster and red\/white wine with dinner. The buffet is very contemporary but it gets three stars because none of the food was really memorable.  I had the tandoori chicken in the Indian food section and it was dry.  The prime rib was ok, but not very flavorful.

Why not give everyone a whole lobster or increase the types of offerings here?  The buffet isnt worth the 38 price tag.  Maybe for 25 I'd come back.

The buffet at the Aria was a high end type of buffet serving what was said to be a "gourmet dinner"! There's was from latino, Asian, Mediterranean, American, pizza, and a aisle full of salads fruits and desserts! The best part was the seafood section, there was Alaskan King crab legs, mussels,  shrimp, crawfish etc! My husband and I paid approx 93.00 for two at about 5:00pm so be prepared to pay but it's very worth it!

Initially we were thinking of going somewhere else for a dinner in July 3. But since we were staying close by the aria, we settled for the the buffet at the aria. The reason for the one star: lots of different cuisine from Asian to Italian, Indian, American and Hispanic and the carving section was the only edible side I can take. The downside is the Asian selection when I was checking them doesn't look good at all. Same with the rest of the cuisine. The sushi selection was very limited. The seafood section is also not a good sight to see. Totally not worth  the money you are  paying. The waitress serving us with drinks was also very rude and condescending. I was thinking of giving her a tip but I decided not to because of how she treated us.

I haven't yet been able to try the food but the service is awful. I have been in line for almost 45 minutes and have watch as two work refuse to bus table circling around them and not doing anything. I blame this on poor management!! If you are going to try to have a high in buffet in a "higher end" hotel pay someone to make sure it is ran right. I hope the food is better than the line if I make it.

I am so not a fan of buffets. I feel like they trick you! They put out all this fluff and get you to navigate away from the meats and fish. This is so not the case with The Buffet at ARIA. Everything and I do mean everything was top notch.

Our hotel stay at the Aria gave us access to the The Buffet daily during our stay. I'm thinking, I have dinner plans, why would I come to an AYCE buffet? Our first day was a travel day and we had no dinner plans. We decided to hit up the The Buffet at ARIA. 

We walk up to the register and ask for a table, no reservation needed. Once we're settled and place our drink order, now its on. I walk around the entire facility and scan each station very carefully. My wife starts making a salad. That's great. I come back with a hunk of prime rib with a dash of horseradish as well as a kielbasa link.

That's it. (For the first plate)

My wife pushes her salad to the side. Ooooh! That looks good, can I taste? Sure! What's that, I tell her horseradish and she dips in. Now she's abandoned the salad and ran over to the carving station. 

After the meats, we hit up the crab legs. I don't like to get too crazy with crab legs, its a lot of work for little yield. They were pretty good regardless. There are many great items, from the Tandoori Chicken to the Italian station, The Buffet at ARIA has dinner down pat.

I was so full, I skipped breakfast the next day! The following day? Back to The Buffet at ARIA but this time for Breakfast. Fresh Salmon and cream cheese is how I started this buffet. Next, they make a Huuuuuuuuuuge pancake that is cooked perfectly. They cut off a square and serve it to the guests. Pretty ingenuous Aria. Then I had Eggs Benedict, a yogurt parfait and some coffee. I'm feeling pretty good! My wife had an egg white omelet with a bunch of healthy stuff mixed in. We both left stuffed but more importantly, the food being served was high quality. I didn't see any brown gravy with the skin on it. Everything was fresh and tasted great. 

The Buffet at ARIA, very impressed with both breakfast and lunch. Highly recommended

Ahhhhhh the famous Las Vegas buffet.....yeah doesn't exist here for me! I have had umpteen and I mean umpteen Las Vegas buffets at probably every hotel on the strip and the one at the Aria is truly forgettable. 

My first grouse....the long line...we waited for close to 45 minutes to get into the buffet and when we got inside....there were empty tables everywhere!! The ladies that were checking people in and collecting the money were painfully slow and were too busy talking on their cell phones. Plus inside the area is pretty disappointing...come on Aria spruce it up!!

My second grouse....food labeling....it is terrible! They have food sections and in a particular food section there will be a plaque telling you all the dishes that are available there. The problem is sometimes I don't know what dish is what....how about putting the label in front of the particular dish!!! Ain't that a brilliant idea!! Example....I picked up a type of salad thinking it was a potato salad....nope turned out it was tuna salad....now if they had just put the label in front of each dish...would have made my life much easier! 

Also I am not vegetarian but I noticed that the labeling made it very hard to tell, which dish was vegetarian or not. Example, it says vegetable fried rice....but its full of pork and beef...fabulous Aria!! You just ruined some poor vegetarian's day!!

My third grouse....food taste...overall not impressed. Yes I know its a buffet and I should not expect Michelin star rated food and to be honest I am not. But I do expect there to be flavor in the dishes and for them to taste different! I tried almost everything they had there and the best thing was the "vegetable fried rice" and the Parmesan bread....all of which I don't need to pay $25 bucks for!

My last grouse....variety....Las Vegas buffets are famous for their lavish spreads and variety in food. I felt a distinct lack of "lavishness" here. If you are going to do less than you had better make sure that the quality of the food is high. Unfortunately, Aria fails in both the variety and the taste department!

The servers were nice and the dessert bar was decent...but that's about it. So if you're looking for a Vegas buffet, don't come here, save your time, money and energy and walk yourself over to the Bellagio or Wynn yes it costs more but at least you leave feeling full, satisfied and happy!

Really good service here and they carry Coke products!  It seems that most other Vegas buffets only carry Pepsi. I was very impressed with the seafood selection here: cold snow crab legs cut in half, hot snow crab legs, and king crab legs! I cut my darn finger eating all the delicious crabs. Medic!

Not impressed at all. Very small selection compared to other buffets that I have been to in Vegas. The food looked like it had been sitting out for a while and tasted as bad as it looked. I love the dessert bars at buffets, if you are anything like me, prepare to be disappointed with their tiny selection of not so good tasting treats!! Overall, $40 is way overpriced for cafeteria food.

If I can best describe the Aria real estate, it would be a frigid fortress of modern and industrial lines.  With that, I surmise that its open floor-plan buffet dining room is aptly designed, resembling a mid-sized Silicon Valley tech company cafeteria or a strip mall's Todai.  This is not a compliment.

The food here mirrors the aesthetic; nothing stands out.  Everything is rigidly assembled without any artful flair similar to lesser off-strip buffets.  The seafood and meat selections here are dry, while the salad bar is just average.  This is made exponentially worse by the fact that the buffet items are limited.  

The stand-out section, however, is their dessert bar and gelato.  Though half of the pickings here are highly flawed to inedible, the other half may satisfy your sweet tooth to some extent.  

Though I have only been here twice, I must say that the wait and bus staff are friendly -- but, unfortunately, understaffed to be fully attentive.

Im not sure what to give this buffet...a mix between two and three stars...iits freakin pricey of course 20 day and 30 night. The food was many, but too much, clean bars, but the food wasn't very good. I;m not sure maybe cause I'm southern and Vegas taste is different, but the yogurt was sour and not good, maybe it was bad....the sausages were quite a feel to choose from, but all of them also tasted a bit sour and not like your usual mouthwatering ones...only the breakfast sausage was good, the bagles and cream chz were good, everything else wasn;t very tasty or satisfying. Thats all I can say....the service was okay as well, our waitress was ice, but the hosts, bar service, and cashiers sure didn;t seem off in a good feel. But they had a good diverse mix of food I suppose.

So good I went back three times.  Twice for breakfast, once for lunch.

The buffet at Aria is perhaps the best kept secret on the strip.  The variety of foods will satisfy even the most picky of eaters.

Yes, tons of shrimp, crab legs, sushi.. the usual you'd get at a buffet... but there's so much more.

The layout is comfortable and easy to get around and the ambiance is great.

Even if I don't stay at City Center next time (I probably will) I'll definitely make a special trip to the buffet at Aria.

First of all I think with any buffet it's smart to go right before the switch from lunch to dinner. 

I enjoyed the crab legs most ! I really liked the way they cut them so it was easy to eat. They looked sliced for you so you didn't have to do the hard work and have to crack them which was awesome  :) tasted great with the melted butter.

 I loved the curry chicken ! Really really good, flavor was perfect along with the Nann and Biryan rice 

The dessert was good, lots of gelato flavors. Carrot cake was good :)

Overall was memorable enough  to want to return for my future visits to Vegas :) and also next time I will make sure to not have a stomach full of Fat Tuesday slurpy right before coming here lol I think I could have enjoyed it more lol

Their buffet is Superior!

Let me start by saying its worth it's price if you are hungry or had a special or it's comped during your stay. The food \/ service are amazing, they steamed by iced seafood which made me smile. The crab legs come in half cut so no need to fight your way from the to the claw, just peel or fork it all up. Comes cold or steamed. They have all types of food from the seafood section to like a wheel of fortune ice-crew, the sliced beef was so juicy as well and always ask for an extra slice. If the line is long and your staying there, try to go through the sky suites line and charge to your room. A little perk to get inside as the other just sit and wait, tip your mimosa cup and carry on!

Amazing feature: all you can drink beer and cocktails (picture below) it's about $15 and to start your day go to the lunch buffet and come pre-game there!

A lot of options, some of the food was cold and old.  However, they have some great fresh seafood and a large dessert section.

We went at like 4pm in the afternoon and some of the food looked like it was sitting there for days.  I had to pass on a lot of the options.

I left disappointed!  Service was good though......

It's a pretty good buffet. Not the best - the Bellagio still holds that honor IMHO - but certainly up there. 

The crab legs were exceptionally good. Everything else was just "good". 

It costs about the same as the other high end buffets but in general is not as crowded. 

Bottom line: If you are here at meal time and want a buffet it's good. Not the best but certainly not bad.  Other than that there's really not much to say...

Ugh!!! Why or why did we go here? It is one of the worst buffets that we have been to and costs a ton. We were there over the holiday and paid about $110 since hubby got the unlimited drinks too.  Nothing was good except the pie my hubby had and their little glasses of salad. The oysters were not edible, crab legs weren't salted, the floor was covered in food and cloth napkins were on the ground next to our table! How busy are you to leave gross food and napkins on the floor. The staff was rude or just ignored you at the salad and carving stations. I heard some guy ask for the lamb that just came out and the carving guy told him no and that he could have the stuff that had been sitting there for a while. I was so shocked, I skipped getting anything from the carving station hoping someone new will come later.  If you hate your job, why not find another one. We will never never return! I was so disappointed that we will not return to Aria to even gamble or stay anymore! Too many other buffets and casinos that provide good service and food. Also, we gamble thousands per day and don't mind paying, but bad food and rude service, no thank you.

Great gourmet food for the money, and a really wonderful dessert selection.

The weekend dinner is a bit expensive - $38 \/ person which includes drinks, a small lobster, and endless king crab and snow crab legs.

If you arent crazy about drinks and lobsters, try weekday lunch which is about $25 and probably one of the best value buffet considering quality of the food.
Went there dinner 1\/31\/12.  They had the unlimited lobster tail for $70 special. Really liked their selection. Nice cocktail shrimps. Crab legs were already opened for easy eating. Good overall.

We saw all the mixed reviews and were a little hesitant, but we were pleasantly surprised.  The nan station was awesome. Seafood was pretty fresh. Overall everything was pretty good. The only thing that wasn't great was some of the desserts were really dry, like the coconut macaroons for example. The two whoopie pies were really good though.  I wanted to try the gelato but was too stuffed!

So my friends were staying at the Aria and we wanted to try their buffet out , not so good and they're overpriced by comparing to Spice market buffet because all the food is not tasty at all at the Aria buffet I didn't like it at all and my friends didn't like their food as well , well I just wanted to try it out , but never going back again
Clean, good service and decent selection. The price is not bad and they have prime rib and crab for lunch. The crab legs come sliced open so you don't have to do any cracking!

There was a long line for us to wait in to get in here so I had the assumption that it was going to be awesome.  For four of us it was $172 for our brunch adventure. 

There were many items to choose from and I really liked the fact that there were labeled sections to the buffet with foods from around the world.  As most buffets, the food wasn't 100% hot and simply plated\/displayed.  I think the shear number of options, it's worth checking out.  

The service was nice and she kept our drinks full and our food plates removed.  I can't even begin to list all of the food I had for that meal because I tried as much as I could.  Overall, everything was decent.

I just read in the Wall Street Journal that Aria has reduced their Buffet budget by $200,000.  This explains the drastic difference of the food quality from the opening week to months later.

http:\/\/online.wsj.com\/article\/SB10001424052702304879604575582253270407576.html?mod=WSJ_business_LeftSecondHighlights

It's an okay one, but overpriced. Went there the day before Christmas Eve, and paid about $50 for the dinner. The lamb was good. Steak and crab legs weren't bad. For desert, I liked their chocolate peanut butter cake. But the oysters were not fresh. I tried one only and I believe it gave me a stomachache. For $50 I would expect something fresh and won't make me sick.

I went to the Aria buffet for the first time last night.
I honestly can't comment on the price, as a friend paid for the dinner.

I was very impressed with the cleanliness of the place.  It was bright, and open, and very appealing.  

The server was polite when taking drink orders and clearing plates.

The selection was very impressive.  Curries, sushi, pizza, meats, and LOTS of seafood.

The quality of the food was standard buffet quality, except for the seafood.  I really didn't care for any of it.  The mahi mahi was cold...not even lukewarm, but cold.  The New Zealand mussels were chewy, and the seafood jambalaya was REALLY fishy.

I was very impressed with the fact that they have so many gluten free options.  Everything is well labeled, so there really isn't much guesswork.

My favorites of the night were the salad, the risotto, all the food at the Tandoori station (curries, etc), the chicken pot stickers, and the mac n cheese.
Now, I have to tell you..the pasta was WAY overcooked and it was kind of mushy, but that's how I like my "comfort food" style mac n cheese.  I actually went back for seconds.  

The desert station was huge, and beautiful.  I only had room for a bite or two of cheesecake but that was good too.

I probably would not go back, because I hear that its a fairly expensive buffet, and I'm cheap.  But if you have $30-$50, the quality of the food is pretty standard.
Disappointing buffet. Not worth it if you have to pay full price. Over $45 per person. For that price I should have gone to a sit down restaurant.

Aria's buffet is definitely one of the better buffets I've had on the strip :) 

On Fridays and Saturdays, the buffet comes with 1\/2 of a Maine lobster per person plus unlimited house white or red wine. Best way to fill up your belly and your drinking needs! 

Make sure you go with an empty tummy. The buffet line has a huge spread-- seafood, sushi, prime rib, pasta, pizza...and more. I have a sweet tooth so the their dessert section made me very happy--gelato, bananas foster, cheesecake and cream cakes...lets just say I was in heaven :) 

Initially the service was really slow. It took us a good 10 minutes to pay and to be seated. They only had a few hostesses working with a line of 50+. I felt really bad for our server who was basically waiting on half of the tables in the whole restaurant. But it was amazing to see how she memorized all the drinks that the table next to us ordered (let's just say they were a very demanding group). 

The food was fresh and very tasty. I would definitely go back on my next visit to Vegas!

Went for breakfast. Cheaper than eating in the cafe. Everything gluten free is labeled as such, amazing! Gluten free choices are basic though- eggs, bacon\/sausage, potatoes and fruit. Food was just ok.
Overwhelming in quantity, underwhelming in quality. Good variety. Definitely not worth 50 bucks :\/

Can be a pretty long wait for the lunch buffet, so plan accordingly. This is your standard Vegas buffet. A lot of food for cheap. Nothing really blew my mind but if you are looking to work off that hangover and not pay $30 for a burger at one of the casino eateries then this is the place for you.

$25 buffet for dinner with prime rib and king crab legs not bad! 

The prime rib, crab legs, and prawns were pretty much all I ate..Everything else is just mediocre. The "asian bar" is not well executed as EVERYTHING there tasted like soysauce. lol 

I'd be back for the fresh seafood: king & snow crab, prawns, and the prime rib...nom nom!!!

Review is for dinner buffet, 11\/1\/16
