As far as Vegas buffets, and I've been to ALOT of them, this ranks very high IMO for quality.  The price reflects that ($37), its about as expensive as they get.  But if you get comped, or a 2-for-1, or MyVegas reward then yeehaw, score!

I thought the asian stir fry dishes, compared to other buffets, were outstanding.  Ingredients like wood ear and gai lan, and several dim sum.  The hot\/sour soup was right on.  If you want REALLY good asian food then get your butt down to Spring Mountain Road, otherwise, its decent.

Some may say you 'cant screw up crab' but I disagree.  You surely can.  Go try the Paradise Seafood buffet and let me know, assuming you survive.  Aria serves whole legs (instead of ruining the meat by slicing them in half), and the legs were fairly meaty.  Theyre tasty.  And I had a bunch. I piled on a bunch of steamed clams and a few mussels.

The Prime Rib was fantastic.  Medium rare and tender.

Salad bar - check, good, lots of decisions to make.  

I'll admit I passed on the Indian fare and the pasta.  I filled up with crab and prime rib :)

Our server, from Nigeria, was friendly and attentive, took good care of our drink needs.  Coffee nice and strong.

While other reviewers poo-poo the dessert array, I thought it was one of the best I've seen at a Vegas buffet, reminded me of the old Palatium Buffet at Caesars.  EVERYTHING i tried was delicious.  Burnt cream, cheese cake, black forest cake, a scrumptious white choc chip cookie, coconut ice cream (or was it gelato? I dont know).  

The clientele here, generally well dressed - so I wouldnt show up in gym shorts\/t-shirts.

For a buffet, I think they've executed it pretty well, far better than most, so by comparison to other buffets it gets 4 stars.  I hope next time I go to Vegas its still a MyVegas reward!
Great selection of food, prime rib outstanding. Only negative you have to pay for your drinks at the table before you get them.

Wow!  For everyone that wants the best gluten free selection, highest quality, best service, best tasting food, freshest food, special treatment, reasonable customizations, there's no better place then here!!!!  We love close to Vegas, and we've tried a lot of buffets, and this one truly is unlike and far above all the others.  Wynn was good, but this is unbelievable everything!  Must try it, and you'll come again and again.  Enjoy fellow buffetiers.

This is one of the top buffers on the strip with a great selection of cuisines.  The seafood was good and they had a great selection.  The carving station is good as well.  Service and ambiance were good.  The dessert station is also particularly good.

The Buffet at Aria is my second favorite buffet in Vegas, after Wicked Spoon at Cosmo. Aria is also much cheaper than Wicked Spoon, so it's the buffet I like to go to when I do not want to splurge. 

The atmosphere is very clean and open, with plenty of comfortable seating. The servers were so wonderful the past two times I have been there, always filling up beverages and having the greatest attitude while dealing with so many people at once. You also never feel rushed to finish your food and leave, the service is so great. The sangria (red and white) is so good here, I still have dreams about it. 

The food is solid quality and they have many vegetarian options (compared the Buffet at Bellagio, which had slim pickings for vegetarians). They had tofu marsala, miso soup, and your traditional breakfast items, like pancakes, waffles, and potatoes. Also, the man who works in the dessert section was so personable and knowledgable, it's so nice interacting with people who have such a great attitude. 

I just really love everything about this buffet. The drinks are yummy, the food is solid, and the service is fantastic. The Buffet at Aria will always be my go-to buffet when I don't want to splurge at Wicked Spoon.

This buffet was sad times considering the other fabulous buffets in Vegas.  Really, they're kinda in a hidden type area of the Aria, so maybe they're hiding out and when someone stumbles upon it they think, oh well, I don't know where I am anyway so let's just go in!

I love me a buffet, so going out to Vegas is exciting because it's like buffet country.  I barely picked up anything in my graze of the stations.  Nothing really looked that appetizing.  It's definitely a smallish buffet, but I'd still think quality over quantity for the mola you're shelling out.  

The only good thing was the dessert bar.  I always enjoy a soft chocolate chip cookie and brownie.  So that kinda made things better, but not really.  If you stumble upon this place and you haven't eaten in days and you're starving it would be fine.  If you have the time to meander to anther... I'd pick that option!
This is the best breakfast buffet I have ever had! The food is excellent and they have so many different types of food to satisfy any cravings. Would highly recommend.

Since I was staying in the hotel we had a $25 credit to use anywhere in the hotel. Why not spend it on an expensive dinner. I came in a group of about 8 people. They ended up splitting us up almost across the buffet since we didn't want to pay an extra 18%. I can see maybe like the next table over or even across the section but whatever, they had their rules. 

I must say that the spread was one of the biggest I've seen. They literally had food from all over the world! French, Mediterranean, Italian, Chinese, Mexican... They had a salad area with different types of leaves and tons of toppings. A seafood bar with crab legs, ceviche, and oysters. But the best part of any buffet, the desserts! And boy was it pretty! They had this ice cream wheel, yes I know let me explain! Think wheel of fortune but with flavors. Pick your flavor and the lady scooping will spin the wheel until it comes to your ice cream. They also had mini cupcakes, whoppie pies, cake pops, and the regular stuff like cakes and cookies. 

I wouldnt say that the food was out of this world. Frankly a lot of it just tasted like mass produced buffet food would. But the variety, cleanliness, and pleasant drink staff makes me want to come back. 

Two adult dinners came out to be about $85. If you want to add bottomless beer its and extra $12.

My family and I love coming to this buffet. There's never a super long line to the entrance and this buffet also has a locals' discount. This buffet is pretty big and has a wide variety of foods (Asian, Mediterranean, Carvery, Mexican, Italian, etc.). There is also a tiny section categorized as a Children's Table. 

The Carvery section has lamb chops!! Other buffets at this price usually just have 2-3 types of meat to offer. They sometimes only give you 2 pieces at a time though, depending on how busy they are.

They have a large section for their seafood - sushi, baked seafood, shrimp, mussels, etc. The crab legs taste amazing and the cold crab legs are usually already broken in half so it's easy to get the meat. Unfortunately, the crawfish wasn't that good and didn't taste fresh. I have yet to find a buffet in Vegas that has quality oysters - this buffet is a hit or miss with their oysters. Tonight, it was a miss.

If you're going to make your own pho, definitely take advantage of the extra toppings that they have right next to it. The broth is very bland.

Lastly, desserts. My favorites are the crème brûlée, flan, fruity pebble rice krispies, and the ice cream. They also have mochi ice cream too! I wish I wasn't so full already so I could have tried more desserts.

I'm really quite picky, someone who doesn't mind paying for great food, and generally not a fan of buffets as quantity usually trumps quality. I am also not the type of person that can eat enough to make the price of a buffet worth while.  Despite this, my husband and I ate at the Aria buffet when we stayed with them a few years ago and it has been the only time I've felt like the food was worth the price of admission, so to speak. I returned to the Aria again, in fact I'm still here, and I visited the buffet again today for lunch around 2pm (they close for lunch at 3pm although they were still seating people around that time). I do not know why it has such a low rating, but I can only assume that the negative comments are the result of circumstances that are the exception rather than the rule. 

The restaurant is very clean, the rest rooms were also clean. If you eat here when there's a 1\/2 hour wait or more, I'm sure you will find things a bit less put together simply because of volume and the nature of a buffet. Our server, whose name I regretfully forget, was wonderful and attentive even at the end of her shift.  She even offered to make me a cherry coke and it was perfect.  Everything was available, it was all fresh and tasted quite good. Crab legs were refilled often and continued to be filled until we left around 3pm even though they are supposed to be turning over for dinner. The fresh fruit is also great quality and delicious right now. They continue to have a nice selection of deserts and the crème brûlée was good, perhaps not quite as delicate as a gourmet pastry chef might prepare it but the flavor was lovely.  No, they do not have the biggest selection I've ever seen, but bigger selections don't necessarily mean better. There's something for everyone here and I know I'd rather have them focus on quality over quantity.  

Prices vary depending on time of day (breakfast\/lunch vs dinner) and day of the week (mon-thurs vs fri-sun).  The best price available will be for breakfast\/lunch mon-thurs, but you can earn 2 for 1 buffet vouchers by playing MGM's My Vegas apps and earning loyalty points towards rewards such as this one. You can also redeem these points for a single free buffet. So, I heartily recommend this buffet and I look forward to going back for dinner before we leave.

Creme brulee at 11am. Yes.

I was really pleased with the Aria Buffet as a whole. On a Sunday morning, the line wasn't ridiculous and we were seated within 10 minutes of walking up. The presentation for the chicken and waffles was beautiful. There was a little fry basket lined with paper and it had mini waffles and chicken tenders\/nuggets inside. Perfectly portioned and cute to boot. Did I mention the dessert station?

Minus a star for some food looking like it needed to be stirred. Also the person who is responsible for writing the food names on the signs needs an English class desperately.  Maybe it was purposeful, but I don't think so.

just to list off some things:

- great selection of food
- not just great selection, but great quality for a buffet
- great atmosphere and design. very contemporary.
- attentive wait staff. people say that it wasn't as good, but our waitress was very observant of our table. drinks were refilled, and plates were removed with perfect timing.
- DESSERT IS AMAZING! i love the coconut tapioca pudding shooter with candied mangoes. haha.

overall verdict: yes, YOU should try this buffet. if you like it, GREAT! if you don't, you can at least say that you've tried aria's buffet, and YOU can write a review on how much you don't like it. haha. enjoy!

The food was AMAZING here.  The crab legs were so good, their Mexican station was great, the seafood station was so good. The Fried chicken was very good. Your going to be spending about $40 on the weekend and about $25 during the weekdays. $12.99 for unlimited wine, and beer. The only negative thing is that the service was slow and removing the dirty plates from the table and getting your actual drinks. The actual servers weren't to friendly which can make it weird at times, but who cares food was great. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.
The breakfast buffet was amazing! I fell in love with their portugese sausage and some raw oatmeal type dish that had berries and banana! It was less than $20!

Really, Yelpers?  Two and a half stars for this place?  I think that's a bit harsh.

Despite the horrific reviews for The Buffet at Aria, our group had to test out this new buffet for ourselves.  We walked in with virtually little to no expectations and were pleasantly surprised.

Because it was lunch (about $18) on a Monday, the buffet was not crowded, and we were seated prompty.  Everything was spic and span clean, and service was very friendly and welcoming.  The food choices, although not as plentiful as, say, the buffets at Wynn or Bellago, were not bad at all.  And the desserts were especially appealing in presentation and the majority also in taste.

Having visited various buffets on the Las Vegas strip, I really think this one is getting a lot more flak than it deserves.  Nice atmosphere, good service and food, reasonably priced.  Solid four stars in my book.

I've actually been coming here for a few years even before I finally moved to Vegas, so I've seen the minor changes they've had over the years. I think it is about time to write a review.

Parking - MGM properties rolled out their paid parking. It's annoying but I guess there's not much I can do about it. I wish they could validate for eating there or something but anyway..

Came here on a Fri night around 6:30pm, there was no line to get in but the place was only around 40-50% capacity which was actually kind of surprising - as it's usually even less than that during peak hours. 

Our server was Maryann, she was wonderful to deal with. She always came by every several minutes to check on us and was very friendly. 

As far as food selection\/quality compared to the other resorts, this place is probably closer to a 3.5 star. The other 0.5 star they earned from me is from the good service we've consistently had. 

The good-if you come fri-sun for dinner, they usually have king crab legs and oysters. Quality is generally acceptable as long as you don't come too late in the day. The meat carving section is also usually pretty good - definitely get the prime rib if you're a fan. 

Worth a try-I always find myself eating the Indian food- the naan bread, tandoori chicken and the curries always find their way to my plate. Their dessert section is small compared other buffets but still acceptable. They have their famous spinning wheel of gelato\/ice cream as well as little different cakes and such. I usually find myself ending the meal with a cake pop and some coffee. 

The not so good-the Asian food is a joke. I'm sorry. The "sushi".. Is very sad looking. The fruit selection is almost non existent. The cheeses look like they've been out for too long and the pizzas are always kinda dried up.  They used to grill large shrimps and scallops in the middle but I think they pulled the plug on that. 

In summary, come here for the king crab legs and oysters on the weekend if that's what you're into.  Or if you like to sample little bits of each kind of cuisine.  If it's not your thing then I suggest you go somewhere else.

ok note to buffet eaters in Vegas.. if you're worried about the hefty price tag going during lunch! its cheaper

and now proceeding to the food (which really deserves 3.5 stars)
King Crab Legs (i piled my plate high with such high expectations, they over salted so that you limited what you ate - fail)
Roast - cooked to perfection
Sushi\/Sashimi - decent considering it was a buffet
Grilled Shrimp - devoured.. inhaled really..
Ceviche - really refreshing, clean flavors
Desserts - ALL AMAZING!

decor was interesting, plenty of seating, a bit of a wait but wasn't terrible (20 minutes?) average cost for a buffet in Vegas, but well worth it!

We were here last Friday night for the Gourmet dinner. Everything was really delicious!!!! The night before we went to Bellagio buffet which was okay but the line was over an hour. Aria had no line wait which is surprising considering it was way better than Bellagio. The buffet had unlimited lamb chops and delicious Macaron cookies which is worth the money right there. In addition, it had make your own pasta station and delicious prime rib\/ cowboy steak. The crab legs were also a lot better than Bellagio.

Our plan was to head to Lotus of Siam and on our way there, we found out that they were closed on weekdays between 2:30 - 5 pm. Damn. While heading back to the strip, we found out that Wicked Spoon was also closed between 2:30 - 5 pm and we passed on spending $60 each for Bacchanal. Instead we found ourselves back at Aria and decided to give the Buffet at Aria a try.

We missed the lunch cut-off at 3 pm by 20 minutes, so we paid the dinner price at $37.99 per head. The buffet's food area is not as comprehensive as Bacchanal, but still offered plenty of selection for indulging. If looking from left to right, they have Sweets, Asian, Italian, Pizza, Mediterranean, Tandoori, Latin, Carvery, and Diner. Two islands in the middle of it all have the Fish Market and Salad. I was pleasantly surprised with the seafood variety available: steamed crab legs, peelable shrimp, clams, mussels, seared ahi tuna, cooked salmon, seafood paella, sushi, and more. I was also pleasantly surprised that they have Coke Zero available from their offerings of Coke drink products!

Other than the seafood, I filled up on prime rib (so yummy with fresh horseradish too!), creamed corn, mac and cheese, and spinach dip. If you stop by the Salad area, they have fresh fruit juice and thai tea ready for dispensing. At the end of the meal, I was slightly disappointed with their desserts. While I enjoyed the oreo whoopie pie, tiramisu cup, cookies and Merlyn Monroe popcorn (white chocolate drizzled popcorn), their gelato and ice cream flavors were just okay. I usually like to end with a fruit sorbet, but they only had coconut and mandarin yuzu. Coconut - I'm allergic to, and mandarin yuzu - super tart. BF got the cherry cola and pistachio and loved the pistachio one so much - definitely get the pistachio if you can!

No discounts for Mlife members, but show your Mlife card to rack up points.

One of the worst buffet in vegas, rode staff, for just one glass of water you need to wait more than 10 minutes. I was waiting for waitress to bring me spoon and fork for 15 minutes. Lastly I asked to meet manager. Then brought me that. Don't get there it is the worst buffet ever I have got.  When we wanted to leave, staff asked for tip.

Brunch was EXPENSIVE. 30 something a person. For that much money I'm expecting food to be refilled quickly. I finished the last two eggs Benedict which was delicious, but then they stopped making more! Ugh disappointed! Other than that, brunch options were fair, although mediocre for the price. The dessert baked treats and the gelato wheel was a highlight. Very clean eating \/ serving areas. Probably won't come back for a brunch.

I was with family 8-1-16 about 6pm  they serve old sushi. I told manager she say nothing wrong. rice was almost uncook.  came out from freezer bite.
winn buffet was very good.

The lunch buffet is really great! 

They have a large selection of seafood, from crab legs, clams, prawns, mussels, and much more. They even have the options of hot and cold, where you get the traditional seafood cold on ice or cooked in awesome sauces, still warm. Either way, both are fresh and delicious. 

They had a lot of different stations:
-meat carving station with selections of chicken, prime rib, and sausage
-a make your own taco and nacho station with choice of cheese, sour cream, pico de gallo, guacamole, salsa roja, salsa verde, etc
-Asian station with fried rice, soups, dim sum, general tsao's chicken, and more
-cheese station with crackers and meats
-small sushi station

I think the best part of the buffet was the dessert. They have a spinning gelato bar, with flavors like coffee, vanilla, peanut butter, Thai tea, and more. The cookies, brownies, cannolis, whoopie pies, and cake pops...everything was good! 

Service wasn't an issue for our group. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive to when we needed more drinks or to clear our plates when we were done. 

Will definitely come back just for the seafood and dessert!

The buffet at Aria, although revamped, is mediocre.  We got in at about 3:15 p.m. on the lunch price for dinner.  Since it was Christmas Day, the holiday brunch buffet items like scrambled eggs, eggs benedict were still on the buffet at 3:30 p.m.  The items were slowly changed.  Not worth the money.

Since I spent my last trip in Vegas staying at the Aria, I figured I might as well check out their buffet for dinner one night.  Overall, there is not much to say- it was a good buffet, but for Vegas it seemed pretty standard and was nothing special (note: I did go on a Monday night and have heard that weekends might be better).

For the most part, the food I had was good.  I spent most of my time downing roast beef, shrimp, and snow crab legs.  I also tried a variety of pastas, pizzas and other dishes.  But again, although all of it was good and tasty, none of it was special enough to say it was really amazing.  

On the service side of things, the wait staff was a little slow at first, but as the meal went on it seemed to pick up a bit, so I'm not sure there's really anything to complain about.

In essence, the Aria buffet was simply unremarkable.  I don't really have anything bad to say, but I don't really have anything good to say either.  In Vegas, I would expect better.

We came during brunch and was immediately seated. Customer service was ok, but they kind of slow with cleaning up the dirty plates at our table.

Buffet lacked a bit of variety, however their desserts were delicious. I also really enjoyed their sushi station as well and their lemon grass chicken (tom yum) soup.

There are so many buffet restaurants in Vegas.  However, I highly recommend the Buffet at Aria. It is high price but definitely worth it.  Why settle at other buffet locations with most of the food choices you won't even eat.  At the buffet, choice of the food is not many as other buffet locations in Vegas but all good foods.  One of the best buffet restaurants in Vegas if you want to eat buffet.  I normally don't eat buffet but this is the place.

We weren't sure if we wanted to try Arias Sunday Brunch when we love the Bellagio's buffet so much, but decided to try since we loved our stay at Aria.

The Yelp's were all over the place so wasn't sure what to believe.

Here is the real deal:
Perspective: Bellagio's brunch buffet is 5x better. Wynn is 2x better.Paris is about the same.

Aria's was good but not even close. Less selection, less variety, not glamorous looking, etc. For example, the cheese area consisted of 2, yes, 2 kinds of cheese...Swiss and Cheddar...really??

Granted, there was ethnic variety with Indian, Chinese, Mediterranean, etc. but it felt more like a buffet at a Marriott than Sunday brunch in Vegas.

came here this weekend after they had renovated and it has only gotten better since last time we came here.  This is buy far the best buffet on the strip.  We were here 2.5 hrs eating alof of good crab all kinds  and other seafood as well as meats and many other things especally deserts, they had my jusbands two favorite gelatos, orange shebert and mint and chip.  The food here never disappoints.  Will for sure be back here the next time we are in town and will have to try the brunch buffer here as well.

Let's make this review short and not-so-sweet.

There were literally bugs in the salad (more than one).  Food ALL OVER the ground - it was filthy.

When we complained to the manager there, he offered us $5.  We couldn't even get to the real food stations because of the filth, and he offered one person $5, not each of us.  Wow.

I've heard this place has sanitary issues from a couple others as well.  Not cool!

Alaskan king crab legs- YUMMY! You will eat a lot. Don't forget to ask them to steam them for you. Trust me on this, you can eat twice as much if it's warm and right. 

Desserts- EXCELLENT. They taste as pretty as they look, which is rare. Said to be made by Jean-Phillipe or someone who has an attractive bakery within the hotel as well. 

Prime rib- good. Cooked perfectly to taste perfect. 

Service- waiter wasn't so friendly, but I guess he got the job done?

HINT: Alaskan king crab legs only for weekday and weekend dinners. Jumbo snow crab legs served during both.
Now serving brunch instead of lunch. Wad here few months ago for lunch it was so good. Came back the other day and the choices wete not as great anymore. Wont be back.
I havent been very impressed with this places.  If you are looking to spend this type of money just go to a great steak house dont waste your time or money.
Pretty weak. Food is very bland. Selections are not nearly as good as at The Cosmopolitan or others. $27 brunch.

For a buffet, this recently renovated spot is very good. We liked the wide variety of foods (dim sum, sushi, Indian, gelato, fresh seafood, soups, Chinese, meats, and more). Some of the food wasn't stellar, but some really was outstanding. I found the best tandoori chicken ever, fresh from the oven, moist and flavorful. Fresh, chewy naan was an unusual thing to see on a buffet and very welcome. Great prime rib and au jus. Great seafood. Soooo many choices! 

Lovely desserts; we found the less spectacular-looking things tasted better than many of the beautifully composed desserts. I loved the gelato.

This was a good step or two above the Bellagio buffet, which surprised us.

I wasn't disappointed. 1\/2 lobster comes with the buffet. Crab legs are cut lengthwise for easy access. Dessert bar is amazing. Wine is complementary. I haven't been to many buffets, so I guess I'm not that picky. Definitely got my money's worth.

SERIOUSLY not worth your time (went for lunch, $25).

It's like a really shitty college cafeteria (with no hot college girls and middle America in their place).

We all agreed everything we had in there was sub-par at best. I was too sketched out to eat the fish. The hashbrowns tasted microwaved, the bread was gross, the breakfast burritos were legit from TBell (red tortilla), etc. etc. The Ice cream\/gelato was the best thing they had. In fact, if you like all you can eat ice cream\/gelato, I'd check it out. 

In my opinion you might as well spend $10-15 more for the EPICness which is the Wynn buffet.

I felt ripped off, even though we had a voucher for $33 off per person from our hotel. It just wasn't very appealing. We came for dinner, and the crab legs everyone talks about just weren't enough to overcome the profound sense of meh that I experienced surveying the other options. The sushi was meh, the pizza was meh, the Indian food was meh, the gnocchi was meh... I could go on. But I won't. Because this buffet isn't even worth the time for an extended review.

Went for breakfast on a Monday morning after staying the night at Aria.  

The good..Nice layout, located on the 2nd floor promenade, and it was reasonably priced (if you like the food)

The not so-bad..It's not as big as the other Vegas buffets I've tried.  

Let's get to the ugly.. How can you screw up breakfast?!? Cold potatoes and eggs. Eggs benedict with no hollandaise, tasteless dim sum choices, dry waffles and pancakes, and the sausages.. ugh.  Seemed like we tried it all, and all were FAIL.  I felt a little guilty that I've wasted all that food.  But, my taste buds were not having any of it.  We ended up eating a pastry and gelato for breakfast.  A $30 meal for pastry and gelato.  Might as well just have gone to Jean-Phillippe.

Chinese New Year buffet cost about $40 and was worth at best $10. Seriously this was the worst breakfast I have ever had. The pancakes were dyed red and looked unappealing. The omlet was meh and while the wait staff was fantastic the food servers\/cooks were not remotely friendly or helpful. Perhaps because I am not a meat eater I did not find many things to eat to but my dining companion who is a meat eater also found the food to be sub par at best. Perhaps there are better meals throughout the day but a breakfast buffet should at the very least be tasty particularly at the price point.

I went for the dinner buffet on a Wednesday night. I liked that there was no line, it wasn't crowded, and the food was fresh.

All of the beef dishes were stand outs:

- Prime Rib
- Beef Fajitas
- Mongolian Beef

They were all really tender and well cooked (not overdone). Everything else was solidly good. The home-made ice cream was the best thing in the dessert section. They were a little light on options in that department.

Great crab legs. Awesome waitress she had our drinks out before we finished the other.  I didn't think the food was that great for the price you pay. The pizza sucks. The or meat is pretty good. The other selections just are not that great and lack a little flavor. I do give 3 stars just for the service

Beaufriend and I went to this buffet wanting to try something new. Oh man, what a waste of $$! Buffet has very little selection of food! Panda Express has better selection and better tasting food than the Asian food they have laying out in this buffet. Italian food section-they only have fettuccine alfredo that looked like no one has touched. They also have 2-3 diff kind of pizza. Poor guy behind the make your own pasta station looked like he's begging people to make him cook for you. His station looked so plain that you won't even really notice him there. Dessert area, from what most of the reviews I've read..I really thought they would have a lot of selection! Wrong! I guess comparing it to the Wynn buffet...The Buffet at Aria is nothing! 

Maybe the only good thing they have here is that they serve Indian food which you don't normally see in buffets. Also, they have good size shrimp cocktails. 

The Buffet at Aria...never again. Sorry.

So this is the new Hotel in town, so you know that means, this is the new hot spot buffet. It's 38 a person for dinner which is pretty cheap for what they advertised, unlimited wine and a whole Maine lobster. First off the wine was blah. And they were super strict on the serving of the Maine lobster. It was 1 per person and they triple check to make sure you haven't already gotten one. With all of the scrutiny I figure it would be a decent presentation of the lobster. NOPE! Just boiled. It had no flavor. Also it didn't arrive until almost the end of the meal even though we requested it at as soon as we sat down. I started down the buffet line and first things first it was king crab legs, pre split. Which was a definite plus since the spines on the king crab legs are a pain to fight through. They were always low on them and I didn't feel like waiting for more in that terribly long line. I tasted almost all of the other items and it was nothing amazing. The best dish was the lobster ravioli. I did have 2 plates of that. 

The service was terrible, the waitress looked pissed off and barely ever cleared our plates and instead of refilling drinks she just brought out new ones, but she only did that once. 

Recommendation, come for an early dinner to avoid the crowds, stick to the king crab legs and lobster ravioli.

Worst buffet in Las Vegas !
Worst service and very pricey!
Do not go pleeeeaaase!
Over price reheated food.Chinese food was discusting. In general Horrible and not worst the time and money!

Was told if I want crab legs Aria had the best bang for your buck.  I have a hard time paying $40-50 for a dinner buffet when I mainly just want unlimited crab legs.  Found out Aria puts out crab legs for lunch which sold us.  Why pay $40-50 when you can pay $25 instead.  We got there at 2:30 and the menu didn't change when they had dinner switch over so we saved some money by going a little early.  The prime rib was excellent as well. The shrimp and grits was the surprise hit with me.  If looking for a nice buffet I recommend Aria but I also hear there are a couple other good ones as well.  The only thing I would say that should be better is the desserts.  They all look great but just wasn't super impressed with that section.  But let's be honest I come for the main dishes not the dessert and Aria didn't disappoint.

I am not a seasoned Vegas veteran (in contrast to poster below), so perhaps my expectations are too high.

 I went on Sunday, so was either lunch or brunch.  30 minute wait to get in at 11:30AM..  I did not like this at all, but wanted to see the buffet..  taken to table and ambience is basically a big cafeteria. Food is not presented well, served from "windows" cut out of a wall.. very cafeteria like.  Many tables are empty.. which I take means Aria staff pace the line vs. over-stuffing the buffet line.

Biggest line was for the crab legs.  I am not a crab connosseir but I enjoyed them.  They are served cold\/ice with lime\/lemons vs. hot\/steamed.  Breakfast burrito, believe it or not, was very good.  So was the thick sliced bacon (a very nice touch).  Hash browns were bland, dry, bricks.  Omelette station was there.  Eggs benedict too too buttery, but otherwise nicely done.  Desserts were very good.  I wish i tried to eat more in retrospect.   I was offput by the presentation I guess.. I assumed the chinese food was not going to be good until I read these reviews... 

Server bought OJ and bloody mary's often and cleared plates quickly and really did try hard.  I am glad I tipped the full 20% before being seated.. I would have not liked tipping 20% and then being left thirsty etc. or with dirty plates laying around.

I was very impressed with the buffet at Aria. Great variety of ethnic foods. I especially liked the Sunday brunch buffet, great variety of breakfast items, all their pancakes are delicious, they had about 3 different kinds. Everything is so fresh and yummy. Of the desserts, the bread pudding was by far the best. Only thing I wasn't so impressed by was the service, but ultimately didn't matter too much in a buffet setting.

I had Thanksgiving dinner here with family and friends. I was a little worried about coming here with all the "not so good  reviews" on yelp but,  it was actually good.  REAL good. Prime rib was tender and juicy, crab leg was on the small side but, its ayce. turkey was juicy and not dry, ham was wonderful, sushi was fresh, especially the salmon and tuna rolls. They also had a good variety of desserts and gelato. Thier Har Gow and Siu Mi was pretty tasty. Service was awesome, my plates were gone by the time I came back with my seconds and thirds.  The seven of us came out to $399 and our group was abt 25 people, Kids were regular price, no discount or half price.  I woulda given them 5 stars if they were in the low to mid $40's and kid half price and not $57 p\/p tax and tip included but, it was still worth it especially when some1 in our group had VIP status and we waited less than 15 mins and bypassed 200-300 people..

I cannot believe Aria Buffet is priced at a whopping $30++ per person for a cafeteria style establishment [ formica tables with very basic chairs]. I was almost tempted to walk out once I had viewed their food displays or lack thereof, but held off because my husband and I were rather hungry and we had paid already. There was no line, but now we know why. In the hopes of making the buffet look modern\/minimalistic, they have made the whole place look cheap and nasty with orange color everywhere, making the overall look similar to a school cafeteria. The food was less than desirable, aside maybe from the roast beef. The dim sum was a very poor rendition of the real Chinese treat and the Indian chicken Korma was rather lacking in spice and taste. The sushi suffered from lack of any particular taste, along with the smoked salmon and prawns. My Husband tried the sausages and said these were tough and fatty. The pizza was little better than a flatbread with a few pepperoni slices as topping. Desserts were okay I suppose, although I was looking for some sugar free varieties but found there were just 2 types of muffin on display. Ice cream looked okay with a good selection. On the plus side, our waitress was very pleasant and supplied our ice teas very quickly. For $30 ++ We could have gone to the Wynn and had a beautiful brunch, in superb surroundings with food trays being changed every 15 minutes or so. Yes, we possibly would have to wait a few minutes, but well worth the wait. A definite NO-NO to the ARIA BUFFET. Don't waste your time or your money on this mediocre café.

I am surprised that this buffet is not rated better because I really liked it. The seafood was outstanding: shrimp and mussels so fresh you can't stop eating. The crab legs were less impressive, but good enough for a buffet. The bottomless drinks were also pretty fantastic - I've had sangria and a mimosa, my husband had a bloody mary and a beer - and both food and drinks were relatively inexpensive. Last but not least: the dessert selection was fabulous. I still relive the caramel flan...

The biggest problem with this buffet was that it took some time to get in: long line at the door even though it appeared half empty inside.

Other than that, highly recommend: it's worth your time and money.

Went for lunch and had naan, masala, crab legs, crab claws, banana foster dessert, thai iced tea. The price was reasonable for lunch for the quality of food. The attendants were attentive and friendly.

Selection was great and the quality of the food was excellent. Service was a little slow but overall it was an enjoyable experience that was worth the money.  After going to other buffets I found that this was definitely one of the better ones in comparison.

My husband and I did the Aria buffet for breakfast. The cost was $14.99 per person. There are cheaper breakfast buffets out there, but I think we got our money's worth. 

The ham was so moist and tender, and the bacon was crisp. I loved the smoked fish section...three different kinds in addition to anchovies. Delicious! 

There were about 5 different flavors of cream cheese. Many buffets just serve those little prepackaged Philly cream cheese containers. I had the cream cheese with chives on my bagel with smoked salmon and capers. Wonderful. 

They had a section of pizza...even a breakfast pizza with breakfast sausage and egg. I didn't eat the pizza, but it looked like it was a popular option with many guests. 

There was an omelet station and a good selection of fruit. The orange juice did not taste fresh-squeezed, but the coffee was tasty. 

We also enjoyed the selection of coffee cakes and muffins. Good stuff. 

We'll definitely go back.

This is a 3.5 star review that leans 4... it's it pricey? Yes,  is there a few flaws? Yup. That said We were happy with the food and there's allot of options to choose from. Omelet station was good and bacon was crispy which is rare at a buffet in my experience. Would i go here again? I'm not sure but I'm glad we tried it once

I came here for Sunday Brunch before heading back to Cali after a great weekend. This buffet was a total buzz kill. 

So... if there was a "0" star option, I would've picked that and still commented that there needs to be a negative star rating. 

This was hands down the worst buffet experience ever. I cant believe they even got away with labeling this a buffet, especially in such an upper scale hotel. 

First off, they advertise themselves as being the Crab Leg central of Las Vegas. If by "crab leg," they mean "cold small crab fingers\/slivers," then yes, this is your place. 

Second, the rest of the buffet was mismatched, random and clearly lacking in any menu planning whatsoever.  You would have a carving station with lamb (no prime rib on the Sunday Brunch Menu, go figure), then next to it, you would have enchiladas, then scrambled eggs. Nothing made sense. 

The decor was lack luster, sterile and looked like a hospital cafeteria. This place makes Hometown Buffet look like the Four Seasons. 

The only thing good about this place was.... well. yea. nothing. I want my money back.

I used my 2 for 1 lunch reward from MyVegas slots, so I went in for a Cheaper price! I've been here multiple times and this buffet is pretty much average. There's nothing really good (except the flan) and there's nothing really bad. It has all the standard stations that you'd expect from a Vegas buffet, just without the premier foods. 

I got my money's worth from eating endless snow crab that was already cut in half so it was time efficient! They have normal crab claws, but it takes too much time to open it. If you're one of those people who say " but there's more meat in the claws" think again. Although you might be right, you can eat the crab meat a lot faster from the ones that are already cut open than taking time to open the crab claws. Thus resulting in more meat! 

The service here seemed to have died.. I remember having great service last year with constant refills and check ups. Now you have to chase down someone just for more napkins.. 

Despite the fall in service and quality of food, I would probably come back again just for the crab and the flan. 

P.s. I've had Caesars, Bellagio's and this buffet all in one stay, and the flan is the best here! It's a must have compares to others.

I wasn't really expecting much, especially after being a bit disappointed in the Bellagio buffet, but I liked the selection, the service, and the quality here.  Breakfast is fantastic, coffee refilled often (and it's a great breakfast blend flavor), the mango chicken sausage is fantastic, lox, Benedicts, Nutella red velvet pancakes,  fruit, salads, sushi, steamed bbq pork buns,  ... if you can't find something here to hit the spot for you, well, you might be too picky. And having the two free buffet ($100 equivalent) per night was a fabulous perk!

Two things to note about my rating.  First, it's a rating acknowledging this is a buffet.  Second, we went to the breakfast buffet.

Aria's breakfast buffet is one of the few buffets worth visiting.  Lots of great options with many unusual offerings (like a variety of humus or red-velvet pancakes).  Had crab claws that were very good.  I shelled a bunch for my friend.  And if you're looking for something really good, have them make you a crab omelet.

After my slightly traumatic experience at Buffet of Buffets, I was really hesitant about going the The Buffet at Aria.  But all my friends were going, what was I supposed to do?

I was actually pleasantly surprised by this place.  The food was very good!  And for $25, not too bad for brunch.

Favorites:
-Fresh cut slab of honey bacon
-Steamed King Crab Legs with Hot Butter
-Jumbo Cocktail Shrimp that were fresh not frozen.
-Flan 
-Chicken Congee
-High quality green tea

Negatives:
-Servers seemed to hate their job and were really slow and inaccurate about bringing you things like drinks.
-Duck salad was so salty it was inedible.
-Not enough room in my tummy for seconds after I had tried everything.

My gosh you failed me. Lunch and Dinner sucks. Overcooked fish, meats and mushy grilled veggies :(

Its only been 6 months since I visited, what happened?? It was recommended over Wicked Spoon and boy was it correct 6months ago. Not sure about know. Go off of recent reviews because these place can go down hill in just a couple months.

A plus, the restroom is in the same section as the buffet area. No need to exist and come back. And so far I haven't experienced any lines or wait. But some servers are pretty disgruntled here.

Good food. Lots of choices. Kind of pricey at $25 for a lunch Buffett. Nonetheless if you are looking for a decent buffet, check this place out. At the same time, you could get a great meal for the same price at a restaurant.
I visited 4 buffet's while in Vegas and this one was THE BEST one! Sadly, I went the day before I was to leave, cause I definitely would have gone back if I had more time. I will be back next year!

Do NOT believe the 5 start reviews, or you WILL be dissapointed! This buffet is mediocre at best!

How could such an exceptional hotel like Aria have such a mediocre buffet? It just doesn't match up. I'm 50 years old, and I've probably been to over 50 buffets. I just don't understand how could anyone give this place 4 or 5 stars?

If you want details, here's what I did and did not like:

1. Crab Legs - Lots of snow crab, cold & steamed. But, no claws, and the small legs had NO flavor. They must be overboiled or old.

2. Mexican Food - Poor selection and odd choices for dishes. I love Mexican food, but found nothing here I wanted seconds on. 

3. Meat Station - Prime Rib was just ok, Ham was undercooked, brisket was good, Salmon was good.

4. Sushi - If you want some vegatables or cream cheese wrapped in rice and seaweed I guess you'll be ok. If you want actual sushi with real fish and seafood, you'll have to go somewhere else. 

5. Breakfast Food - Eggs, eggs, everywhere! If you just want freshly cooked eggs and omelets,  you will love it here. But then, why not just go to Dennys? Its a lot cheaper!  Oh, and the hashbrowns here are mediocre to bad. 

6. Drinks - I bought the $13 drink package. If you want a mimosa with your brunch, you'll have it in a small round glass and it will taste bad.  Want Sangria? You'll have it in a small round glass and it will be mediocre. Want a glass of wine? It will be bad wine served in a small round glass. Want beer? YES get the beer!! Its brand name and on tap. But of course, it will be served in a small round glass!! For $13 though, how can you go wrong?

6. Deserts - Bland, bland, bland...  Gelato - good, good, good!! But why did you take my favorite - Pistachio and make it fat free? Just give me the good stuff!! Afterall, I'm eating at a buffet!!

7. Service - Table wait staff - Good!  Wait staff at service stations - Poor!

Overall - Not something I expected at Aria. I thought it would be much higher quality. I spent the whole time trying something else, hoping I'd find at least one item that I wanted seconds on. Other than the gelato, it didn't happen.

We PARTIED at Rehab in Hard rock, the drinks were priced like being on the strip, but they were a pretty good size. Next, we stopped to eat at the Pink Taco restaurant, the food was awesome (I love Tacos). and then walked next door and got to see some of the hottest dancers at Club Paradise. Drinks were served fast and beers were ten bucks. The club gave me a ride back to the Aria in a limo.(Free ride, tipping is customary) I was staying over at the Aria. I have to brag about their buffet and poker room. It was fun in Vegas on a Sunday. I'd go back to all of these places.

whats going on here-  i see reviews being responded to by Aria management apologizing and vouching improvement and yet still negative reviews.  Patrons are paying a lot of money  $30+ per person for a quality meal and its so disappointing to hear that so many feel it is a waste.  Come on Aria- you are suppose to be one of the quality resorts in Las Vegas.  The restaurants in your establishment are a reflection of your business.  Please STEP IT UP.

Okay just got to give a positive review for this place after all the negative ones I saw. My husband and I came here on Friday for the brunch buffet and guys it was so good! There was a bit of a wait but hey, I don't care. The service was fantastic! They have so much food! Literally I tried everything (judge all you want) and it was so good. 

They have everything. The desserts are incredible, the pancakes were so good, they had fried chicken and waffles, tons of salads and fruit, so much fresh seafood, Mexican station, Italian station, omelet station, carving station, sushi station, dumplings, egg rolls, pho bowls, cereal, muffins, bagels, you name it they have it!

This place wins over Wicked Spoon just cause they have so much variety! The only con is the plates are too damn small haha!

We had lunch there today and after seeing the long lines I was expecting a good meal and selection.
What I had was one of the worst buffet experiences ever. I am not a buffet expert but still has lot of buffets on cruise and other resorts which are free or included and they are lot better than this one.
The selection was very bad almost 2 chicken dishes  in the whole buffet and just cold unpeeled shrimps if you like shrimps.
In both selection and taste i would rate it poor.
Was very disappointed.

The lunch buffet offered a wide selection of food and dessert. They had meat carvings, Italian, Mexican, Asian, family style, sushi, as well as other lunch options available. The quality of the food was great and well seasoned, unlike the typical unseasoned buffet food other hotels offer. Their sea food is what really sold me as well as the huge dessert corner which includes creme brulee, gelato with multiple flavors, cheesecake, and other desserts. The service was good, other than having to ask the waiter for water three times. You get what you pay for.

Pros: unlimited Wine and 1\/2 a lobster free with buffet dinner

Cons: Food is just ok in the buffet, my lobster was tough and gross, and the server rarely if ever came by and so our unlimited wine was only 1 glass.

I would rather go to nicer buffets on the strip with better food and better prices.

This is not the best buffet I ever had. But I wasn't in the mood for paying $40 at the Wynn or Bellagio since I'm not a big eater. In contrast Aria buffet cost $27 which I thought had decent food. I enjoyed the snow crab and king crab which obviously tasted frozen. But what do you expect, Las Vegas is not Maine. The fish - halibut and salmon tasted overcooked and dry. I enjoyed the lamb which my friend claimed to taste too gamey for him. My friend also had an under cooked chicken, pink in the center, yuck!
But the desserts were a delicious heaven, so many choices. If only I had more room. I recommend starting with the desserts!

This buffet really didn't impress me I must say.  All the items they had were non-appetizing. One of the members of my party tried the noodles and said they were greasy, and the selection of items wasn't great. Even the sandwiches didn't look good. The only perk was the crab legs and the chips and guacamole, which were decent. Also, the waiter kept switching and we weren't sure who to ask for refills. The other good thing about this buffet was the dessert section. They had rice krispie treats which I liked, and also they had a great banana cream pie dessert. Also the cookies were excellent, but that was the only great thing about it.

If you are looking to eat alot, drink all the non alcoholic beverages you want, and check out the hotties you might've danced with last night, this is the place to be. There was a lot to choose from-crab legs, shrimp cocktail, salad, prime rib, bacon, dessert, chinese food, etc. Service was great...our waiter was very attentive and made sure to keep our glasses full. Be sure to go around 2-3pm so you can get a taste of breakfast and lunch. Would I go again? Most likely....not the best meal I ever had in Vegas but definitely for the selection.

This was the only buffet we tried (first time visitors) so we don't have anything to compare it to in town. It was nice and at $40\/pp reasonably priced. The variety is small but great tasting, and I could have eaten the Na'an all night. The husband enjoyed the brisket. Everything was clean and bright but a bit too cafeteria style for my taste. Overall I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if it's convenient it's a good option.

Cheaper than Wicked Spoon, Bellagio & Wynn. Not fancy or elaborate in terms of decor, but it's modern and clean. I like coming here for lunches. 

Highlights: 
-Pho station
-Indian food
-Decent amount of seafood, including the popular crab legs 

Ask the waitress to mix all their fruit juices together. Makes for a delicious fruit drink!

Had lunch today,disappointed with the food and service, broth was not hot enough, noodles were undercook, staff were slacking,had to try to get their attention before getting your order, little words spoken and of course Not a smile on a face, from the cashiers to the server behind their stations ....saw a staff handling food with his bare hands! Yuck!

This place IMO was REALLY GOOD!

I came here for dinner with my friends on a Friday and it wasn't really packed at all.  We found out it was unlimited wine after we paid which was like ~$40 (just like any other buffet place in Vegas or prob cheaper).  So definitely worth it!  They had all kinds of food here from Italian to Indian to American to Asian.  The list felt like it went on and on.  Again, I am not a dessert kind of guy, but wow the thing I remembered most was their dessert...(sadly I know...)  Their strawberry shortcake...OUT OF THIS WORLD! It was so flaky and delicious.  Wasn't super sweet like most places.  Just RIGHT!  Next on the list...I know I'm weird...the marshmallow! Marshmallow...really?  YES REALLY!  By far the best tasting marshmallow ever!  It's located next to the chocolate dipped strawberries...(IMO sucked balls).

Hmm maybe I am a desserts kind of guy....=\/

Not worth the price.  I expected delicious over the top Aria type food.  Most of the food has been sittin around dying.  The people cutting the meat were rocking an attitude too.  It's just ok.  I've had better...at half the price.

came here for the brunch buffet... and of course when in vegas... eat your heart out! hmm... actually, that's my motto for everywhere and anywhere you go.... 

the buffet is just ok... selections weren't THAT great...and nothing really stood out from the selections.

my advice... stick to the Buffet at the Wynn.... if you're gonna pay $30 bucks for a buffet, stick to the Wynn... never fails there.

So yummy!!!  It was $35\/person for breakfast & around $15\/person for bottomless drinks of about 10+ choices.  I'm local so trust me when I say, that is not bad for strip prices.  The food was excellent!  Usually at buffets the seafood (especially crab legs) are dry but this was great!  You have to take into consideration at a buffet you're paying for at least 3 meals, dessert & multiple drinks per person so $50 + tip is great!  They had a great selection (however personal preference, I wish there was more Indian food). The carrot cake pancakes were awesome!  I've been to multiple buffets in town & would 100% recommend Aria!

Like most buffets in Las Vegas, this place had a long wait time (1 hr). We decided to stick it out, but must say the cashier was unfriendly and rude. Once we were seated a gentleman took our drink order right away and was very attentive and would offer refills with a few minutes of finishing your drink. 

The food: Theres SO many choices here! mexican, fish market, asian (sushi, build your own pho, etc), indian, italian, a salad bar, soul food (fried chicken, mac and cheese) various meats and an array of desserts (key lime, gelato, caramel popcorn, popcorn with chocolate drizzling, etc). The food was pretty good and fresh, although not great. I was mostly impressed at the variety of foods offered.

My legs grew wary as I stood on the long line at the Buffet, pangs of hunger hitting me here and there. It was a Wednesday night at 7:30 PM. An hour later, my prayers to the food gods were answered and we were finally seated. We were a party of 3 and paid $34.99 each. Feel like getting drunk? Get the bottomless drinks for $12.99 each. 

The place itself was clean and service was efficient after being seated. I wasted no time. I swiftly ran to the bathroom to wash my hands and went straight to the first station I saw: Asian. 

The first plate I got was cashew chicken with fried rice and some Italian chicken along with beef and broccoli. The cashew chicken and beef and broccoli and fried rice were pretty decent but the Italian chicken tasted too much like wine so I didn't finish it. The cashew chicken was too nutty for my taste. 

My second plate was crab legs and sushi. The sushi wasn't any greater than other sushi I have tasted (it was spicy salmon) and the snow crab legs were good too. I don't really know how to open crab legs so I probably would've had a better experience if I knew how to open them, haha. 

My third plate was spaghetti with marinara and alfredo sauce, shrimp, onions, tomatoes, and mushrooms. I actually finished all of this but it wasn't the best pasta I have had (check out Carmine's in NYC). 

My fourth plate was actually dessert because I was waiting for my beef ribs to cook. So instead of just waiting and wasting time, I decided to continue eating. My favorite dessert was the flan; it was absolutely phenomenal. The tiramisu cake sucked so I didn't finish it (way too much espresso). The cheesecake was alright. The cupcakes, yogurt, macaron, and brownie on the stick was ok too. I got chocolate gelato as well...it was meh.

My fifth plate was finally my beef ribs, macaroni and cheese, and mashed potatoes. This was probably my best plate. The mac n cheese and mashed potatoes were delicious. However, the beef ribs could have been cooked more and had more flavor. 

Besides all of the stuff I ate, they had a salad bar, pizza, an Indian station, etc. 

After consuming all this food, I could not get up and entered into food coma. It took me 2-3 hours to recover. 

Overall, I think buffets value quantity over quality but this was one of the better buffets I have been to. However, the food was not particularly phenomenal and didn't get my taste buds dancing. If you're really hungry and what OK food, check it out. I didn't get to check out the Bacchanal Buffet but I know it is also more expensive at $50.

This gets 3 stars because the food wasn't that great and the line was too long, but it was a fair price. They say what happens in Vegas stays in Vegas, but the memory of this bland food will stay with me forever.

The selection was not satisfying. The sushi was not fresh and I can tell the sushi was refrigerated because the rice was hard. The crab legs were salty, I assume they boiled it in salt water. Not worth it to come.

Sometimes, a buffet isn't just about the food.   In fact, the food here is very good.   But, I paid about $75 for brunch for two (one had a bloody mary, so that added to the price a little).   It was crowded in the seating area--and really, really crowded at the omlette station.

It was maybe a $45 experience.

Talk about foreshadowing: anytime you see a short or empty buffet line in Las Vegas, you should beware. The buffet at Aria was average. It was unimpressive for what i thought would be a buffet equal to that of other 5-star hotels like Bellagio or Wynn. 

In terms of variety, I felt the aria buffet tried to accomplish that by offering a number of different international cuisines such as indian, chinese, japanese, etc. However, i still felt that WITHIN each cuisine, there just wasn't much. For example, sure they had japanese food, but specifically they only had 3 types of rolls and some nigiri. No other types of sashimi, no unique rolls, no tempura, etc etc. 
In terms of seafood, they had the usual king crab legs, shrimp scampi, and oysters, but it wasn't any different from what you would find in any other decent buffet. 
In terms of how they serve you the food, it's a little strange: they have their food on smallerl serving plates. While this may give an impression that the dishes are more fresh and replenished more frequently, this also causes an inconvenience to the customer when dishes are constantly running out and staff members have to refill it. This means customers waste more time waiting for their food than eating it. 
On a more positive note, the service was excellent. This is strange just because no one really notices the service or remembers their waiter in a buffet, but mine was so good that i certainly did remember. She was always refilling our drinks, asking if we needed anything, and never late in clearing our used plates. 

Overall, if you had a choice of buffets at Las Vegas, I would still opt for Bellagio or Wynn. The price at Aria is similar to that of other upscale hotel buffets (~40 for dinner) and simply doesnt satisfy in terms of variety or taste.

I don't know what's wrong with the food, this is my second time here, 6 months ago the food they're serving is pretty good, with variety choices, but today all the meat I had is over cooked, super dry, seafood paella look like smushed rice stir with some dry up seafood, the steam clam look like clam in mud, the only good thing is the crab leg is not over cooked.  Dessert is not bad, still many choices, coffee gelato is good. Anyways very disappointing!

Came to Vegas last week and decided to try this buffet out since it's at the new Aria hotel. $29.95 for the brunch buffet!? Given that it was a "Holiday" buffet, I don't think it was worth the price at all. What was so special about the holiday prices? Perhaps it was the king crab legs and oyster bar, but those didn't even taste fresh. 

I've got a few bones to pick with this buffet:
1. I wasn't impressed with the selection of food they had.
2. Items weren't filled up when empty and counters weren't wiped down. 
3. Instead of placards that indicate what dish it is, they used a sharpie to write on the glass. 

For what the hotel is, I think the buffet could have lived up to it. Aria is structurally beautiful and I love that its layout is eco-friendly, but the buffet simply sucks.

I'd actually give then 3.5 stars. The biggest and greatest thing was that they cut the grab legs in half so you have to do a lot less work than other buffets.  I thought they'd have more options as far as different foods from different cultures, so that was a little disappointing.  The food we did have was just OK.  Another great thing - Luis, our waiter.  He was the sweetest and friendliest guy  :-)

I was kinda excited to come here.  I mean, it is a new Hotel with of course new slots, tables, places to check out and even a buffet!  Located on the 2nd floor, Aria really did good and the look of this buffet.  Very sleek, comfortable looking and feeling and very spacious.  Thats all the good i really have to say about this place.

$20 for lunch buffet...The food selection isn't as great as I thought it would be.  The crab legs were cut in half and seasoned a little bit too much, the prime rib??? was juicy and tender.  Their pastas were a bit try tasting cuz i'm sure they were sitting out for sometime, the mussels were small, smaller than an actual dime.  The only yahoo moment was the raspberry cheesecake shot with a lemon syrup on it.  The service needs work..a lot.

As we concluded our epic Vegas weekend celebration, we had our last dinner at The Buffet, located inside the state-of-the-art and magnificent Aria hotel\/casino.  The restaurant is located on the 2nd floor and brilliantly withholds the contemporary theme of the hotel itself.  Upon arrival in the late afternoon, we were greeted by the absence of the line of people in front, but with a warm joyful welcome of the energetic restaurant host.  The pricing is actually excellent compared to any other buffets within the proximity of the strip. (Less than $40\/person, depending on lunch or dinner and the day of the week)

The layout of the buffet is nice and simple.  The beginning of the linear path starts off with seafood and sushi, and as you work your way down, there are vast food selections yielding cuisine of different ethnic cultures. 
~ The crab legs were freshly chilled and sliced in half for easy access to the succulent crab meat.  The cocktail shrimp had a great texture, not too firm and not too tender. The sushi quality and selection were good but not amazing.  
~ I also enjoyed the worldly choices of entrees:  The chicken curry was well-prepared and simmered in a rich plethora of exotic herbs.  It complemented the soft and toasty naan bread, immediately making it one of my favorite dishes.  I also enjoyed the tender slice of prime rib, which was rich in flavor.  The selections of the Chinese and Italian dishes were also delicious and enjoyable.
~The assortment of desserts made a great impression the end of our little feast.  Some of the cakes were a little too sweet (such as the Snickers cake), while others were at its optimum level of sweetness.  The macaroons served to please the taste buds with the correct level of coconutiness.  The gelato was also rich, irresistible, and kept calling for our attention even when our stomachs were filled of the hot savory food from right before. The choco-chip cookies were scrumptious... We took some on the way out =]

Overall, this buffet should linger among the top of your Vegas buffet list due to the astounding value and enjoyable food quality.  Look forward to it!

came here because we had a resort credit.  would probably not have come here without it because it would of been 45 dollars a person since it was 'holiday' pricing.  but i believe most hotels will charge alot during holiday periods.  we came at around 5pm and there wasn't a wait at all.  we also noticed throughout the night that the line wasn't that long compared to lets say the spice market.  like most buffets they have your prime ribs, sushi, crab legs, etc.  some unique stuff we tried were the dim sum, and fish and chips.  they also have a really fresh salad bar.  we both felt the quality of the food and vegetables were very fresh.  unlike most buffets where they leave a lot of old food, we noticed they didn't do that here.  as for desert, they had many selections from creme burlee to cheese cake to ice cream.  one thing we didn't enjoy was the server had too many tables to wait on and therefore it took  a little to get our drinks.  but i guess thats a management issue.  overall i would say this is a great buffet with many different ethic foods and from what we tried, the food all tasted nice and fresh.  because of the price though, i'm not sure if we'll come back for awhile since wynn, belliagio, rio, and spice market are all really good options.

We had a nice dinner here with four guests. We showed up at around 6PM on a Thursday and it was quite slow. I wasn't expecting too much from this buffet, but one of my favorite items, snow crab legs, were so delicious here. They have two varieties: steamed and regular (on ice). The steamed was very fresh with a hint of sweetness to it. I had so many crabbie claws it made my guests a bit concerned. But they were so good!! There's a huge pail of butter right next to it, which only added to the satisfaction. 

I also had the mashed taters, succulent prime rib and pork carved offerings, in addition to the wide variety of deserts (gelato, cakes, cookies, cupcakes, flan, etc.). I didn't get to the fruits and veggies but the seafood selection was pretty good. The sushi was a little lackluster with the highlight being salmon nigiri. However, I'd come here again just for the crab legs (they also have king crab on ice), and maybe the $12.99 bottomless cocktails.

I was excited about trying a buffet in the really modern-cool Aria hotel.  In there description it is  suggested that it is a gourmet buffet, but nothing I experienced was even close to just plain good food.  If you are a vegetarian you are in real trouble here except for the just plain salad.  Most of the items don't give you a clue about the contents ( Vegan, vegetarian, gluten free).  Even the deserts were blah.

I went here for lunch and to my surprise it was actually pretty good with lots of great selection. They had unlimited crab legs! they also had pho (Vietnamese beef soup) wow! how cool. Overall, was a good buffet, I especially loved the mini donuts that they had, it had a nice raspberry or strawberry filling inside..what a sweet surprise!

Really Aria?? A supposedly fancy\/elegant\/sophisticated hotel has a Mexican station with hard shell Tortillas, yellow cheese, ground beef and sour cream? For one moment I though I was at Taco Bell. What an insult for my country. For the price of the buffet I would have expected real tacos. 

Not a really big variety of food. Even prime rib was chewy I couldn't eat it.

Only good thing was the ice cream and the men that served it. He made my day. He was really nice.

 Also, Waiter looked like he was mad at everyone. I was scared to even ask for water.

Instead try the one at the Whynn, Paris or Rio

If you are looking for the high class experience of the Ritz buffet in Grand Cayman this is NOT it. However, it was a lot better than I expected with a huge variety of cuisines that would surely fulfill any desire. (at least on the weekend)

One strange fact I noticed was seeing breakfast items a bit scattered without reason. Why were there waffles and syrup next to the clam dish. Or the same comment for the pancakes near the carving station. I do not think it changed the quality of the food but it did leave me with odd feeling looking around trying to make sense of the offerings.

DISAPPOINTMENT

My wife and I heard all the raves about The Buffet at Aria so decided to cashed in on the comp dinner buffet from Myvegas.

Food - 0\/5

We did the typical routine, walking around getting a little of each to try so we know which one to come back for seconds. On the outside, all foods look very picture perfect, but boy were we wrong.  The food tasted like the chefs had extra salt laying around so they decided to add a few extra table spoons to each dish. I finished 2 glasses of coke before I could finish what was on my plate. After "the sample" dish, we bolted for the desert and didn't bother coming back for seconds. 

Desert was just ok. Nothing exceptional.

Service - 5\/5

Our server was great. Bring our second glass of drink right when we finish our first one. That's attention to detail. Keep up the good work. 

In summary, we were disappointed even when the dinner was free. Could you imagine if we paid $80 for 2 people?

don't do. 

NOT worth the 33 bucks. Will never make this mistake again. Unimpressive is being kind.

Had breakfast buffet twice here during a recent stay. They offer a wide range of cuisines - from American-style to Chinese foods (though, it wasn't very Chinese-y). Overall, the food quality was pretty good, but for the price ($23-$28), it is a bit pricey.

The staff was pretty decent - the waiters were pretty prompt with refilling your drinks. The dining room looks out to the pool. Depending on who's swimming out there, could be a nice view, or it could cause you to lose your appetite. ;)

Okay I have decided to write a review on a buffet that is so-so.  Not sure if I am being fair with this as I generally do not enjoy buffets...any place that I have have to wait in line or watch people mull around with plates of food in their hands while they "sample and eat" at various food stations does not appeal to me.

Needless to say The Buffet at Aria has vastly improved from its original days.  Clean, open dining area seen from the hallway makes it feel spacious.  The individual food stations were small while the portions were also small...nice!  Better than a huge stainless steel tray and a spoon where you scoop up your portion size. I think this is better so that you will eat smaller portions and more variety.

It was nice to see a seafood station that is part of their regular menu...nit some special Only on Friday or the weekend.

If you like buffets and are with friends or family, I would suggest giving this one a shot however if you're looking to be impressed there are others that are far better than Aria....
Such a nice hotel with such sad food. I was overall disappointed, even though the venue was nice. Saw some people from the Glee TV show there, but nothing worth writing about.

Came here on a Saturday night with a group of friends for dinner at around 6:15 pm (by the time we left at 8:00 pm a long line had formed an the entrance of the buffet). Different stations included: salad station, seafood station (hot steamed crab legs, crab claws, raw oysters, crab fish, various sushi, paella, mussels fra diablo, seared salmon, iced cooked shrimp), Asian station (3 varieties of steamed dumplings, beef in garlic ginger sauce, chicken in some sauce as well), various breads and pastas, various cheeses and meats, pizza, and some other stations that I have forgotten. Upon looking around at all of the options I made a dive for the steamed crab legs and the iced crab claws. The steamed crab legs were delicious and salted just right and the iced crab claws were delicious as well. Besides attacking the crab legs and claws (which constituted the majority of my meal) I also tried the osso bucco, which was delicious and resulted in me coming back for seconds. I also had the mussels and clams from the paella, which were cooked well and a couple of pieces of sushi (nothing to wow at). 
   For dessert I had the creme brûlée, which was perfect. Creamy custard with a crunchy torched sugar topping. Caramel macchiato and chocolate gelato with caramel syrup, Oreo cookies, and banana flambé. The flan was good too, but a little too sweet for my taste. The black Forrest chocolate cake was good, the sweetness of the chocolate cake was contrasted with the thin raspberry jelly on top of the cake. I also tried the smores as well as the caramel popcorn which tasted fresh. 
   Our waiter here was very attentive, friendly, and nice. She also brought everyone 2 glasses of water or soda (depending upon what they ordered) as the glasses are 8 oz, not 16 oz. she was also very quick to refill the drinks when they were close to being empty and was very quick to take away the dirty plates as well. 
   Caesars buffet, which I also tried, does have a lot more options than Aria, especially when it came to the gelato variety as well as the amount of various stations, but for a $20 difference ($40 at aria vs $60 at Caesars) I would go to Aria as I love my hot steamed crab legs more than I like the iced ones.

Pros:
- it is at Aria
- there are a wide variety of selections

Cons:
- very mediocre food 
- almost everything was bland, reminding me of dorm room meals and community kitchens
- no matter what the cuisine (american, Mediterranean, Chinese, indian, seafood, desserts), they ended making a mediocre version of it
- huge disappointment considering it is $35-40 per person

Like all other tables in Vegas, there is strategy involved when hitting the buffet.

I took my practiced hand to "The Buffet" at Aria last weekend when I was in sin city. It's a good choice though not the best buffet I've visited. It features a few stand-outs -- and a few misses -- among otherwise average food.

I'll get to what I liked and didn't like in a moment, but first allow me to share my philosophy on smart buffet dining.

To get the full dining experience at any buffet you need to go in with a plan. There is no wrong plan, it's all a matter of personality.

For example, the Scouters will tell you to do a walk-thru of all the counters before even picking up a plate. The Meat Heads go straight for the carving table to satisfy their carnivorous cravings and get their "money's worth". The Aristocrats start with courses -- maybe a hearty salad and soup for round 1, followed by the protein and carbs in round 2, and finished off nicely with a dessert and coffee for round 3.

But for me, I personally fall firmly into the Forager camp. I am curious and I like variety. I need to try as many tastes as I can in order to feel my trip to the buffet has been a success.

Therefore, I start at one end with one plate and literally take just a spoonful of each item that remotely catches my interest. I'll sit down  with a plate that looks something like this:

A small helping of a greens and typical salad toppings, two pieces of sushi, a spoonful of garlic mashed potatoes, a beef enchilada, two small spoonfuls of lamb curry, a spoon of basmati rice, some blueberries, a spoon of Mediteranean pasta salad, and a slice of lamb with some mint jelly.

To the untrained eye, my plate looks like the mess of a buffet novice, however there is order to my chaos. It's all about portion control. I get one, maybe two bites of everything. Then I can go back and try other things, or get more of the items I loved from the first round.

I'd say I got to sample at least 80% of Aria's buffet this way. Here are my favorites:

1) Leg of lamb at the carving station
2) NY Strip at the carving station
3) Shrimp Cocktail
4) Freshly made garlic naan (they even have a tandoori oven at the counter!)
5) Lychee, scallop coconut salad
6) Crab Legs (I can't eat them, but everyone at my table said they were great)
7) Creme Brulee

Things I didn't like:
1) sub-par sushi
2) beef enchilada
3) dulce leche dessert
4) not enough labels on food (was I eating lamb curry, or beef curry?)

Another part of the plan: make sure you go for brunch -- it was $26 (with tax) before 4 p.m. The prices rises to $30+ for dinner.

Dear Aria Buffet: YOU RUINED FATHER'S DAY FOR US.

I took my husband here for Father's Day because he wanted to try this place out - this buffet ruined our holiday, single handed. As an avid buffet adventurer, I have been to 90% of the buffets offered on the Strip - and, congratulations, you are by far the WORST one yet. Before you start defending your so-called gourmet delicacies, I'd like to say that I am not a buffet expert, a chef, or anyone who knows culinary art. However, I have eaten at a LOT of buffets, more than I care to count, mainly because I enjoy variety in my food and the endless possibilities, and I'd like to think that I have at least somewhat of an idea of what food is supposed to taste like. But, let me make my case:

1. The food..MEDIOCRE, at best. For a very expensive buffet ($50\/person), it lacked everything that an expensive buffet had. Let me start with the selection - limited, bland, and everything was just all wrong. 
ASIAN - they had vegetable dumplings, vegetable potstickers, vegetable everything (more on veggies later). There were only 2 choices of soup there, fried rice, chow mein, and crab legs. ITALIAN - spaghetti, some kind of veggies (again), veggie lasagna, a bowl of banana chips and a bowl of cranberries (WTF?). 
CARVING STATION - meats were cold...they just sat there under a heat lamp, but once it hit your plate, it went cold quick. 
TANDOORI - I'm sorry, I'm not Indian, but I swear the "tandoori chicken" looks\/tasted exactly like baked chicken. Not sure why they even tried to pass that off as anything tandoori. The rest of the curry tasted like melted mustard.
DELI - didn't even try this station, it just looked like a large collection of Lunchables meats and cheese. 
FISH MARKET (seafood station) - The station was full of duplicate foods just too make it look like it was filled. Two buckets of crab legs, 2 buckets of crawfish, 2 buckets of mussels, and 1 bucket of oysters. The oysters looked like they were picked from the bottom of the reject buckets from other, better, buffets. The oysters were stale tasting, and they sat in a pile on the ice...the ones on top were warm and the ones on bottom were still frozen. Pretty sure they're not supposed to be like that at all - something about food regulations, I'm sure. 
DESSERT - this is by far the only dessert station on the Strip that pales in comparison to the dessert bar at my local 9.99 Chinese buffet. The desserts aren't even made there - they came from a box, and all your "chefs" did was pull it out of the box and plop it on a plate. And seriously, who serves chocolate chip cookies and boxed pies? At a $50\/person buffet? I expected this from the $9.99\/person Chinese buffet down the street from my house, but not from YOU, fancy-hotel&buffet-on-the-strip. I was really, really disappointed. 

2. Did I mention the customer service? The "chef" at the seafood station was rude and nasty. I was standing next to a young girl waiting for the prawns.
