There were also TONS of other things (clams, gazpacho, Mexican food, Meat cut to order, Indian, Mediterranean, and more); unfortunately, I stuffed my face with mostly crab, cod and green beans.

The desserts are also awesome!  They have carrot cake, red velvet whoopie pies, 5 layer chocolate cake, cake pops, cheesecake, pecan cake, strawberry cakes, gelato, macaroons, cookies, and more!

Also, for $12.99 you can have bottomless mimosa, red & white sangria, and other alcoholic drinks.

I have dined here twice for DINNER, on two separate occasions, and I must say I am a fan. Who wouldn't want complimentary lobster and wine! Sure the Merlot, which is my choosing, is a teeny wee bit on the dry side, it still is good. Their crab legs are definitely tasty too since they don't throw a bunch of salt on it like other buffets do. And their salmon nigiri is always fresh and delish! I loveeee salmon, and salmon nigiri is like jackpot! Their prime rib is cooked well, more on the medium rare side, my preference. It's not dry like other buffets and seasoned quite well, which is impressive. They have a make it yourself pasta section where you choose the noodles, sauce and meat. I don't eat the mexican and chinese food sections since I detest chinese food and I eat mexican food in San Jose on a daily basis. Their dessert section is ok, but after eating their food, dessert is tooo filling. Maybe add macaroons to your dessert selection? =)
Save your money and go to hometown buffet, it's the exact same food. Seriously disappointing. Had to come here by default since wicked spoon was closed.

This was the worst buffet!!! We spent about 90-100 dollars for two persons, we got there around 8:40pm and everything was dry and looked old. Although most of the food looked unappetizing we gave it a try. When I got to the seafood I was craving the shrimp. There was about 15 shrimps left and I asked for more, and the lady working in that section told me there was no more because it is 9:15 ish and they would be closing soon. I was so disappointed since I am pregnant and shrimp is probably the safest while expecting. I literally cried because I spent almost 100 dollars only for shrimp, and a piece of carrot cake. My boyfriend tried other items, but he agreed this buffet was garbage. BAD PLACE we went back to our room and ordered pizza .

My favorite buffet in Vegas. THIS WAS AMAZINGLY AWESOME! Quality & wide selection. Everything from grape leave wraps to miso soup to crawfish to pizza to fresh sliced prime rib & pork to eggs Benedict to hand made sorbet... Upscale and way better than Bacchanal that is advertised everywhere! I will be visiting this buffet each time I go to Vegas.

So this definitely falls short of the bellagio buffet even though it's only a bit cheaper ... But it's still really good...

Came here during brunch so we had a nice variety of food,though didnt seem as big as the bellagio. 

Eggs Benedict was on point... Deserts were also pretty good but again fell short of it's old world neighbor.

Staff was amazing though, came in a bit rough so hydration was key... I was working with coffee orange juice coke and water and I'll tell you wat not one of them were ever empty 

Definately would recommend but the bellagio is better
The best one around this area. Cause it has the best Asian foods. Appreciated! The desert is good I can't stop stick on ice creams.

Went there Wednesday for breakfast before flying out since we were staying at Vdara. $43 for 2 people.  The coffee was good and our service was 4 stars,  but the food overall was subpar.  All the hot food on the buffet line was lukewarm at best. The scrambled eggs were seriously undercooked and the omelet station used carton scrambled eggs not fresh eggs.  It's a shame that such a beautiful property such as Aria has such a mediocre buffet.

DO NOT GO. Go to the Starbucks and get a sandwich and I'm sure you will enjoy your meal more. This place is an epic waste. $35\/person for brunch and horrible. If u need to go to a buffet go to wicked spoon at Cosmo but avoid this place like the plague. Everything was salty. The guy making eggs didn't know how to a make a sunny side up egg. Dim sum was horrible. This place was so bad even the cut fruit tasted horrible.

Finding this strip buffet from the parking garage can be a real adventure. The buffet is in a very attractive, contemporary, and bright setting. I've been here for lunch before - this was my first dinner. An active staff kept the serving areas very clean. Very good table service: beverage were kept filled and dishes removed from the table very promptly. A few floor spills were quickly cleaned up. Dinner selections were varied, definitely upscale, looked good, and tasted good. They had an especially large seafood area and plenty of steamed clams. The prime rib, a critical item in my judgment of a buffet, was excellent. As with many strip buffets, there's a strong emphasis on international foods and seafood. Overall, I was impressed with dinner. Prices are competitive with other "high end" strip buffets and I consider it among the better strip buffets for dinner. Unfortunately, MGM's absurd, new parking charges void my return here in the future.

Convient for those staying at the Aria but not really worth it to come from anywhere else just to eat. 

Breakfast was passable at $14.99 a person. In particular I thought it was interesting that they had 6 different types of sausages and veal bacon for breakfast.  Moreover the seating was very spacious (like the parking spots at the hotel). However everything else was pretty normal with your standard breakfast fare. Services was good and the place was extremely clean feel to it.

Stay Away Stay Away Stay Away!

There's literally 10 better buffets within a short distance.  I have NO IDEA how they could have come up with such a lousy buffet at such an expensive property but, shazzam, they did it.

Just not good.  The only reason I don't give it 1 star is because I reserve that for places that are nearly or actually inedible.

Still love this buffet. This time got a free MyVegas redemption. Went Thursday dinner. Only difference we noticed between weekday and weekend"gourmet"  dinner is they weren't grilling seafood in the middle and no creme brûlée.  But prime rib, crab, shrimp still there

Note- no prime rib label but they have it. 
Also: mac n cheese and naan bread surprising really good. Usually skip carbs in buffet but they're worth it
But skip: watermelon lime juice, Thai tea, steamship beef

***also only bad thing is the water tasted gross. Not sure what it was but bring your own or order soda

I went to the buffet at Aria not long after the hotel first opened. It wasn't busy at all that night and service was great. The food was replenished pretty quick when items were running low, but some of the items lacked flavor. While it was a good meal I wouldn't necessarily make a point of returning to this buffet out of all the other delicious ones in Vegas.
Thanksgiving Feast was bomb, Caviar bar and the oyster bar was amazing. Long lines but to be expected on thanksgiving in Vegas.

Been to a lot of buffets, expensive and non and I would say this one is great for the price you pay. Tons of food to choose from, a lot of which is made to order. Loved the chilequiles for breakfast, the bacon was perfect and the yogurt bar was amazing! I got the french toast dips, a number of sausages, salad and everything was very tasty. The dessert bar... oh man. I felt like a kid in a candy store. Everything looked amazing. Lemon bar, brownie, gelato. All of it was great. The coffee was good too! I would definitely eat here again during my next stay.

hell no i would not recommend this to anyone... i was there sat. morning & sunday afternoon again though of lunch\/dinner will be better than breakfast... well it turs out I was wrong pretty much its all the same sh*t .. (excuse my language) 

sat. morning its $23.95 per person & my brother was also charged as an adult. kids & adult same price... the food weren't that much selection... the texture of the food weren't that great.. desert is way too dry & not really appealing... the only thing i like the most was their fresh fruit.. which is only melon, watermelon, pineapple, & strawberry. 

sun. afternoon... cost $30.95 per person pretty much the same... except no more fruit, only fruit salad -_-..... 

the place is beautiful but the serivce is horrible ... the place is not well managed... 

NEVER AGAIN! ... i was full but i didn't know what i ate nothing I can say "that was so good" .. sorry stomach i'll treat u better next time ..

My girlfriend and I are veteran Vegas buffet junkies. We've been to almost all the buffets on the strip and have been going for years. Aria's buffet received two stars not because of the food quality, but because of the disappointment factor. We expected a Wynn or Bellagio quality Buffet for the price and location, but it was well below par. The other reviews are very appropriate, it is very drab and boring inside, someone said it looked like a cafeteria, they were about right. If you went for the lobster, don't set your hopes too high. The lobster was dry and you only receive half a lobster, it's like Todai.

Went at around 3 PM and stayed until 4:30 to get both brunch and dinner food.  The food was not very good.  Alot of it "looked" good, but when i tasted it, I was always dispointed.  Honestly, the best thing was the mac and cheese.  The sushi was terrible.  The pizza was OK.  The cook to order pasta was pretty good.  The fish and chips were pretty good.  A cheese station was pretty good.  The eggplant rotini thing was not good.  The desserts were terrible even though they looked amazing.  The "Indian" food was not good at all.    The salmon was terrible - it tasted like they cooked it in a s hitton of butter but it still had no flavor except for the butter.  Go to Bellagio.

We went for dinner buffet.  There was a good variety of food at the buffet.  Seafood, Asian,  Indian, Mediterranean, carved meat,  salad bar, dessert. Food was average at best.  I guess you pay for the variety\/options for food.service was atrocious.  They have you pay for buffet beforehand,  and I guess it was my bad,  I included the tip beforehand. I would hve never left a good tip for the atrocious service we received.  We had to flag down our server for refills.  Our plates were not cleared off our table. Thankfully we didn't opt for all you can drink for two hours for additional $17, we would have never received our drinks in time .  Next time we ll try Caesar or Wynn.
MUCH better the second time around.  They definitely worked out a lot of the kinks from the service.
We stayed at the Aria this past weekend. LOVED IT! The buffet was really good. Good quality and lots of choices. I didn't feel like crap all day long either. VERY GOOD. I recommend.

My first time to the City Centre. Our group decided to give Aria buffet a try since we had already eaten at Bellagio which we knew would never disappoint. Aria did not disappoint us at all. It apparently is the only buffet in Vegas that comes with a whole Maine lobster per person! The lobster isn't small either....you get one big peice and it's good. I'd have to say the best part of the buffet for me (and I'm more of an entree person) was the desserts!!!! YUM!!!!! Save room for the desserts cuz they won't disappoint. I guess the variety of the entrees\/side dishes was good, but something was just missing for me and I can't quite figure it out - it just wasn't enough to satisfy my appetite which I consider huge. Other than the desserts, do try the garlic naan breads - YUM! Other than that.....ambience\/service is great. It's different than the other buffets also where the food is presented in a cafeteria-style lineup. It's been 5yrs since returned to Vegas so to be fair, I can't quite compare Bellagio's buffet to Aria's although I wish I had if the distance wasn't the issue since we were hanging out at Aria afterwards. After all the walking you do on the strip, anymore walking must be deemed absolutely necessary!!! I'd recommend the Aria Buffet - you have to give it a try - it won't disappoint - it's definitely not a bad one and probably on the same level as Bellagio if not slightly under.

I am going to be rather harsh in my review, although there are definite redeeming qualities about this buffet.  My cousin, his friend, and I recently visited Vegas for a quick trip.

We decided to go to only one buffet. I usually go to the The Buffet at the Bellagio, but we thought to give Aria a shot since it was a new hotel and all.

Like everything else at Aria, it was beautifully decorated with modern touches.  Our waitress was attentive and the crowds weren't too bad.

Now to get into the ONE and ONLY reason why this is a two star review:  
- Holy s**t balls about the sushi.  It was like if a first grader was making sushi rice for the first time.  It was hard, under-cooked, and not sticky at all that sushi rice is suppose to be.  No one should be forced to eat things that can make your bowels run like Niagara Falls after rain.  And no good restaurant should even have the audacity to serve something like that.

On to why it's not a one star review:
- Prime Rib cooked to perfection
- Pasta bar that has a super nice chef ready to take your order.  (He also makes good basic pastas.)
- Dessert bar to die for: Creme Brulee, Ice Cream Bar, Crisp-on-the-outside soft-on-the-inside cookies. more Creme Brulee, Oreo Pudding Shooters, Tropical Carrot Cake, and did I mention the Creme Brulee.

I don't care for Alaskan King Crab legs, but they have those as well.  I didn't have any of their Mexican or Indian wares, since I know I can get those on the cheap when I go home.  I mean chips, salsa, and guac is what you have for Mexican.  Really?  For a weekday dinner where I spend thirty dollars for a good meal, that money should have just gone to a sit down restaurant with a prix fixe meal.  That probably would have been more satisfying.

Went here for lunch.  Everything took forever.  There were lots of tables but they don't seat you right away.  The drink cups are so small and they don't refill  them right away.  Also they don't refill on the food either.  Lots of empty food trays.  There is one guy at the dessert area and they were completely out of dessert but he remain on the ice cream station not refilling any dessert.

Update:  That night I had really bad food poisoning.  Ugh!!!

First Impression: Great decor, bright seating, many food selections

What impressed me:
Crab legs were sliced lengthways to allow easy consumption
Omelettes were made fresh to order
Jean Philippe cakes were displayed on top of dessert shelf
Servings portioned out to allow tasting

I enjoyed this buffet for brunch. I would even go as far to say that I prefer this over Wicked Spoon. The food here was fresh and tasty.

We stopped by at The Buffet at ARIA based on a recommendation and we were definitely pleased! The brunch here was $29.99 (+tax & tip) and we were happy to find that there was a little bit for everyone!

My favorites were definitely the breakfast selections .. cute little baskets with waffles & french toast!! I thought some of the other delicious items were the blueberry blintz, the side of mashed potatoes & gravy, and general so's chicken & fried rice. The dessert selections were delicious as well, especially the panna cotta!

The services was spot on during the time we were eating. We got drink refills in a timely manner, our plates were cleared off our table while we got up to get another plate, and for what we received, we thought the buffet was very fairly priced.

Although the line to get in was long, we thought it was worth the wait. This has by far been the best buffets I've been to in Las Vegas!
Most simple but yet tasteful cleanest buffet ever. Yes they do lack alot of variety of food unlike other buffets but Arias buffet has quality unlike other ones.

ONE WORD, EPIC!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This is the king of buffets. I've never seen such a big buffet in my life. 
We came here on Monday for brunch. The fee was $22.99  for two hours of unlimited food. If you wanted unlimited mimosas, bloody marys, and champagne for extra $16.99 extra, though.
 
Honestly, it was worth every penny.

I think you need to go on an empty stomach in order to enjoy everything lol.

It's so amazing how they have multiple sections for different foods all over the world. Some of the sections are Mediterranean, Asian, Latin and Italian. They also have seafood, desserts....honestly, anything you can think of they had it. 

The craziest thing I saw that made me label them the king of buffets was that they had two specific items one was corn- Mexican style with mayo and cheese. I honestly never seen a buffet have something so specific and authentic. Another was red velvet pancakes- with nutella. 

What I also like about the buffet that it is very spacious and you never had to wait to get anything! 

Our server was also very sweet and attentive. 

I would never think of going to any other buffet in Las Vegas besides this one.

I have to say for 40 bucks it was pretty good, very nice and clean. Food like pled very fresh and not like other buffets where it's been sitting there. Only thing I have to say was that he ting our drinks refilled took a bit. Other than that I would go back again

When I was in Vegas last year, I checked out Aria's buffet to see what was on their menu. What I saw was something spectacularly presented. The price was out of my range at the time, but I had budgeted to attend for this year's visit. Unfortunately, the presentation wasn't nearly as good. What happened? Not only were the dishes plain, but there were crumbs and sauces spilled everywhere. Many of the nameplates above the food weren't there and some were mislabeled. I had to ask a few times to figure out what something was. Another disappointment was when I frequented the Chinese section's "Dim Sum" area, many of the bamboo steamers were empty. I checked about 5 times during the span of an hour, and they were out each time. What can make this worse was that a lady behind the dessert section, who was having a bad day, snapped at me for waiting for her to put the food out. At this point, Aria deserved a 1 star from me.

Fortunately, the dishes I sampled were outstanding. The chow fun and fried rice in the Chinese section were very authentic and had great "wok-hay." This translates from Chinese as "captured flavor by the high-heat from a seasoned wok." The tender roast beef was cooked perfectly with small sections of fat attached for flavor. One my favorite items I indulged were Italian large shrimps meant as a pasta topping. I just ate them by themselves. The shrimp was cleaned well, cooked to the right temperature, contained lots of meat, and smothered in a heavenly butter sauce. I had a good waitress and the few dishes I had made it worth coming. In the future, I will probably not return since there are other good buffets to try in Vegas for approximately the same price.

Everything looks beautiful and you feel like the price is worth it until you bite into the food. The food was such a dissapointment that I would not eat it for free. The gelato and all the dessert are horrible .The other restaurants in the hotel are around the same price..... more or less and the food is 2000000× better. Please avoid coming here if you are a food snob. This is on a hospital food level of nasty.

There are so many places to eat in Las Vegas and for this buffet, I was not impressed. I was told to eat at a buffet because "that is what you do in Vegas." So, giving it a try, I landed in the hotel's buffet. Aria is a beautiful hotel however the food at the buffet is less than stellar. Most of the food that I had was either too salty or dry. There was not a great selection of foods here to choose from. I would highly suggest that they do a food makeover of this buffet. The only decent thing they had to offer, besides the nice staff, was the desserts. However, even the desserts were pretty basic and lacked any imagination. All that said, I would not pay the price to come to this buffet again.
Five stars for Danny !!!! Our server was amazing never been to a  pace with such a nice guy love the food love the place coming back

Don't come here expecting the best buffet you've ever had. The food quality is mediocre at best. Crab legs are pretty good. Not as good as the Seafood buffet at Rio. Crawfish was lackluster. Come on where's the Cajun seasoning? Oysters during dinner were a decent value. Besides that everything else is disappointing. Chinese...boring. General Tso's Chicken tastes weird. BBQ Pork buns were not authentic. Pretty crappy Chinese fare actually. Italian? Forget about it...crappy pizza and vegetable lasagna. Indian.... Meh you get better Indian food at a local Indian buffet. Fried chicken? Over fried and probably double fried since they were hard as a rock and not juicy and tender. Mexican? Another meh... Prime Rib was decent. Having lived in the Midwest. Definitely not in the very good category. Not to bad though. I was highly unimpressed with this place. Everything was average to below average. Crab legs, oysters, and shrimp were the only positives. Even the clams and mussels didn't taste that great.

Dessert...wow was I disappointed. Cheesecake was lame. Their Gelato was pretty good. 

For lunch $25.99 on the strip. It was ok value. Otherwise save yourself the trouble and go elsewhere.

Luckily this was the first buffet we went to on our Vegas trip because otherwise, I would have been even more disappointed!! First of all, they don't have a wide variety of foods at all compared to some of the other better Vegas buffets... All of the food is categorized, which made it easy to find everything, but there wasn't a big selection in each category. I found the foods I tried to be OK, but nothing amazing. I had the Indian, Mexican, Japanese, and "American" foods (sweet potatoes, casserole), but nothing really stood out. The dim sum was dried out, and the Indian food wasn't very authentic tasting. Some of the foods weren't even hot, just warm. The desserts were pretty good, but the "gelato" was really just regular ice cream that you can buy in the supermarket. The worst part was the service... our server brought us each one drink and when we immediately finished them (they give you TINY glasses!!) she avoided eye contact and rushed by us many times, until I literally had to grab her sleeve to ask for another drink. She seemed annoyed that I was asking for a refill. They also didn't come by often enough to take our plates, which is a given at a buffet! We paid $45 each (with taxes and tip) which did not seem worth it... the taste and quality just did not measure up. I don't know how this buffet stays in business.

I agree with the others who have said that Aria is a 5 star resort and this buffet is very disappointing. It is NOT what you'd expect after spending time in the rest of Aria. My husband and I also had high hopes for this buffet, and it failed us! The buffet at Caesar's was amazing.. there's no comparison.

Worst buffet ever made in vegas. Basically a rip off ($35 each), with just a straight line of selection. Food was not even that great, the only highlight was the steak, the creme brulee, and unlimited wine. But if you're at a buffet, you want various selection of food not just wine. 

I don't recommend this at all, especially if you're starving and they tell you that they're serving "gourmet" food, most likely thats a lie.

Meh.

You'd expect a brand new, snazzy hotel to wow you with a marvelous buffet...it was mediocre at best.

My worst experience was getting burned by a VERY hot metal serving spoon right in front of a server, dropping it, and him giving me a condescending look. Really? 

The waitress tried to get us drunk by putting 3\/4 champagne in our mimosas...it's not bad, but I'd like to also taste the orange juice.

Food included Asian, Mexican, breakfast and roast beef with the works. There were no tags or signs, since they hand write it on the glass covers...hope you can read their writing. 

And as for the dessert? 3 kinds of oatmeal cookies, chocolate whoopie (tasteless) pie, flan, and ice cream. I read the desserts were amazing.........where have people been comparing these to, hometown buffet? They were, at most, subpar.

Not worth the $40+ per person + $6 drink.

Good food for a better price than Bellagio.
Lots of choices and fresh pasta was good.
Lamb was good and they had Indian and Mediterranean menu which was very good for us.

Small selection consisting of mostly Asian cuisine and the usual pizza, pasta, and salad bar. The only worth while item is the fresh crab legs, that were delicious. $17 all you can drink option is a plus, great cocktails to choose from.

I've now been to three Vegas buffets for dinner and my ranking is:

1. Wicked Spoon at the Cosmopolitan
2. Bellagio Buffet
3. Buffet at Aria

I expected a little bit better. Everything reminded me of what I'd get at an all-inclusive resort. Everything was just a little bit off. 

However, I really did appreciate the warm crab legs and had a boatload of them. 

There's a sign at the beginning of the line that says the wait is ~1.5 hours from that point. Luckily, the line only took 45 minutes.

Good buffet with several different stations such as sliced meats, crab legs, salad bar omelet stations for brunch etc.  If you have a large party then this is a good place to go, because there's something for everyone.  

Their dessert station is okay it has a bunch of mini pies and cakes as well as someone scooping ice cream. Honestly your better off using your calories elsewhere for the desserts.

I was in Vegas recently and checked out this buffet twice.  The first time was Sunday Brunch (I Highly Recommend).  They had red velvet cake pancakes-they were unreal-so awesome.  They had carrot cake pancakes, delicious prime rib, ten different flavors of ice cream, blueberry blintzes..I could go on-It was crazy!!  I also went for breakfast one morning on a regular weekday.  It was still great, but no prime rib..Brunch-do Sunday Brunch!!

I think the trick for this buffet is coming in at the right price.  Going in at the tail end of breakfast into lunch is the best, Thurs\/Fri brunch would still be an acceptable price.  Anything beyond the $24.95 they charge for that, and it's not worth it.  That's mostly because the variety of food isn't nearly as impressive as the other big buffets - it's completely dwarfed by Studio B at the M Resort, and probably the Wynn and Bellagio buffets as well (but I've been to neither of those and can't say for sure).

We got in towards the tail end of breakfast.  For some reason, the switchover was extremely late, I don't think it started flipping until past noon.  That turned out to be a blessing, as some of their breakfast items were pretty nice - eggs benedict and omelette bar were my favorites.  The brisket at lunch was pretty dang good too.  Avoid most of the Asian food and especially the sushi, I remember those seeming like they were lifted right out of a $10 asian buffet.  Remember to save room for dessert, those were not bad. 

The designers did a great job with the dining room - the lighter colors and big windows really help the airy atmosphere,  It's much nicer than the Wicked Spoon's totally enclosed, black and orange motif.  Service was fine for us, but part of that was probably because of our large group of 20.  All in all, wouldn't mind going again if we were staying in a nearby hotel, but depends on the timing, as mentioned.

Linda was amazing! She was the best waitress that we had in Vegas!!!  We could have used more vegetarian options and vegetarian items were always labeled as such. The weight at 11:30 was about 45 minutes. They were empty seats, but that would not allow people to stop them. The food was pretty tasty for what it was.
AMAZING BOMB DOT COM! the lady was so nice came for dinner but got charged for lunch price so that's a plus! my most favorite was the seafood of course!!
